Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
"I lost control.  I pushed someone who was in control."

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient is a ___ year old man with unknown past psychiatric
history who apparently became agitated at a widespread panic
concert and was observed to be kicking and spitting, requiring 7
officers to subdue him.  He was brought to the ED by ambulance
and was highly agitated on presentation, chanting loudly in
gibberish which he called "speaking in tongues."  The patient 
was
given Zyprexa 10mg and became more sedate, but was still unable
to cooperate with an interview and responded to questions with
gibberish.  

On re-evaluation the following morning, the patient was able to
speak coherently at times giving his father's name and phone
number, but repeatedly reverted back to gibberish, at which 
point
he would gesticulate and make facial expressions as if he were
trying to communicate something important.  He exhibited 
paranoia
asking for a glass of water and then refusing it three times
because it had been spit in.  He was evasive and guarded and
repeatedly suggested that the interviewers would burn in hell 
and
stated that he spoke to god daily and that he knew how to speak
in tongues.  He was easily distractible asking if we thought it
interesting that the sheets had the word ___ printed on
them.  He became quickly frustrated with the questioning and
demanded that we leave the room and threatened that we would all
be in trouble once he got out of the hospital.

Obtained collateral information from pt's father ___
___ cell, ___ office, ___ home).
According to the father, last ___ pt was behaving 
bizzarely, walking
naked around the house, staying in bathroom for several hours,
punching walls, singing, reading Bible, writing, talking about
suicide. Pt's father describes some ideas of reference, eg pt
reading a newspaper and relating it to himself, grandiosity - pt 

thinking he's direct descendant ___ ___. Father
states that pt is preoccupied with scars on his face s/p acne as
a teenager and often feels that people are looking at him. He is
not really able to describe concrete manic episodes, rather he
states that pt usually keeps to himself, sleeps during the day,
plays drums at 3 am in the attic.      

Additional collateral info was obtained per ___
(___), ___ at ___, who
visited pt at the hospital. Ms. ___ stated that she knows very
little about the patient. According to her, he is taking 2
classes at ___ - Creative Writing and 
Music.
Pt's creative writing professor remarked that pt has been in
class only twice, that he was "strange, sarcastic, detached, had
written a bizarre writing excercise". 

Medical records obtained from pt's ___ hospitalization
indicate that he was started on Lithium 300 mg 2 po AM and 3 po
___, as well as Lunesta 3 mg po qhs, and Valium 5 mg bid prn.

 
Past Medical History:
According to the father pt has been diagnosed with bipolar
disorder in ___ after being hospitalized for bizzare
behavior at ___ in ___, ___. At that
time pt was started on Lithium, which he has been taking
sporadically. He was followed by a psychiatrist Dr. ___
___ ___. Pt has suffered from depression
since age ___, been on mul. He has been hospitalized multiple
times. He has hx of SA, first at age ___ for OD on "some pills"
and also another time he put rope around his neck.

Per father, no ___ PMH, no allergies
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
none
 
Physical Exam:
On admission:
MENTAL STATUS EXAM (USE FULL, DESCRIPTIVE SENTENCES WHERE
APPLICABLE)
     APPEARANCE & FACIAL EXPRESSION:  Patient is a dishevelled
young man with short brown hair and facial scruff.  he has a
small abrasion on his L shoulder and some light bruising around
his jaw line.  He avoids eye contact and has a blank expression
on his face.
     POSTURE:  No bizarre posturing or waxy flexibility.
     BEHAVIOR (NOTE ANY ABNORMAL MOVEMENTS):  Patient initially
chanting loudly in gibberish when first brought into ED.
     ATTITUDE (E.G., COOPERATIVE, PROVOCATIVE):  Patient
uncooperative with interviewer, demanding that interviewer 
"leave
now" and "stop asking questions."
     SPEECH (E.G., PRESSURED, SLOWED, DYSARTHRIC, APHASIC, 
ETC.):
Speech pressured at times, sing song in quality, 
incomprehensible
as it sounds like a different language that he calls "speaking 
in
tongues."
     MOOD:  Patient declines to say.
     AFFECT (NOTE RANGE, REACTIVITY, APPROPRIATENESS, ETC.): 
Restricted, dysphoric.
     THOUGHT FORM (E.G., LOOSENED ASSOCIATIONS, TANGENTIALITY,
     CIRCUMSTANTIALITY, FLIGHT OF IDEAS, ETC.):  Thought process
is disorganized, tangential as he answers questions with
irrelevant responses and is easily distracted.  
     THOUGHT CONTENT (E.G., PREOCCUPATIONS, OBSESSIONS,          

DELUSIONS, ETC.):  Patient is hyperreligious, paranoid,
grandiose.
     ABNORMAL PERCEPTIONS (E.G., HALLUCINATIONS):  Patient
declines to answer.  However, states that he speaks to god 
daily.
     NEUROVEGETATIVE SYMPTOMS (E.G., DISTURBANCES OF SLEEP,      

APPETITE, ENERGY, LIBIDO):  unknown
     SUICIDALITY/HOMICIDALITY (INCLUDE IDEATION, INTENT, PLAN): 
unknown
     INSIGHT AND JUDGMENT:  Poor insight and judgment.
     COGNITIVE ASSESSMENT:  Patient alert but unable to 
cooperate
with cognitive exam.  Does not answer questions appropriately.
          

Physical exam: notable for superficial abrasions on left knee 
and shoulder

On Discharge: Pt. is a young male with intact grooming. Behavior 
is calm, but irritable at times, cooperative with exam. speech 
is RRR. Mood is "fine." Affect irritable. TP-linear. TC- no 
overt evidence of delusions, no abnormal perceptions. No S/H 
TIP. I/J-fair.

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt. medically cleared and admitted to ___ inpatient 
psychiatry service after spending 2 days in ED for agitated 
behavior requiring multiple chemical restraints. Patient 
evaluated upon arrival to unit and placed on 15 min checks. Pt. 
refused to sign a CV.

Psych: Pt. initial presentation consisted of psychotic symptoms, 
namely grandiose and paranoid delusions, of being ___ the 
___, being able to speak in tongues, thinking people had 
spit in his water. ___ also beleived that he could read the 
mind of the the young girl he pushed and believed that she was 
making fun of his breasts and acne scars. He consistently denied 
any auditory hallucinations. ___ thought disorder and 
disorganization of speech were quite striking during his initial 
presentation and early part of his hospitalization, 
characterized by extreme looseness of associations, bordering on 
pressured and angry derailed tirades. ___ also presented with 
noticeably flat affect despite his angry and irritable behavior 
early on in his admission. He initially refused to take any 
medication and denied anything was wrong. An affadavit for court 
commitment was filed prior to expiration of ___ and ___ 
was committed to unit for 45 days, and required to take 
medication. ___ was started on Geodon 40 mg BID, which was 
quickly titrated up to 60 mg BID and eventually 80 mg BID after 
5 days. He also received Ativan 1 mg q6 PRN anxiety and poor 
sleep which he used regularly. He tolerated the medications with 
minimal side effects, though some ? stiffness was noted and 
patient was given Cogentin as well with each dose of Geodon. In 
the second week of medication, ___ developed an episode of 
orthostatic hypotension and his dose was decreased to 60 mg BID 
for 1 week. His orthostatis resolved with increased PO intake, 
and ___ was able to be titrated back up to 80 mg BID, Cogentin 
was also d/c'd. It was felt Geodon would be an appropriate 
antipsychotic for ___ given its neutral metabolic profile, 
ability for IM dosing if needed, lower risk for EPS, and little 
risk of prolaction elevation (given concern over breasts). ___ 
responded very slowly over the first 2 weeks of medication, 
showing improvement in his thought disorder and speech 
organization. The most striking feature of ___ hospital 
course, though, were his marked negative sxs which seemed to 
worsen during his stay: flat affect, alogia, withdrawal, apathy, 
and demoralization. It was thought that ___ likely was 
suffering from post-psychotic depression. Through discussions 
about his presentation and literature review, it was thought 
___ might benefit from initiation of Mirtazapine to help with 
negative sxs. He was started on 15 mg HS. Unfortunately, ___ 
did not tolerate the medication well, and developed intolerable 
sedation. The medication was thus discontinued on ___.  The 
patient was continued on the Geodon 60mg PO BID which he 
tolerated and was also continued on Cogentin 1mg PO BID PRN and 
Ativan 1mg PO TID PRN. The patient was discharged with 
prescriptions for the above medications and with a plan to 
follow up with his psychiatrist in two weeks.

As far as Mr. ___ diagnosis. He is ___ yo male admitted with 
bizarre and agitated behavior, exhibiting grandiose and paranoid 
delusions, and severe thought disorder. Patient has a ___ year 
history dating back to age ___ of depressive sxs and obsessive 
traits, 1 pior SA, and suffered the loss of his mother to CA at 
age ___. Last ___ patient had ___ psychotic episode, initially 
thought to be manic as well, but from discussions with outpt. 
psychiatrist and viewing d/c summary, there is little evidence 
of a manic episode. Based on current presentation and past 
history, it appears that Mr. ___ is suffering from the early 
beginnings of Schizophrenia, likely paranoid type, with 
pronounced negative symptoms and subsequent post-psychotic 
depression.

In the future, if patient does not show adequate remission of 
symptoms with geodon, it may be reasonable to try Risperdone, 
given the availability of a long-acting injectable form. Also, a 
re-trial of Mirtazapine may also be a consideration in the 
future if ___ negative/cognitive sxs continue to be an issue, 
though a lower starting dose would be recommended with slow 
upward titration.

Medical: ___ initially complained is some hand pain and 
tingling in his right hand secondary to injury from concert. 
Physical exam of this region was benign. No imaging was felt to 
be necessary. Patient was managed with PRN Ibuprofen with good 
effect. One episode of orthostasis as noted above on unit, 
responded well to decrease in Geodon dose and increased PO 
intake. The patient did not experience any other medical issues 
during his hospitalization. His vitals were monitored daily and 
apart from the orthostatic episode remained stable. He will f/u 
with his PCP upon discharge.

Social: SW evaluation done on admission. SW in contact with 
family throughout stay. Conference call made with ___ and 
psychiatry resident during initial part of stay to discuss 
diagnosis, treatment, and likely dispo planning. Also, ___ 
court-ordered to contact ___ to bring school materials. 
Contact made and ___ of school came to bring ___ belongings 
and materials, thought ___ made the decision to not continue 
with school given his current hospitalization. Letter was 
submitted on his behalf in attempt to obtain refund of tuition. 
The associate ___ of ___ ___ 
(___) was contacted and will be receiving the letters. 
A family meeting was held with pt. and father, and treatment 
team on ___ to facilitate d/c planning. 

Legal: ___
Checks: 15 minutes throughout stay. No acute behavioral issues 
on unit. No suicidal ideation or behaviors noted during stay.

Dispo: The patient was found to be appropriate for discharge on 
the ___ day of hospitalization. His father ___ was 
present during his discharge, and the plan is for the patient to 
return to ___ with his father. He will follow up with his 
psychiatrist and PCP as scheduled.
 
Medications on Admission:
Lithium 600 am, 900 HS
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Lorazepam 1 mg Tablet ___: One (1) Tablet PO three times a 
day as needed for anxiety/agitation.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Multivitamin     Tablet ___: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
3. Tretinoin 0.1 % Cream ___: One (1) Appl Topical QHS (once a 
day (at bedtime)).  
4. Ziprasidone HCl 60 mg Capsule ___: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Benztropine 1 mg Tablet ___: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for EPS.
Disp:*26 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Axis I: Schizophrenia, paranoid type, with prominent negative 
symptoms
Axis II: deferred
Axis III: no active medical issues

 
Discharge Condition:
Medically and psychiatrically stable for discharge home without 
thoughts of self-harm.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your psychiatrist or go to nearest emergency room if 
you feel suicidal, homicidal, or your symptoms worsen.

Please take your medication as prescribed.

Please follow-up with your outpatient providers as scheduled.

Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
BPH
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
TURP

 
History of Present Illness:
Today I saw Mr. ___ for further evaluation of lower 
urinary tract symptoms, especially urgency. 
He is a ___ white male with a history of prostate
enlargement and lower urinary tract symptoms who complains
primarily of urgency and urge incontinence.  He also has a slow
stream.  He comes in to discuss options for management. 
Currently, he voids five to six times a day with nocturia x 3,
has urgency most of the time, has a reduced stream most of the
time.  Denies any leakage, does not normally wear pads.  He does
say that very rarely he will leak out a few drops prior to 
making
it to the bathroom.  He has been maintained on alfuzosin for his
BPH-related symptoms. Urodynamics showed ___ obstruction by 
___ criteria with normal bladder capacity and complacence. 
Given all the above, the decision was made to proceed with a 
TURP.

 
Past Medical History:
Onychomycosis, Hyperlipidemia, BPH, Sinus node dysfunction
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No GU cancers
 
Physical Exam:
Afebrile, VS wnl
NAD, Ox3
Breathing comfortably RA
Abd soft, NT, ND
Voiding clear light pink urine with voided volumes > PVR
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to urology after undergoing transurethral 
resection of the prostate. There were no intra-operative 
complications. Post-op course was also uncomplicated. Patient 
was placed on overnight continuous bladder irrigation which was 
light pink and discontinued on morning of POD1.  The foley was 
removed and patient voided without difficulty.   At discharge 
patient's pain well controlled with PO pain medications, 
tolerating regular diet, ambulating without assistance, and 
voiding.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. alfuzosin 10 mg Oral qday 
2. Lovastatin 10 mg Oral qday
 
Discharge Medications:
1. alfuzosin 10 mg Oral qday 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice daily 
Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Lovastatin 10 mg Oral qday 
4. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) 1 TAB PO Q4H:PRN 
breakthrough pain only(score>4) 
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth 
every 4 to 6 hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO BID Duration: 3 Days 
RX *sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim 800 mg-160 mg 1 tablet(s) by 
mouth twice daily Disp #*6 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume all of your pre-admission medications, except HOLD 
aspirin until you see your urologist in followup AND your foley 
has been removed (if not already done)

-Continue taking PROSCAR (Finasteride) AND/OR your other 
prostate shrinking medications until you are otherwise advised 
.

-You MAY be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine
bright orange.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative, and available over the counter.  
The generic name is DOCUSATE SODIUM.  It is recommended that you 
use this medication.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks and while 
Foley catheter is in place. 

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg 
Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger).

IF YOU ARE DISCHARGED HOME WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:

-Please refer to the provided nursing instructions and handout 
on Foley catheter care, waste elimination and leg bag usage.

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up in 1 week for wound check and Foley removal. DO NOT 
have anyone else other than your Surgeon remove your Foley for 
any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.

-Start prescribed antibiotic on discharge.

History of Present Illness:
___ yo F with h/o atrial fibrillation on coumadin, s/p MVR, HTN, 
PUD, and diverticulosis who presents with lethargy, melena, 
blood oozing from her mouth and ? hematemesis. Per pt, has had 
epigastric pain for several days and vomited up "small" amount 
of dark colored blood for past 3 days. She later denies this and 
states that she only vomited up dark blood on one occasion on 
the day PTA. Per daughter, noted dried, dark blood around pt's 
lips on ___. Denies hematochezia, BRBPR but does report one 
episode of melena the night PTA. Per husband, he noted that pt 
was much more fatigued and tired yesterday and was unable to 
climb up a flight of stairs. He also noted "dark colored spots" 
over her legs and arms and dark blood oozing from her mouth 
after removing her dental plates. No coughing or vomiting up of 
blood per husband. This morning, she was found to be very hard 
to arouse from bed and again noticed dark, dried blood around 
her mouth and clothes. Upon EMS arrival, ___ reportedly wnl, BP 
60/palp. She was given IVFs during transport to ___.  
.  
In the ___, initial BP 80/palp per ___ RN. Given 500 cc bolus and 
BPs improved to 103/56. She continued to be fluid resuscitated 
with a total of 4L NS. NGL lavage performed with return of dark, 
coffee-grounds. Labs significant for Hct 29.8 (baseline mid 
30's), INR 21.2, venous lactate 10.7, Cr 3.6 (baseline 1.4 - 
1.9), troponin 0.02, CK 81. The pt was given 2 units pRBC, 2 
units FFP, panoprazole 40 mg IV X 1, and vit K 10 mg IV X 1. 
Given elevated venous lactate, a CTA abd/pelvis was performed 
that showed no signs of mesenteric ischemia, bibasilar lung 
opacities, non-specific bilateral perinephric stranding possibly 
related to renal failure, and ascites, pericholecystic fluid, 
and RV enlargement suggestive of R sided heart failure. She was 
seen by GI consult and admitted to the MICU for further care.

s/p mechanical mitral valve replacement ___

___ CXR
SINGLE PORTABLE VIEW OF THE CHEST: There has been previous 
sternotomy, with 
midline sternal wires and prosthetic mitral valve again 
identified. Marked 
cardiomegaly is again noted with bilateral peripheral 
interstitial opacities. 
Findings may be related to chronic interstitial lung disease 
though 
superimposed mild congestion is also probable. There is no 
pleural effusion. 
The bony thorax is unremarkable. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
1. Cardiomegaly with probable mild congestion. 
.
___ CT abd/pelvis
IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of mesenteric ischemia. 
2. New bilateral perinephric stranding, a nonspecific finding. 
This may be 
related to medical renal disease. 
3. Reticulonodular opacities at the lung bases likely reflect 
edema 
superimposed on chronic interstitial lung disease. 
4. Cardiomegaly with right heart failure. 
5. Small volume ascites.  
.
___ CT head
IMPRESSION: 
  
1. No evidence of infarction or hemorrhage, allowing for the 
presence of 
intravenous contrast from the preceding abdominal/pelvic CT. 
.
___ CT head
IMPRESSION: No evidence of acute hemorrhage or acute large 
vascular territory 
infarcts. Prominence of the ventricles slightly out of 
proportion to 
prominence of the sulci is unchanged compared to ___. 
Periventricular 
hypodensities may represent chronic small vessel ischemic 
disease, 
transependymal migration of CSF, or a combination of the two; 
comparison with 
earlier prior imaging, if available, may be helpful in assessing 
change over 
time. 
.
___ CXR
The heart is enlarged. Mitral valve replacement is present. The 
interstitial 
failure present on the prior chest ___ appears 
less marked but 
this could be due to technical differences and I suspect that 
some 
interstitial failure is still present. Atelectasis is again 
present.

Brief Hospital Course:
Hospital course was as follows: 

In the ___, initial BP 80/palp per ___ RN. Given 500 cc bolus and 
BPs improved to 103/56. She continued to be fluid resuscitated 
with a total of 4L NS. NGL lavage performed with return of dark, 
coffee-grounds. Labs significant for Hct 29.8 (baseline mid 
30___s), INR 21.2, venous lactate 10.7, Cr 3.6 (baseline 1.4 - 
1.9), troponin 0.02, CK 81. The patient was given 2 units pRBC, 
2 units FFP, panoprazole 40 mg IV X 1, and vit K 10 mg IV X 1. 
Given elevated venous lactate, a CTA abd/pelvis was performed 
that showed no signs of mesenteric ischemia, bibasilar lung 
opacities, non-specific bilateral perinephric stranding possibly 
related to renal failure, and ascites, pericholecystic fluid, 
and RV enlargement suggestive of R sided heart failure. She was 
seen by GI consult and admitted to the MICU for further care.  
.
In the MICU, GI performed EGD and noted esophagitis/gastritis 
and to have large clot in stomach but no active bleeding. 
Hematocrit nadir was 27, transfused 2 units w/ appropriate 
increase. Reversed anticoagulation w/ vitamin K, now on heparin 
gtt as INR<2 w/o new bleeding. Also patient noted to have a 
history of interstitial lung disease (f/b Dr. ___ and 
does not have home O2 but currently w/ O2 requirement s/p IVF 
resuscitation on arrival given hypovolemic hypotension in 
setting of bleed. Her O2 requirement has been lessening w/ 
diuresis. The morning of transfer, the patient was noticed to be 
slightly confused and does have a h/o sundowing. A head CT was 
negative for bleed and then found +U/A so started ciprofloxacin 
which was changed to ceftriaxone for concerns of deleriogenesis. 

.
Please see the following problem list for the pt's course once 
called out to the medical floor:
.
*) Increasing O2 requirement: Likely ___ volume overload from 
diastolic heart failure in combination with known interstitial 
lung disease. s/p echo ___ with EF 60-70%. Pt received IV lasix 
to a goal of -1.5L for approx 5 days and was transitioned to PO 
lasix when no longer exhibited signs of fluid overload. She 
continued to have a fluctuating O2 requirement and NC was 
titrated to >93%. On discharge, patient was satting well on 2L 
off of lasix.
.
*) Upper GI bleed: In setting of supratherapeutic INR. s/p 2u 
pRBC. Resolved and Hct stable s/p transfusion and Vit K. EGD 
with esophagitis, gastritis, clot but no acute bleeding. 
Continued BID protonix. Daily hcts were stable and increased 
throughout stay.  
.  
*) Anti-Coagulation/MVR - Patient on IV heparin with goal 50-70 
for anticogagulation for MVR. Initially on coumadin 2mg QD, 
which was eventually increased to her home regimen of 10mg 
___ and 15mg ___. On discharge, INR was 3.1 and heparin gtt 
discontinued. Patient to have close follow up with ___ 
Clinic.
.
*) Confusion/dementia: Pt with occasional severe agitation. Last 
episode ___ AM (pulled out IVs, refusing PO meds and O2NC). 
Likely secondary to underlying dementia/sundowning. Pt received 
zyprexa and haldol prn. Per daughter, this is her baseline.
.  
*) Acute on chronic renal failure: Prerenal, baseline Cr 
1.4-1.6. Followed Cr daily. On discharge, creatinine was 1.5.
.  
*) Cardiac - EF 60-70%. Continued metoprolol and transitioned to 
XL. Lisinopril was decreased as BPs were low normal. Continued 
statin.
.
*) UTI: Pt received cipro x 3d. Cx negative.
.  
*) s/p MVR - Mechanical valve. Heparin as above.  
.  
*) Hypothryoidism - Continued synthroid at home doses. TSH 0.68, 
free T4 normal.  
.  
*) DM II - Continue ISS while in house, but pt with little 
requirement. D/C'd on HD#12. Restarted metformin 1 day prior to

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE:
================================
___ with history of 3VD-CAD who elected PCI, now s/p DES to LM, 
LAD, and RCA presenting with substernal chest pain earlier 
today, found to have mild troponin elevation with new ST 
depression (V3), and is s/p PCI w/ POBA of D1 branch of LCA and 
was chest pain since then, but noted to have asymptomatic NSVT 
(38beats) x 1 episode

ACTIVE ISSUES:
================================
#CAD
Pt has known hx of 3VD-CAD who elected PCI (vs CABG), who 
previously was s/p DES to LM, LAD, and RCA who presented on this 
admission with substernal chest pain, was found to have mild 
troponin elevation with new ST depression (V3), and is now s/p 
PCI w/ POBA of D1 branch of LCA.

Subsequent to PCI, pt remained CP free but was noted to have 
asymptomatic NSVT (38beats) x 1 episode, that was not in the 
setting of any electrolyte abnormalities. See below for 
evaluation/treatment details. 

Otherwise, pt was continued on ASA, Plavix, Atorvastatin, and 
was started on Metoprolol after long discussion. Pt has listed 
allergy to Metoprolol but in actuality he avoids it as it made 
his depression worse in the past. Though in light of the 
frequency of his anginal episodes, the benefits of Metoprolol 
clearly outweighed the risks. For this reason, Metoprolol was 
started with the patient's permission.

#NSVT
Subsequent to PCI, pt remained CP free but was noted to have 
asymptomatic NSVT (38beats) x 1 episode, that was not in the 
setting of any electrolyte abnormalities.

Accordingly, pt had exercise stress test which showed no 
exercise induced VT with only 2 isolated VPBs noted during the 
procedure. He also had TTE which showed LVEF 45-50%, mild 
symmetric LVH, mildly depressed LV function, mild regional LV 
systolic dysfunction w/ hypokinesis of basal to mid 
anterolateral wall and entire inferolateral wall. 

Given such findings, it was felt that pt may have either 
arrhythmogenic scar tissue in the inferiolateral wall or 
infiltrative process (ex: sarcoid) that may predispose him to 
arrhythmias. Accodingly, he was discharged to home with 
outpatient cardiology follow up and was scheduled for elective 
outpatient cardiac MRI (to evaluate for previously mentioned 
etiologies).

CHRONIC ISSUES:
============================
#Hypertension:  
Patient with history of hypertension, and was mildly 
hypertensive upon arrival but remained within an acceptable 
range on home dose lisinopril, chlorthalidone and metoprolol. OF 
note, amlodipine was stopped during this admission given 
addition of Metoprolol Succinate.

#Obstructive sleep apnea:  
Patient with history of sleep apnea, and uses CPAP at home. He 
did not bring his machine with him so was provided with one 
which he used nightly.

#Anxiety/depression:  
Well-controlled currently so was continued on home regimen 
(lithium, ativan, prozac).

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
============================
1. Given inferior wall motion abnormalities, pt will need 
cardiac MRI to determine whether arrhythmogenic scar or 
infiltrative disease exists, that could account for NSVT. 
Cardiac MRI office will call pt next week to schedule elective 
study.
2.Pt will need to attend f/u with PCP for general healthcare 
maintenance
3.Pt will need to f/u w/ his cardiologist regarding his anginal 
symptomatology s/p PCI. Moreover, he will need to have his 
B-Blocker titrated as needed.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female admitted to the hospital with  abdominal 
pain, nausea, and elevated white blood cell count.  Upon 
admission, the patient was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, 
and underwent imaging which showed perforated appendicitis. She 
was started on a course of antibiotics ceftriaxone and flagyl 
and underwent serial abdominal examinations. 

The patient was taken to the operating room on HD # 3 where she 
underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy.  Intra-operative findings 
were notable for acute perforated appendicitis with phlegmon and 
an abscess.  There was a 100 cc blood loss.  The patient was 
extubated after the procedure and monitored in the recovery 
room.  

During the post-operative course, she was febrile with an 
elevated white blood cell count. Her surgical pain was 
controlled with intravenous analgesia. Because of the 
temperature spikes, the patient underwent a cat scan of the 
abdomen on POD #5 and she was reported to have a right lower 
quadrant collection.  She was taken to interventional radiology 
where a drain was placed. Her abdominal pain persisted and she 
underwent another cat scan of the abdomen which showed an 
additional fluid collection posterior to the uterus.  She 
returned to ___ on POD #11 where another drain was placed.  Over 
the next ___ hours her white blood cell count began to normalize. 
 She continued on her course of ceftriaxone and flagyl.  

The patient was discharged home on POD #14.  Her antibiotics 
were discontinued and her white blood cell count was stable at 
11. She was transitioned to oral analgesia and was voiding 
without difficulty.  She had return of bowel function.  Her 
vital signs were stable and she was afebrile.  Discharge 
instructions were reviewed and questions answered.  A follow-up 
appointment was made in the Acute care clinic.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Of note, during the patient's hospitalization, she noted a left 
leg lesion.  The Dermatology service was consulted and advised 
removal of the lesion.  An appointment was made for follow-up by 
the Dermatology service.   They will call the patient with the 
time and place of the appointment.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and found 
to have a perforation in your appendix. You were given IV 
antibiotics but continued to have pain and signs and symptoms of 
infection. You were taken to the operating room to have your 
appendix removed laparoscopically, and the infection washout out 
of your abdomen. After surgery, you continued to an elevation in 
your white blood cell count.  On imaging, you were reported to 
have fluid collections in your abdomen for which drains were 
placed.  Since then, your white blood cell count and your pain 
has decreased.  You continue on antibiotics.  Your are preparing 
for discharge home with ___ services for drain care assistance 
with the following instructions:

Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We 
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. We have scheduled an 
appointment for you listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

You will also need to follow-up with Dermatology to have 
excision of lesion left lower leg.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with history of recent appendectomy for 
perforated appendicitis on ___ complicated by 
multi-loculated fluid collections requiring ___ drainage x2 
discharged ___, who re-presented to the ___ ED this 
admission with ___ days of abdominal pain.  CT scan demonstrated 
new mesenteric stranding in the left mid upper abdomen without 
clear abnormality of the adjacent bowel, no drainable 
collection, bowel obstruction, or drainable fluid collections.  
She was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service for serial 
abdominal exams and she was made NPO with IV fluid. 

On HD2, her abdominal pain improved, but she remained tender to 
palpation in the LUQ.  She passed flatus.  She had a repeat CT 
abdomen/pelvis which demonstrated  persistent mild inflammatory 
wall thickening of the cecum and surrounding soft tissues in the 
right lower quadrant.  A c.diff toxin was sent which came back 
positive.  PO vancomycin was initiated.  The patient's abdominal 
pain improved.  Her diet was advanced to a regular diet which 
she tolerated.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and had 
abdominal/pelvic CT scans showing mild inflammation of your 
colon.  You tested positive for clostridium difficile, a 
bacteria in the colon, which can lead to bowel inflammation and 
diarrhea.  You were started on a medication, called Vancomycin, 
to treat this bacterial infection.  You are now tolerating a 
regular diet and are ready to be discharged from the hospital.

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

to RCA and POBA to D2 as well as hypertension and DM who

# CAD: Extensive CAD history with recent NSTEMI in ___ with 
DES to RCA. Symptoms on presentation (throat pain) are atypical 
for CAD, but prior NSTEMI had similar symptoms, making this 
concerning for an anginal equivalent. Troponins were <0.01, 
0.02, 0.02. Given her relatively stable troponins and her 
complicated cardiac anatomy, the decision was made to optimize 
medical management of CAD. She was continued on aspirin 325 mg 
and Plavix 75mg. She is also on Carvedilol 12.5mg BID, 
Lisinopril 20mg, and Imdur 90mg. Throughout this 
hospitalization, we attempted to better control the patient's 
hypertension on admission (180s/100s).

unchanged from previous TTE in ___. Was euvolemic on exam.

was monitored on telemetry throughout the admission.

180s/100s. Patient had a good deal of anxiety on admission. She 
was unclear on which medications she had been taking most 
recently. By discharge, pressures had come down to 120s/80s.

medications were avoided.

patient was on Insulin Sliding Scale. She will be discarghed on

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo F with hx of CAD s/p CABG in ___ (LIMA->LAD, 
SVG->diag->OM, SVG->PDA) and s/p NSTEMI in ___ with DES x3 
to RCA and POBA to D2 as well as hypertension and DM who 
presents with chest pain and palpitations. 
 
#  chest pain/palpitations:  This patient was monitored in the 
ED and transferred to the cardiology floor for further 
evaluation.  She remained chest pain free during her hospital 
stay.  Her history and risk factors  raised some concern that 
chest pain may represent unstable angina given that it awoke her 
from sleep.  However, she demonstrated no elevation in trops x2 
and, her EKG was paced. On arrival to the floor she was 
hypertensive to 200 SBP.  She was continued on her home aspirin, 
plavix, Imdur, and statin and her home carvedilol was increased 
to 37.5 bid.  Her pacemaker was interrogated and revealed no 
significant tachyarrhthymia. The interrogation demonstrated 
normal device function. 81,024 PVCs  noted with 19 PVC runs 
without electrograms available for review. Rare PVCs were noted 
on telemetry.  It was ultimately felt that her chest pain may 
have been related to her hypertension she had no concerning EKG 
changes and no elevation of troponin.  

# Chronic  systolic congestive heart failure: Patients last echo 
in ___ showed 45%. Patient appeared euvolemic on exam this 
admission.  She was continued on  carvedilol (increase dose), 
lisinopril, and torsemide, and on a low sodium diet.   

#Complete heart block s/p pacer:  Patient was V-paced on 
admission, with a normal functioning device noted above.

# hypertension - Patient was hypertensive on admission with SBPs 
in the 180-210s.  She was continued on home doses of lisinopril, 
felodipine, carvedilol, imdur.  Her carvedilol dose was 
increased to 37.5 BID.  And her BP stabilized <160s.  

# diabetes type 2:  In house her home oral antihyperglycemics 
were discontinued and she was maintained on SSI and a diabetic 
diet in house.  On discharge she was restarted on oral therapy

Transitional Issues
Patient has not been able to afford her tradjenda, and although 
her pharmacy has an RX pending for her for this medication she 
has not been taking it.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo woman PMH CAD, diastolic HF ( mildly 
reduced EF 40-45%), PMR (on steroids), DM2, and per chart review 
a history of vertigo who presented with sudden onset of 
dizziness and vomiting. 

# Vertigo: Ultimately cause was unclear but resolved. She was 
seen by the Neuro Stroke team and had CT head as well as CTA 
head and neck which showed no evidence of acute intracranial 
abnormality or vertebral dissection. There was evidence of 
atherosclerotic disease. Acute stroke was therefore thought to 
be unlikely.  She was found to be orthostatic in the ED and 
received 1.5 L of IVF.  She was admitted to medicine and placed 
on telemetry; she had no events. The Electrophysiology Service 
was consulted to interrogate her pacemaker and her pacemaker was 
found to be working fine. ___ maneuver did not reproduce 
her symtoms making BPPV less likely. She was seen by physical 
therapy who recommended that she was safe for discharge with 
home physical therapy.  If persistently orthostatic, would check 
AM cortisol level to evaluate for adrenal insufficiency, 
especially since she is on long-standing Prednisone.

# Blurry Vision: Ms. ___ also noted that she had new blurry 
vision. Ophthalmology was consulted and blurry vision had nearly 
resolved. They believed vision changes may be related to dry 
eyes and recommended artificial tears QID, with Ophthalmology 
follow-up in 1 week. 

# ___: On HD2 she had an increase in her creatinine from 1.4 to 
2.1. This was thought to be contrast induced nephropathy vs. 
prerenal. Her lisinopril was held x 1 day. She was given IVF and 
creatine improved with creatinine at discharge 1.4 consistent 
with pre-renal rather than contrast-induced nephropathy.  Her 
lisinopril was restarted on discharge. 

# Nightsweats: Reported on admission. This was not worked up as 
inpatient, but this should be followed up as an outpatient.  

Chronic Issues:

# CAD: S/p CABG and PCI, s/p dual chamber pacemaker 
- continued home medications: carvedilol, plavix, aspirin, 
rosuvastatin

# HTN: continued torsemide and lisinopril (except x 1 day in 
setting of ___.  

# DM2: held home hypoglycemics, placed on insulin sliding scale

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with a history of CAD (LIMA->LAD, 
SVG->diag->OM, SVG->PDA), RCA PCI in ___, possible prior 
inferior and apical MI, poorly controlled DM, poorly controlled 
HTN, prior CVA, diastolic CHF and HLD, CHB with DDD, who 
presents with throat pain and elevation of troponin now s/p 
stent x3 to RCA for ostial lesion and 90% ISRS, with return to 
cath lab for D2 POBA due to recurrence of throat pain and rising 
trops.  Had improvement in symptoms but still elevated troponin 
most likely ___ to demand myonecrosis with poor clearance ___ to 
___. 

# NSTEMI and Demand Myonecrosis:  Pt presented to ED with severe 
throat pain for third time in a matter of days. First two times 
trops were negative and stress tolerance test and MIBI showed no 
anginal symptoms and a known fixed apical wall defect unchanged 
to prior. ECGs uninterpretable due to vpaced rhythm from 
patient's pacemaker for complete heart block. On this admission, 
pt worked up with CT neck which was negative.  However, troponin 
found to be elevated.  It is likely that her throat pain is her 
coronary equivalent given patient's diabetes.  Echo demonstrated 
worsening anterior and septal wall motion abnormalities with 
suboptimal view of lateral wall.  Trops peaked at 1.8 and the pt 
was classified as having an NSTEMI.  An invasive approach was 
indicated given elevated trops, prior CABG, and high TRS of 6. 
Cath revealed an RCA ostial stenosis ISRS of RCA, and these were 
treated with 3 DES.  While in cath lab, pt became hypertensive 
and recurrence of throat pain and case was discontinued but note 
was made of an occluded D2 and 70% OM lesion.  Back on the 
floor, pt had worsening of throat pain and spiked troponins 
again.  In conjunction with the previous echo demonstrating 
worsening wall motion abnormalities over left anterior wall, 
septum, and possibly lateral wall (suboptimally visualized) this 
suggested another potential culprit lesion outside of the RCA. 
Pt went back to cath lab on following day where OM2 showed good 
FFR of 84% so was not intervened on, but occluded D2 was POBAed 
with improvement of pain.  However, the following night patient 
again developed neck pain in the setting of an elevated blood 
pressure to 190's/110's. She was started on nitro gtt which 
resulted in complete pain relief. She was gradually weaned off 
of the nitro gtt and remained pain-free.  She developed a more 
modest trop spike most likely due to demand ischemia in setting 
of hypertension.  The patient seems to be very sensitive to 
hypertension and easily develops demand myonecrosis most likely 
from her ischemic cardiomyopathy causing elevated O2 demand with 
decreased supply in setting of CAD and both systolic and 
diastolic dysfunction.  The patient's troponins were monitored 
and were on the decline at time of discharge.  It will be 
important to control patient's hypertension as hypertensive 
episodes cause her to have her coronary anginal equivalent 
throat pain.  For stent, pt to continue aspirin and plavix.  For 
CAD/HTN/Angina, pt on Coreg 25, Imdur 60, Atorvastatin 80, and 
lisinopril 20 mg.  Of note, Imdur causes the patient headache 
within first hour of taking.  Imdur just started, and pt may 
become tolerant of side effect with time, but should continue to 
monitor in case side effects become worse or intolerable.  She 
was advised to take the medication an hour before getting up to 
go to work.
.
# Acute on chronic systolic and diastolic dysfunction:  No signs 
of acute symptomatic heart failure.  LVEF is now worse and 
estimated to be 30%.  Pt to continue on Coreg 25 mg and 
Lisinopril 20 mg with increase of lisinopril as tolerated.
.  
# RHYTHM:  A paced V sensed throughout at rate in ___.
.  
# HTN: Continue on Coreg, Imdur, Lisinopril, with uptitration of 
lisinopril as renal function tolerates.  ___ from 
CIN, this was not further increased in the hospital.  Pt sent 
home with script for blood pressure kit for outpatient follow 
up.
.  
#  DMII: ISS while here.  Discharged on home meds as creatinine 
came back down to 1.2.
.  
#  Dyslipidemia: Switched crestor to atorvastatin 80 mg. Spoke 
to pharmacy, unfortunately copay is $99 for either medication.
.  
# ___: Pt developed CIN both times she was administered 
contrast.  This improved with time and hydration.
.  
# Incidentals:

- 4-mm pulmonary nodule along the right major fissure. In this 
location, 
this could represent a lymph node. In a low-risk patient, no 
further specific 
followup is needed. In a high-risk patient, followup CT at 12 
months may be 
performed. 

.

admitted for throat pain and were found to be having a heart 
attack.  You were treated with placement of 3 drug eluting 
stents into a heart artery called the right coronary artery.  
However, you continued to have pain and your cardiac markers in 
your blood demonstrated that you were having another small heart 
attack.  You were treated with dilation of one of your other 
heart arteries which improved your symptoms.  

Your blood pressure was also high on admission and your 
medications were changed to better control this.

The following changes were made to your medications:
START Plavix (clopidogrel) to prevent your stent from clotting
START Carvedilol (coreg) for better blood pressure control
STOP Atenolol
STOP Amlodipine
START Isosorbide Mononitrate (Imdur) for control of your pain 
and blood pressure control
INCREASE Lisinopril for better blood pressure control
START Nitroglycerin tabs to be used as needed for chest or 
throat pain

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year-old female with schizoaffective disorder, history of 
stroke, and hypothyroidism who was admitted on ___ with an 
NSTEMI and an acute stroke s/p hypercarbic respiratory failure 
secondary to aspiration PNA, who improved but had subsequent 
difficulties swallowing and PEG tube placement.  During the 
subsequent hospital course, the patient underwent speech therapy 
and continued to improve to the point of tolerating increasing 
PO trials prior to discharge to rehab.
.
# Stroke: The patient was found to have subacute strokes in her 
basal ganglia and caudate and had weakness and dsyarthria 
present on admission, which corresponded to her neurologic 
deficits. She was initially unable to cooperative fully with a 
neuro exam, but did have hyperreflexic reflexes on exam here.  
Neurology was consulted and recommended aspirin and plavix, 
which was held briefly around the time of her PEG placement.  An 
NG tube was attempted to be placed, but patient did not tolerate 
exam.  She failed speech and swallow multiple times.  A PEG tube 
was placed for tube feeding after serial discussions with the 
patient and family. Later in her hospital course, prior to 
discharge, a video swallow study was conducted, showing that she 
had regained some swallowing function and so pureed solids were 
started in addition to tube feeds. The patient will need serial 
speech and swallow evaluations at her rehab center to monitor 
her improvement and determine when, if at all, the PEG tube can 
be removed.
.  
# Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Thought to be secondary to 
aspiration pneumonia.  She finished a full 8 day course of 
vancomycin/cefepime/flagyl.  Respiratory status was stable once 
extubated.
.
# Spinal Stenosis: Patient had trauma CT on admission remarkable 
for severe spinal stenosis with some cord compression. ___ 
surgery was consulted and felt no acute need for surgery or 
steroids however when her condition improves will likely need 
surgery.  Initially had a hard collar in place, but after 
discussion with Ortho ___, felt that collar could be removed.  
Patient will need follow-up with Dr. ___ in Ortho ___ in 2 
weeks.
.
# Trop leak/Demand ischemia: The patient was initially admitted 
to cardiology and felt to have demand ischemia in the setting of 
recent fall and stroke. She was inititally treated with a 
heparin gtt which was stopped shortly after admissison as the 
cardiologists felt it was demand ischemia in setting of 
infection. Her enzymes trended down and no ECG changes were 
noted.  TTE on ___ showed normal systolic function with no wall 
motion abnormalities.
. 
# Acute kidney injury: Elevated Cr on presentation, but trended 
down with IVF. Likely secondary to prerenal intravascular 
depleption. 
.
# Urinary Retention: The patient was found to have urinary 
retention after extubation. She failed several voiding trials 
and so a foley was placed. The patient should have serial 
voiding trials at rehab to determine when the foley can be 
removed. 
.
# Nutrition: As noted, the patient underwent PEG placement. She 
was maintained on TPN pre-procedurally, while the patient and 
family considered placement of a PEG tube and while the patient 
deferred a dobhoff feeding tube.  The day prior to discharge, 
the patient was able to start PO trials after her video swallow 
study, and the goal was to gradually increase PO intake by 
transitioning to night-time feedings at rehab.

Dear Ms. ___,

hospitalization.  You were admitted after being found down at 
home.  After further work-up, it was determined that you had a 
stroke.  A CT scan of your neck also showed cervical spinal 
stenosis, or a narrowing of the spinal canal in your neck.  It 
was also thought that you were having a heart attack, however 
this ultimately was not felt to be true.  

Unfortunately, you had an aspiration event and were sent to the 
ICU where you were intubated.  You completed a course of 
antibiotics for an aspiration pneumonia and were able to be 
extubated without difficulty.  You failed several speech and 
swallow exams and needed a PEG tube placed to be able to use 
your GI tract.  This was placed by ___. You started slowly 
re-developing the ability to swallow and take some food by 
mouth. We hope that you will continue to improve your swallowing 
to the point that we be able to remove the PEG tube. 
.

are being discharged with a foley. Your rehab center should 
continue to do voiding trials. We hope you will improve and we 
will be able to remove the foley.
.

Atrial Fibrillation with RVR, s/p TEE/cardioversion

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure to take care of you during your stay at ___. 
You came in with shortness of breath and were found to have an 
abnormal fast heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. We were 
unable to slow down your heart rate with medicines, so we 
scheduled you for an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) 
which showed no clot, and then shocked the heart. This 
successfully converted your heart back to normal rhythm. 

You had a little extra fluid on your body from your heart not 
pumping efficiently while it was in Afib. We diuresed you with 
lasix and will be sending you home a small dose of lasix 20mg to 
take daily at home.

After the conversion, you had some very long pauses of your 
heart beat. Because of this we want you to wear a heart rhythm 
monitor for ___ weeks at home, to make sure you are not having 
more pauses, and also monitor if you go back into Afib. ___ 
___ will be in touch with you about this heart monitor, 
which you will receive at home in the mail within 3 business 
days.

We discussed the importance of wearing your CPAP to prevent 
converting back to Afib, and also to prevent the pauses we 
observed. Talk to your PCP about getting reconnected to a sleep 
center to keep your CPAP machine maintained and make sure you 
have the best-fitting mask.

When people are in atrial fibrillation, they are at risk of 
developing clots in the heart, which can break off and cause a 
stroke. To prevent this risk, you will need to take a blood 
thinner called warfarin, in case you go back into atrial 
fibrillation.  You will have to get your INR (a measure of how 
thin your blood is) checked regularly with the ___ 
clinic at ___ to make sure you are on the right 
dose of warfarin. You should get your INR checked tomorrow, 
___.

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

- Please take lovenox 40mg daily for 2 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You can get the wound wet/take a shower starting 3 days after 
your surgery.  You may wash gently with soap and water, and pat 
the incision dry after showering.  
- No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ y/o woman with a past medical history of 
chronic kidney injury (stage V), chronic anemia (EPO-dependent), 
CAD, HFpEF, HTN, and T2DM, who presented with shortness of 
breath, chest discomfort, and dizziness with blood pressures 
>200/90. 

# HFpEF exacerbation | Hypertensive Urgency | Volume Overload:
Initial concern for pneumonia, given possible retrocardiac 
opacity on plain film; however, final read of CXR negative for 
new infiltrate. Influenza negative. Cough with subjective fevers 
at home without leukocytosis. Exam and work-up suggestive of 
volume overload in the setting of diastolic HF and end-stage 
renal disease. TTE showed severe diastolic dysfunction, but no 
significant change from prior. She had minimal troponinemia 
without ischemic EKG changes attributed by cardiology to demand 
and poor renal clearance. Patient was initially started on IV 
hydralazine and nitroglycerin drip and continued on her home 
blood pressure medications (isosorbide 
mononitrate/carvedilol/doxazosin) for blood pressure lowering 
and aggressive diuresis with IV furosemide (80-120mg). She 
diuresed well, with improvement in her shortness of breath and 
lower extremity edema. Renal was consulted and recommended slow 
blood pressure lowering with permissive hypertension and target 
SBP 160s in the first few days with avoidance of DBP lowering 
below the ___. She was subsequently weaned off the nitroglycerin 
drip and the hydralazine and started on amlodipine 5mg daily, 
with improved blood pressure control. Dizziness, which was not 
accompanied by focal neurologic deficits, resolved with improved 
antihypertensive control. At discharge, her blood pressure was 
120-150s/50-60s. She also was started on torsemide 20mg PO daily 
for maintenance diuresis.

# Right Knee Gout: 
Patient developed right knee swelling on ___ in the setting of 
aggressive diuresis. The knee joint was aspirated and sent for 
gram stain, culture, cell counts, and crystal analysis. Crystal 
analysis was consistent with negatively birefringent MSU 
crystals. After a negative gram stain and 36h with negative 
cultures, the knee joint was injected with 40mg of 
methylprednisolone, given limited treatment options otherwise 
(NSAIDs, colchicine suboptimal due to ESRD, systemic prednisone 
suboptimal due to hypertension and fluid overload). Knee X-ray 
showed enlarged joint space and diffuse small lucencies 
throughout visualized bones, with periarticular spurring. MRI 
was obtained and showed changes consistent with osteopenia with 
no concern for malignancy.

# Acute-on-chronic normocytic anemia:
Likely in the setting of ESRD. No evidence of hemolytic anemia. 
Guaiac negative x3. Received 2U of pRBCs for nadir Hgb of 6.6 
for Hgb threshold of 9 per nephrology, with appropriate 
improvement in Hgb. Continued ferrous sulfate 325 mg daily.

# Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count nadired in the 130s, likely 
due to physiologic stress and brief antibiotic treatment on 
admission, normalized prior to discharge without dedicated 
intervention.

# Acute-on-chronic kidney injury (stage V):
Mild elevation of BUN/Cr compared to baseline. At baseline, she 
has declined HD in the past. Most likely cardiorenal in 
etiology, given severe diastolic dysfunction and fluid overload 
on exam in the setting of severe hypertension. FeUrea consistent 
with intrinsic renal disease, which is expected given her stage 
V chronic kidney injury. Nephrology consulted, and patient did 
not need urgent dialysis. Cr remained 4.3 at discharge, likely 
her new baseline in the setting of diuresis.

# Strep bovis bacteriuria: She was found to have asymptomatic 
Strep bovis bacteriuria without pyuria. Antibiotic treatment was 
deferred due to absence of symptoms and lack of clear true UTI. 

CHRONIC ISSUES
# CAD
- continued aspirin 81 mg daily
- continued pravastatin 20 mg qPM
- continued isosorbide mononitrate 60 mg daily

# T2DM
- Humalog insulin sliding scale and glargine 10 units qhs
- held glipizide and sitagliptin

# GERD
- continued pantoprazole 40 mg q24h

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you. You were admitted to the 
___ because you were short of 
breath and your blood pressure was very elevated. This was 
thought to be related to a large amount of fluid that your body 
had accumulated because of your heart failure and your kidney 
problems. We gave you the same medication in your water pills at 
home, but in intravenous form, which helped improve your 
breathing and lower your blood pressure. We also made changes to 
your home blood pressure medication regimen to ensure that your 
blood pressure remains under control.

While you were in the hospital, you developed right knee pain 
and swelling. We took a small sample of the fluid in your knee 
and analyzed it and found out that you had condition known as 
gout. Gout is due to crystals accumulating in your joints. You 
were treated with a steroid injection in the knee with good 
results. 

Wishing you a speedy recovery,
Your ___ Care Team

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___. You came in because you were feeling depressed and had 
thoughts of harming yourself. Psychiatry evaluated you and 
believe you will benefit from inpatient psychiatric care. We 
also started on you on a new medication, mirtazapine, which may 
help with depression as well as increase your appetite.

Studies of your G-tube showed that it is patent and well 
positioned. We decided to hold off on tube feeds during 
hospitalization to see if you can take enough nutrition through 
eating. We are glad to see your taste buds are coming back, and 
encourage you to keep eating. If you are unable to maintain your 
weight, you will need to re-start tube feeds.  

We wish you all the best in your recovery.

chronic PEG supplemental nutrition; with cocaine and alcohol

dependence.

PSYCHIATRIC

#) SIMD/PSA
Patient presented with depression and SI but reported that these 
thoughts went away when he was admitted. During his admission to 
the medicine service, he was placed on 7.5mg mirtazapine which 
helped mitigate his symptoms of hopelessness and may have 
improved his appetite as well. During his stay on Deac 4, we 
increased the dose to 15mg QHS which helped the pt to achieve 
good sleep nightly, and he also ate meals routinely with a very 
good appetite.

Patient expressed significant anxiety about being discharged to 
a shelter, as he was certain that he would quickly relapse on 
drugs if he was not in a controlled hospital setting. He also 
expresses anxiety at currently being homeless,as his long time 
girlfriend has kicked him out of her home given his 
polysubstance abuse. 

Despite reports of anxiety, Mr. ___ remained safe during his 
hospital stay and consistently engaged animatedly with peers in 
the milieu.  He denied si except he would tell us repeatedly 
that if we did not find a "long-term" rehab placement for him 
and d/c'd him to a shelter, he would plan to relapse on drugs 
and then would likely become suicidal again.  Mr. ___ was 
encouraged to work toward sobriety and engage in his recovery 
while on our hospital unit.  Although he attended a couple of 
unit groups and AA meetings early in his admission, he refused 
to engage further in recovery work, and he repeatedly told us 
that he was waiting for "rehab placement" to begin such work.  
We advised the patient using drugs/etoh upon d/c would be his 
choice, and we strongly recommended that he avoid use of illicit 
drugs and etoh.  

Patient was difficult to find long-term placement for in a 
substance rehab program or medical respite due to his medical 
complexities. Patient was told that if he were able to take less 
PRN morphine or transition to methadone, that perhaps placement 
would be easier. The patient reported that he needed to continue 
his morphine at home doses and that he adamantly refused to make 
changes to his pain regimen.  

We discussed his pain medication regimen with Dr. ___, 
___ oncologist/prescriber. She voiced some concern over 
increasing the fentanyl patch (in order to decrease frequency of 
breakthrough morphine ___ and would prefer to have pain consult 
help us convert him to methadone, which she has raised 
previously to the patient, but he has been resistant.  The team 
reiterated this recommendation daily with the patient, who 
consistenly refused such an option and was adamant that he will 
not consider different meds.  We also discussed with the patient 
his long h/o drug abuse and suggested that he has a dependency 
on fentanyl and morphine.  Mr. ___ had no insight into this 
and refused to discuss further with the team.  He would become 
upset and end our meetings when we attempted to direct our 
meetings toward discussions about his drug abuse and options for 
recovery. 

#) SECONDARY GAIN
Mr. ___ underwent a lengthy inpatient psychiatric admission 
as the team attempted to work with him to improve his prognosis. 
 We shared the diagnostic impression that despite his cancer and 
chronic pain (which could both perpetuate depression), his drug 
abuse appears to largely drive his mood d/o and current 
psychosocial stressors including homelessness. 

The team repeatedly encouraged Mr. ___ to work toward his 
recovery during his long hospitalization here on Deac 4 by 
attending groups and working with the team via insight-oriented 
meetings.  Mr. ___ consistently became upset and ended our 
meetings when attempted to engage him in talk about recovery, 
and he refused to consider alternatives to Q2h morphine/fentanyl 
patches.  He also repeatedly told us that if we d/c'd him to a 
shelter he would abuse illicit drugs and then likely become 
suicidal.  
Despite the above, he never self-harmed on the unit and was 
highly animated with peers.  After pursuing placements for him 
in rehab facilities, all of which rejected him due to dependency 
on morphine/fentanyl patch and unwillingness to transition to 
methadone, it appeared likely that Mr. ___ was making 
threats of relapse/suicide to gain shelter on Deac 4.  

On the day of discharge, the patient denied SI/HI, depression, 
or any other acute problems.  He did state that he does not like 
sheltered living, and had no intentions of going to the ___ Medical Stay-Inn Bed which we had arranged for him.  
The patient asked the team to allow him to stay in his hospital 
bed until he could arrange a stable residence.  The pt was 
advised that hospitalization was no longer necessary and that we 
recommend he utilize the sheltered housing which had been 
arranged for him.  
  

GENERAL MEDICAL CONDITIONS
#) CANCER
Patient has history of SCC of left tonsil on chronic PEG. While 
patient was admitted he was followed by nutrition including 
daily calorie counts. They deemed his oral intake to be 
sufficient and patient did not need to use his PEG tube at all 
since his arrival. We notified his oncologist Dr. ___ 
improved po intake and that the GI tube may be able to be 
removed in the near future. Patient continued to take morphine 
at his home dose for his cancer pain. 

#) HYPOTHYROIDISM
He continued levothyroxine at his home dose. 

#) TOOTH PAIN
During admission, patient experienced some tooth pain that 
resolved with tylenol.  He had no fevers or signs of infection.

PSYCHOSOCIAL
#) GROUPS/MILIEU
The pt was highly animated and engaing with the peers on the 
unit.  He never engaged in any unsafe behaviors, and he was 
often found on the telephone talking with friends/family.  He 
did occasionally attend groups including AA at the beginning of 
his hospital stay, but he then declined most groups during the 
last couple of weeks of admission.  The pt ate all meals in the 
milieu, slept well, and cooperated with unit rules.  

#) COLLATERAL
The pt allowed us to speak with his GF, with whom he was 
previously living.  She reported that due to his relapse on 
drugs and lack of motivation for change, he could not return 
home.  She understood that he was recently suicidal and agreed 
that using illicit drugs is the precipitant for him not doing 
well.

#) PLACEMENT
At the pt's request for ___ rehab, the team attempted to 
have the pt d/c'd to subst abuse residential programs, sober 
living residences, or nursing home placement.  All programs,

RISK ASSESSMENT
This patient is currently sober, not suicidal/homicidal, is 
feeling well and is highly animated and euthymic in the milieu, 
all of which indicate a low immediate risk of harm. 
He does, however, have a very high risk of relapse on illicit 
drugs which gives him an overall poor prognosis and a high 
chance of future suicidal thoughts/self-harm.

Static risk factors include:
White male with a h/o suicidal thoughts in the context of 
illicit drug use.

Modifiable risk includes:
Chronic pain (which is well-controlled per the patient on 
Morphine and Fentanyl), recent SIMD (which was treated by a 
lengthy inpatient psychiatric admission where the pt 
successfully started Remeron and experienced a great improvement 
in mood), and homelessness (which was addressed by arranging a 
placement at the ___ Medical Stay-In Bed).  Mr. 
___ chronic illicit drug use and stated intention to use 
again if d/c'd to a shelter do increase his risk.  We attempted 
to modify this by pursuing placement in a rehab/snf/sober house 
(all of which advised that they would consider the patient if he 
would take methadone in lieu of fentanyl patch/morphine - a 
recommendatino which he rejected).  We also attempted to modify 
this risk by providing a great deal of psychoeducation about 
drugs use and its potential to worsen mood and lead to SI.  Mr. 
___ was given the opportunity on Deac 4 to work on his 
recovery by attending a multitude of groups and meetings about 
substance abuse, most of which he rejected.  
Mr. ___ is considered competent to make his own decisions 
(including those described above), and we advised him upon d/c 
he is likewise competent to accept our referrals and maintain 
sobriety or to reject them.  He was advised that failure to 
comply with recommendations could lead to him suffering 
irreversible damage (i.e. suicide in the context of illicit drug 
use).  To further help Mr. ___, we referred him to a 
substance abuse partial program, and have provided aftercare 
psychiatric treaters.

The patient is protected by the following factors:
He now has about 3 weeks of sobriety from illicits and has many 
outpatient referrals for further care.  He does have a GF who 
appears to be supportive and encouraging him to work toward 
sobriety.  Mr. ___ also is connected to his oncologist, with 
whom he appears to have a good relationship and is motivated to 
continue seeing in follow-up.

PROGNOSIS
Poor due to the fact that this patient is at high risk for 
relapse on drugs, has stated that he will likely use again, and 
is precontemplative in terms of the change process.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with developemental delay (non 
verbal at baseline) with possible seizure disorder whom 
presented with generalized tonic clonic seizures and was found 
to be in NCSE whose course was complicated by slow weaning from 
the ventilator requiring tracheostomy and PEG tube placement who 
has not yet returned to baseline and is now comfort measures 
only.  

#Nonconvulsive Status Epilepticus
He presented after possible GTC. cvEEG initially showed multiple 
non-convulsive events, followed by a convulsive event and 
eventually progressed into NCSE. He was loaded and trialed on 
multiple AEDs without success and eventually required intubation 
with phenobarbital and midazolam and propofol gtts. After burst 
suppression was achieved he was eventually weaned down off of 
his AEDs and will be discharged on phenobarbital and ***(maybe 
lacosamide). Etiology unclear, but did not seem to be infectious 
(no sustained leukocytosis, no fevers, normal CSF, no 
consolidation on CXR, UCx final negative, BCx negative), no 
ischemia or inflammation MRI, paraneoplasic antibodies negative. 
His mental status has improved and he is no longer 
encephalopathic. He regards examiner and will wave hello. He is 
non-verbal at baseline.

#Respiratory distress with recurrent aspiration
Initially intubated for airway protection in setting of NCSE, 
but was unable to be weaned from the ventilator so tracheostomy 
and PEG was placed on ___. He has subsequently been weaned 
down to trach collar with humidified air. Patient repeatedly has 
aspiration events with desaturation and respiratory distress. 
There was concern for trachea-esophageal fistula due to TF 
coming out of tracheostomy. CT chest and EGD did not show any 
evidence of fistula. Continue humidified air, morphine and 
Ativan PRN for symptomatic management and comfort.

#Deep venous thrombosis: 
Patient with right sided DVT secondary to PICC-line leading to 
removal of the line.  He was treated with anticoagulation until 
he was made comfort measures only.

#Code status
Patient was made DNR/DNI on ___ due to persistent ventilator 
dependence. The patient's guardian and sister, ___, 
applied for expanded guardianship to make the patient CMO which 
was approved on ___. He is no longer ventilator dependent, 
but is dependent on artificial nutrition. Due to deconditioning, 
severity of brain disease, he is not at his baseline and it will 
be difficult to get him back to a quality of life is such that 
she believes he would enjoy. We are now focused on his comfort 
with feeding for pleasure, reduction in medications without 
prolongation of life through artificial feeding.

Transitional Issues:
-Continue comfort care of eating for pleasure, humidified air 
for tracheostomy, morphine, Ativan as needed for pain, 
respiratory distress, scopolamine, glycopyrolate for secretions
-Wean AEDs as appropriate. When patient becomes less alert, plan 
to transition to Ativan around the clock. 
-Minimize supplemental fluid intake. Will no longer provide 
artificial nutrition

Band Prolapse

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
