Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Your band was removed, but that does not mean you have to 
abandon your efforts to improve your health.  Take this 
opportunity and incorporate what you have learned from your 
health care team.  Continue being active on a regular basis and 
follow these healthful guidelines (not diet!) for life long 
benefits.

In the hospital, you will be on a stage 3 diet for healing.  
This diet includes all liquid, high protein, low sugar and low 
fat supplements.  When you are discharged home, you may advance 
your diet as tolerated.  Below are some helpful tips to continue 


your journey of eating well and healthy living.

 

1.Keep an eye on calories.

2.Always eat at a table.  Avoid eating while driving, standing, 


sitting on the sofa, or lying in bed.  

3.Eat slowly.  Continue to take 30 minutes to eat a meal and 
chew your foods thoroughly. 

4.Surround yourself with healthy foods. Clean out your cabinets 


of any trigger or unsafe foods.

5.Keep a food journal or track your intake on-line.  Record 
what you eat, portion sizes, and the time you eat.  You may want 


to include your mood and hunger level, as well.

6.Avoid skipping meals.  Always eat at regular times to avoid 
overeating later in the day.

7.Listen to your body.  Eat when you are physically hungry and 
stop when you are full.

8.Be active.  Engage in at least ___ minutes of physical 
activity most (if not all) days of the week. 

9.Regularly check your weight.  Give yourself an acceptable 
range (i.e. 5 pounds).  This prevents slip ups from becoming 
bigger problems down the road.

10. Make small changes.  Set small, reasonable goals to keep on 


track. 

11. Reward yourself.  Treat yourself when you reach goals with 
a non-food treat (i.e. pedicure, movie). 

12. Ask for support. Call the ___ nutrition clinic for 
follow-up at ___. Join Weight Watchers, talk to friends 


and family or contact a local dietitian. 

13. Drink plenty of fluids. Stay hydrated.

Fluids & Diet
Fluid intake is extremely important the first month of your 
recovery. You must also take in enough liquids
to prevent dehydration. Dehydration can cause nausea, fatigue, 
lightheadedness and dark urine.  We recommend you track what you 


drink and eat each day. 
Most Frequent Problems

Discomfort
Abdominal soreness below your ribs on the left side is the most 
common site of tenderness after waking up. Despite this 
discomfort, it is very important that you get out of bed and 
take short walks.

Dehydration
Your most important job after surgery is drinking enough fluid. 
Dehydration is the most common reason to return to the hospital 
after surgery. Your goal is to drink 8 cups (64 oz) of fluid a 
day. You may not be able to drink this much fluid at first, but 
come as close as you can. Refer to your nutrition
packet for more details.

Wound Drainage & Infection
It is important to care for your incisions to prevent infection. 


You will have small fiber tapes on your wounds. This should keep 


your wound dry and closed. Leave them on until they fall off by 
themselves. Do not put band aids, ointments, lotions or powder 
on your incisions. You may get your incisions wet but
avoid scrubbing them. Pat them dry. It is not unusual for an 
incision to drain a little bloody fluid after you
go home. If you have some drainage, dab the wounds with diluted 
hydrogen peroxide (hydrogen
peroxide mixed half and half with water) and then cover with a 
dry gauze. Doing this twice a day will
speed your recovery.
Infections are uncommon and rarely serious after a laparoscopic 
operation. An infection will be red, warm,
firm, and tender. The infected fluid will look more like pus 
than like blood. If you notice this please call the
nurse at the Bariatric ___ Program to discuss your symptoms

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the Emergency Department if you develop a fever greater than 101 
F, shaking chills, chest pain, difficulty breathing, pain with 
breathing, cough, a rapid heartbeat, dizziness, severe abdominal 
pain, pain unrelieved by your pain medication, a change in the 
nature or severity of your pain, severe nausea, vomiting, 
abdominal bloating, severe diarrhea, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness, 
swelling from your incisions, or any other symptoms which are 
concerning to you.  
 Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment; 
please refer to your work book for detailed instructions. Do not 
self- advance your diet and avoid drinking with a straw or 
chewing gum. To avoid dehydration, remember to sip small amounts 
of fluid frequently throughout the day to reach a goal of 
approximately ___ mL per day. Please note the following signs 
of dehydration: dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, feeling dizzy or 
faint, dark colored urine, infrequent urination.  
 Medication Instructions:  
 Please refer to the medication list provided with your 
discharge paperwork for detailed instruction regarding your home 
and newly prescribed medications.  
 Some of the new medications you will be taking include:  
 1. Pain medication: You will receive a prescription for liquid 
oxycodone, an opioid pain medication. This medication will make 
you drowsy and impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or 
operate machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities 
while taking these medications. You may also take acetaminophen 
(Tylenol) for pain management; do not exceed 4000 mg per 24 hour 
period.  
 2. Constipation: This is a common side effect of opioid pain 
medication. If you experience constipation, please reduce or 
eliminate opioid pain medication. You may trial 2 ounces of 
light prune juice and/or a stool softener (i.e. crushed docusate 
sodium tablets), twice daily until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern. Please stop taking this medication if you develop loose 
stools. Please do not begin taking laxatives including until you 
have discussed it with your nurse or surgeon.  
 3. Antacids: You will be taking famotidine tablets, 20 mg twice 
daily, for one month. This medicine reduces stomach acid 
production. Please crush.  
 4. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs). Examples include, but are not limited to Aleve, 
Arthrotec, aspirin, Bufferin, diclofenac, Ecotrin, etodolac, 
ibuprofen, Indocin, indomethacin, Feldene, ketorolac, 
meclofenamate, meloxicam, Midol, Motrin, nambumetone, Naprosyn, 
Naproxen, Nuprin, oxaprozin, Piroxicam, Relafen, Toradol and 
Voltaren. These agents may cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system. If you are unclear whether a medication is 
considered an NSAID, please ask call your nurse or ask your 
pharmacist.  
 5. Vitamins/ minerals: You may resume a chewable multivitamin, 
however, please discuss when to resume additional vitamin and 
mineral supplements with your bariatric dietitian.  
 Activity:  
 You should continue walking frequently throughout the day right 
after surgery; you may climb stairs.  
 You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, but avoid 
performing abdominal exercises or lifting items greater than10 
to 15 pounds for six weeks.  
 Wound Care:  
 You may remove any remaining gauze from over your incisions. 
You will have thin paper strips (Steri-Strips) over your 
incision; please, remove any remaining Steri-Strip seven to 10 
days after surgery.  
 You may shower 48 hours following your surgery; avoid scrubbing 
your incisions and gently pat them dry. Avoid tub baths or 
swimming until cleared by your surgeon.  
 If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze.  
 Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, cloudy, bloody or foul smelling drainage from the 
incision sites.  
 Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area for up to 24 
months.  
 Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with hx CAD, HTN, DM2 (diet-controlled), HL, 
GERD who presented at ___ with chest pain, transferred to 
___ for cath, then transferred to CCU after perforated LCx 
during cath. The following issues were addressed during this 
hospitalization: 

# Perforated LCx: Cath complicated by LCx perforation during 
procedure. Perforation was sealed with a balloon. In CCU for 
monitoring. Possible complication is bleeding and possible 
cardiac tamponade. She was monitored closely but remained 
hemodynamically stable. A follow-up Echo was obtained (see 
results above), and she was discharged the day after admission.
 
# Unstable angina s/p cath: Patient presented with UA, trops 
negative, no EKG findings. Per cardiologist recommendations, she 
underwent cath.  Cath notable for Cx with mid vessel 70% lesion 
at the takeoff of a small OM which was subtotally occluded 
filling via collaterals from the LAD. There were robust 
collaterals filling the distal PDA, PL and distal RCA. The RCA 
had diffuse severe disease with serial 60-90% lesions followed 
by total occlusion distally. Successful PTCA of LCx. No chest 
pain while in CCU. She was continued on her home ASA 81 mg, 
Plavix 75mg daily, and Atorvastatin 80 mg.

# HTN. Her home antihypertensives (amlodipine, lisnopril and 
HCTZ) were held initially given that she was normotensive. They 
were re-introduced prior to discharge.   

# HLD: continued atorvastatin 80mg daily as above. 

# Diabetes type 2: diet-controlled, A1C 5.8% in ___. Her 
serum blood glucose was check with her morning labs but remained 
normal. 

# GERD. She was continued on her home pantoprazole.

Dear Ms. ___,

#Why did you come to the hospital?

- You were having chest pain that did not get better at ___ 
___. Your cardiologist, Dr. ___ you for a procedure 
to check your heart's blood vessels for blockages that might be 
the cause of your pain.

# What happened when you were at the hospital?

- You had a cardiac catheterization. During the procedure, a 
balloon opened a blockage in one of your heart's blood vessels 
that was probably causing your chest pain. During the procedure, 
one of your arteries was damaged, causing a leakage of blood 
outside of the artery. It was treated by putting pressure on it 
for a few minutes and giving you medicine to help your blood 
clot. You recovered very well from the procedure but stayed 
overnight in the hospital so we could watch you closely.

# What should I do when I leave the hospital?

You should:
- take all of your home medications as prescribed before you 
came to the hospital.
- see your cardiologist and primary care doctor at your 
scheduled appointments.

___ CXR: IMPRESSION:  
  
No acute intrathoracic process. 

___ TTE:
IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
normal cavity size and regional/
global biventricular systolic function. Small circumferential 
pericardial effusion without
echocardiographic evidence for tamponade physiology.

___ Coronary angiogram:
The coronary circulation is right dominant.
LM: The Left Main, arising from the left cusp, is a medium 
caliber vessel. This vessel bifurcates into
the Left Anterior Descending and Left Circumflex systems.
LAD: The Left Anterior Descending artery, which arises from the 
LM, is a medium caliber vessel.
There is a 30% stenosis in the proximal segment.
The Diagonal, arising from the proximal segment, is a medium 
caliber vessel. There is a 30% stenosis in
the proximal segment.
Cx: The Circumflex artery, which arises from the LM, is a large 
caliber vessel.
The ___ Obtuse Marginal, arising from the proximal segment, is a 
medium caliber vessel.
The ___ Obtuse Marginal, arising from the mid segment, is a very 
small caliber vessel. There is a 100%
stenosis in the ostium. Collaterals from the mid segment of the 
LAD connect to the mid segment.
The ___ Obtuse Marginal, arising from the mid segment, is a 
medium caliber vessel.
RCA: The Right Coronary Artery, arising from the right cusp, is 
a medium caliber vessel. There is a
30% in-stent restenosis in the ostium. There is a stent in the 
proximal, mid, and distal segments.
The Right Posterior Descending Artery, arising from the distal 
segment, is a medium caliber vessel.
The Right Posterolateral Artery, arising from the distal 
segment, is a medium caliber vessel.
Sedation
The procedure was not feasible without moderate sedation. Risks, 
benefits and alternatives were
discussed and informed consent obtained. With rhythm, blood 
pressure and oxygen saturation monitors,
constant nursing observation, and direct attending supervision, 
the patient received an appropriate level
of sedation (see medication list ). The attending was at the 
bedside continuously for 20 min during
sedation. The patient was subsequently observed with serial 
examinations until the return of pre-sedation
mental status.

Complications
There were no clinically significant complications.
Findings

 Branch vessel coronary artery disease.
 Mild disease. Known small OM occlusion is chronic and seen on 
prior angio.

Brief Hospital Course:
========
SUMMARY
========
Mr. ___ is a ___ male without medical care 
for several years, no known past medical history, who initially 
presented to ___ on ___ with SOB and palpitations, 
found to have heart failure (acute, unclear if chronic 
component), afib with RVR, leukocytosis with left shift, and 
infrarenal 6cm AAA. 

====================
ACUTE MEDICAL ISSUES
====================
#6cm infrarenal AAA: CT read at outside hospital raised 
concerning for evidence of hemorrhage into wall and weakening of 
wall concerning for impending rupture. However, per review by 
Dr. ___ ___ vascular surgery team there was no 
radiographic evidence of rupture and emergent surgery was not 
indicated. Vascular surgery team saw him in house and 
recommended optimization of cardiac problems before proceeding 
with an elective AAA repair. To further evaluate the AAA, we 
obtained a dedicated CTA abdomen. Vascular surgery reviewed 
imaging and appears amenable to physician modified ___. He 
was asymptomatic from the AAA standpoint. 

From a cardiology standpoint, we would like to treat with 
uninterrupted anticoagulation for at least 4 weeks at which time 
we will repeat TEE to assess atrial thrombus. If thrombus has 
resolved, consider for cardioversion pending repeat assessment 
of EF at that time. If has cardioversion, would need to be 
followed by another 4 weeks of uninterrupted anticoagulation. 

# HFrEF, acute: Initial Outside hospital TTE showed LVEF 35% 
with inferior WMA, moderate MR/TR, moderate AI and AS while 
patient was in atrial fibrillation. On repeat at ___ while in 
afib with improved rate control showed LVEF 45-50%. He reported 
no functional limitations at home prior to this incident without 
PND, or orthopnea. He underwent a cardiac cath on ___ which 
showed coronary disease (99% stenosis of distal LCx) though not 
significant enough to explain his degree of cardiomyopathy. 
Suspect cardiomyopathy is tachycardia-mediated and may improve 
with cardioversion. Should plan for cardioversion if repeat TEE 
in 4 weeks shows resolution of atrial thrombus and persistent 
reduced EF while in atrial fibrillation. Will discharge on every 
other day dosing of lasix 20 mg. 

# NSTEMI: Presented with lateral STDs on EKG on admission, mild 
troponinemia which has not been rising. Suspect this represents 
a type II NSTEMI secondary to demand ischemia, however could 
have had a missed event several days prior to admission. Cardiac 
cath did show significant a 99% stenosis of distal LCx which was 
not revascularized as did not seem to be supplying significant 
portion of myocardium and given need for surgery in near future 
did not want to commit patient to ___ year of uninterrupted DAPT. 
Optimized medication regimen with ASA, statin, and beta blocker.

# A. fib w/ RVR: Unclear trigger, but suspect may have been 
missed ischemic event as above. Patient was initially held off 
of anticoagulation due to possible need for surgery but once 
deemed stable was started on apixaban 5mg BID (CHADs2-VASc score 
is 4). Patient was initially started on an esmolol gtt but 
eventually transitioned to PO metoprolol succinate 200mg QAM and 
100mg QPM and PO digoxin 0.125mg daily with good control of 
rates. Patient had a TEE in anticipation of cardioversion but 
discovered a left atrial thrombus so cardioversion was aborted. 
Patient will need to remain on uninterrupted for 4 weeks and 
have a repeat TEE at that time to assess for resolution of 
atrial thrombus.  Should also assess ejection fraction at that 
time and if still compromised, consider cardioversion for 
possible tachycardia mediated cardiomyopathy.

# Leukocytosis: Patient presented with leukocytosis in the range 
of ___ with no clear evidence of infection clinically or on 
imaging. In ___ he had had a WBC of 18 on outside labs which he 
brought in for our review. Heme/onc reviewed smear which 
contained signficant left shift and circulating blast count of 
2%. No dysplastic features seen. He was initially given ATRA on 
___ due to concern for APML. However,given the absence of a 
significant number of circulating blasts in the periphery this 
was felt to be unlikely. ___ was sent for BCR/ABL PCR and was 
negative.  This effectively excludes a diagnosis of chronic 
myelogenous leukemia.  Per heme/onc, given low blast count and 
leukocytosis on previous testing, very unlikely to be an acute 
leukemia.  On ___, patient underwent bone marrow biopsy.  
Results pending.  Patient has a follow-up appointment with the 
oncology team on ___ to review results of bone marrow biopsy.
  
# ___: Unknown baseline, Cr 1.8 on admission downtrended to 1.1 
on discharge.  Likely cardiorenal in the setting of heart 
failure exacerbation on admission.  Patient was given IV 
diuresis with improvement in creatinine.  Patient likely has 
mild CKD although do not have baseline to compare to.

# s/p Tobacco use disorder: had quit prior to admission.

====================

controlled at discharge on metoprolol and digoxin.  Patient 
should remain on Eliquis 5 mg twice daily uninterrupted and 
should have repeat TEE in 4 weeks to reassess left atrial 
thrombus.  If ejection fraction still compromised at that time 
please consider cardioversion for potential tachycardia induced 
cardiomyopathy.

- You were transferred to ___ due to concern about an enlarged 
blood vessel in your abdomen (AAA).
- Vascular surgery reviewed your imaging and will plan on 
surgery when your heart rate is stabilized and they can 
interrupt your anticoagulation.

was controlled with medications (metoprolol and digoxin).

ELiquis) for stroke prevention. 
- You were found to have a blood clot in your heart, which means 
your anticoagulation needs to be uninterrupted for 4 weeks.   
- You underwent a bone marrow biopsy on ___ and you tolerated 
the procedure well. 

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?  
================================  
- Please take all your medications as prescribed.
- Please arrange to establish with a primary care doctor within 
1 week of discharge.
- Please go to your follow up appointments as scheduled below 
with cardiology, hematology, and vascular surgery.
- Please refrain from showering for 24 hours after your bone 
marrow biopsy.
- You will need to remain on anticoagulation (eliquis) 
uninterrupted for at least the next 4 weeks. After 4 weeks, you 
should undergo another transesophageal echocardiogram to 
reassess the clot. If it has resolved, then you should discuss 
with your Cardiologist about cardioversion.
- Your surgeon will be in coordination with your Cardiologist to 
decide the safest timing of surgery.
- Weigh yourself when you get home and every morning. If your 
weight changes more than 2 lbs. within 24 hours, call your 
physician for management of your heart failure medications.

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!

Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar Decompression Without Fusion

You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

                Activity:You should not lift anything greater 
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks.You will be more comfortable if you do 
not sit or stand more than~45 minutes without moving around.

                Rehabilitation/ Physical ___ times a 
day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your 
recovery.You can walk as much as you can tolerate.Limit any kind 
of lifting.

                Diet:Eat a normal healthy diet.You may have 
some constipation after surgery.You have been given medication 
to help with this issue.

                Brace:You may have been given a brace.If you 
have been given a brace, this brace is to be worn when you are 
walking.You may take it off when sitting in a chair or lying in 
bed.

                Wound Care: Please keep the incision covered 
with a dry dressing on until follow up appointment. Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower.Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery,do not get the incision wet.Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office.

                You should resume taking your normal home 
medications.

                You have also been given Additional Medications 
to control your pain.Please allow 72 hours for refill of 
narcotic prescriptions,so please plan ahead.You can either have 
them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located 
on ___.We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions(oxycontin,oxycodone,percocet) to your pharmacy.In 
addition,we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 
90 days from the date of surgery.

                Follow up:            

               Please Call the office and make an appointment 
for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been 
done already.

                At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, 
take baseline X-rays and answer any questions.We may at that 
time start physical therapy.

                We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of 
the operation and at that time release you to full activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
Physical Therapy:
1)Weight bearing as tolerated.2)Gait,balance training.3)No 
lifting >10 lbs.4)No significant bending/twisting. 
Treatments Frequency:
Please keep the incision covered with a dry dressing on until 
your follow up appointment. Once the incision is completely dry 
(usually ___ days after the operation) you may take a shower.Do 
not soak the incision in a bath or pool.If the incision starts 
draining at anytime after surgery,do not get the incision 
wet.Call the office at that time. f you have an incision on your 
hip please follow the same instructions in terms of wound care.

Descending artery, which arises from the LM, is a large caliber 
vessel. There is a severe thrombus with a TIMI flow grade of 0 
in the mid segment. There is a 100% stenosis in the mid segment. 
The Septal Perforator, arising from the proximal segment, is a 
small caliber vessel. The ___ Diagonal, arising from the 
proximal segment, is a medium caliber vessel. The ___ Diagonal, 
arising from the mid segment, is a medium caliber vessel. There 
is a 100% stenosis in the proximal segment. There is a severe 
thrombus in the proximal, mid, and distal segments. Cx: The 
Circumflex artery, which arises from the LM, is a large caliber 
vessel. The ___ Obtuse Marginal, arising from the proximal 
segment, is a medium caliber vessel. The ___ Obtuse Marginal, 
arising from the mid segment, is a medium caliber vessel. RCA: 
The Right Coronary Artery, arising from the right cusp, is a 
large caliber vessel. The Acute Marginal, arising from the 
proximal segment, is a small caliber vessel. The Right Posterior 
Descending Artery, arising from the distal segment, is a medium 
caliber vessel. The Right Posterolateral Artery, arising from 
the distal segment, is a medium caliber vessel. 

Percutaneous Coronary Intervention: Percutaneous coronary 
intervention (PCI) was performed on an ad hoc basis based on the 
coronary angiographic findings from the diagnostic portion of 
this procedure. A 6 ___ EBU3.5 guide provided adequate 
support. Crossed with a Runthrough wire into the distal LAD. 
Predilated with a 2.0 mm balloon and then aspiration 
thrombectomy x 2 passes. Significant improvement in thrombus 
burden. Final angiography revealed normal flow, no dissection 
and 0% residual stenosis. Diagnonal 2 with thrombus was wired 
and dottered with improvement in flow. The procedure was not 
feasible without moderate sedation. There were no clinically 
significant complications.

or residual thromus) seen in the mid and distal LAD by ___.

stent placed.

ACUTE ISSUES: 
============= 
#Anterior STEMI
#Apical Akinesis
Patient presented initially to CHA with ___ minutes of chest 
pain. EKG demonstrated ST elevations in V1-4. He was given 
aspirin, clopidogrel, heparin gtt, nitro, and morphine and 
transferred to ___ for further management. On arrival, he was 
taken to the cath lab where a thrombectomy of the LAD was 
performed. No stents were placed. There were no residual 
coronary artery disease visualized on the cath, raising concern 
for an embolic source of the stroke. Plan is for him to follow 
up with Dr. ___ in clinic to arrange for ziopatch placement 
in order to quantify any possible paroxysmal atrial 
fibrillation, although we did not identify this on telemetry 
during his stay. He had a negative TTE with bubble study. He has 
a newly depressed ejection fraction of ___. The patient was 
started on aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and 
lisinopril for cardioprotection. He was started on warfarin for 
prevention of thrombus prevention given apical akinesis; he 
should receive a follow up TTE in 3 months post-discharge to 
assess return of function and possible cessation of warfarin. On 
discharge, his INR was 2.1.

#Scrotal swelling
Patient was very concerned about a described "dusky" 
discoloration of the scrotal skin skin his recent laminectomy. 
The patient was evaluated by Ortho Spine and Urology. Urology 
felt it could be related to nerve damage after recent spine 
surgery. Can continue to monitor.

#S/p laminectomy
Patient was recently admitted on ___ for severe central canal 
stenosis at L3-L4 with almost complete obliteration, consistent 
with cauda equina and had a laminectomy performed. Ortho Spine 
saw pt during this hospitalization and advised outpatient follow 
up 2 weeks post-discharge.

Brief Hospital Course:
A/P: ___ y/o female with a PMH of HTN, hyperlipidemia, and breast 
cancer who presented to the ED s/p mechanical fall and was found 
to be hypoxic.   
.  
# s/p mechanical fall: In the emergency department the patient 
had a plain film done of her left hip as well as CT scan of the 
pelvis which showed no evidence of fracture. She did have some 
initial improvement in her hip pain with addition of Percocet 
and tramadol as needed, however still had some unsteadiness on 
her feet due to pain. The physical therapy team evaluated her 
and felt that she would be safest to go to a rehabilitation 
facility to rebuild her strength before going home. She 
continued to improve with each physical therapy session.
.
# Hypoxia: The patient was noted to have an O2 sat of <85% on RA 
on the ED and was started on 4L O2 NC. This was then weaned to 
2L. On room air she repeatedly had O2 sats between 85-88% and 
<88% upon ambulation on room air. Upon review of the records 
this appears to be a common occurrence upon hospitalization that 
she has been hypoxic and requiring oxygen. She however, has been 
completely asymptomatic related to this. She had a CTA which 
showed no evidence of PE, but did show evidence of diffuse 
emphysema which was in accordance with what was seen on prior 
CTA a year ago. As a result she was scheduled for follow-up in 
___ clinic with Dr. ___ at the end of ___. She 
remained asymptomatic throughout her hospital stay.
.  
# UTI: Pt was asymptomatic, however had a urinalysis revealing 
many WBCs in her urine upon arrival to the emergency department. 
She was initially treated with levofloxacin and then switched to 
ciprofloxacin for a total of a three day course. She would 
benefit from repeat U/A and culture after discharge given a 
history of frequent UTIs in the past and episode of urosepsis on

Brief Hospital Course:
___ F with history of CKD, dementia, HTN, DMII, presenting from 
clinic with worsening hypertension, altered mental status and 
acute renal failure.

# Delirium - the patient was found to be delirious on admission. 
 Initial workup, including blood work, cultures and head CT scan 
was negative.  A paronychia of her right large toe was found 
which was drained; pain from the paronychia may have contributed 
to her initial delirium. Geriatrics was consulted, and the 
patient received supportive measures such as better pain 
control, a bowel regimen and attempts to preserve her sleep wake 
cycle.  She was agitated at times, and responded poorly to 
olanzapine but did improve with daily seroquel 6.25 at night, 
which was later increased to 12.5 to help improve her sleep/wake 
cycle.  A urinalysis was later re-checked which did demonstrate 
a urinary tract infection and she was treated with IV 
ceftriaxone for 3 days. Finally, her delirium might have been 
worsened by constipation, which was treated with disimpaction.

# Urinatry tract infection - treated as above.

# Hypertension - the patient had a blood pressure elevated with 
systolic pressures in the 200s at clinic prior to admission.  
She was continued on valsartan and amlodipine, and hydralazine 
10mg bid was added to her regimen, resulting in good blood 
pressure control.

# Diabetes - the patient was not on any oral anti-hyperglycemics 
on admission as her PCP had discontinued these 3 weeks prior.  
She was started on a humalog sliding scale and lantus.

#Acute renal failure - This resolved quickly with IV fluids. 

#Code status: The patient was confirmed to be DNR/DNI with the 
family.

#Transition of care issues: Geriatrics recommended discontinuing 
the rosuvastatin and omeprazole if they are not needed.  This 
should be discussed with the patient's primary care provider.

his ankle to help with the edema.  We will plan on bringing him
into the operating room early next week for removal of the
external fixator with ORIF.  He is understanding of this.  All
his questions and concerns were answered.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
 - Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please 
follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
 -Nonweightbearing right lower extremity in splint

MEDICATIONS:
   1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This 
is an over the counter medication.
   2)  Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on 
how to wean down:
 then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
 then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
 then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
 then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
 then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
 Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
   3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
   4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
   5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
   6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
   7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
   8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
       
 ANTICOAGULATION:
 - Continue your dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and 
plavix

WOUND CARE:
 - You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
 - Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
 - Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.
 - Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed.
 - Do NOT get splint wet.

DANGER SIGNS:
 Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
 - Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
 - Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
 - Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
 - Fever greater than 101.4
 - Shaking chills
 - Chest pain
 - Shortness of breath
 - Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
 - Any other medical concerns

 

FOLLOW UP:
Please call ___ to schedule a follow up with your 
Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr. ___. You will have follow up with 
___, NP in the Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic 14 days 
post-operation for evaluation. Call ___ to schedule 
appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for any new medications/refills.

 
Physical Therapy:
Activity:   Activity:  Out of bed w/ assist
 Right lower extremity:  Non weight bearing
 Left lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
Encourage turning, deep breathing and coughing qhour when awake.

hospital course his pain was well controlled. He was gradually 
converted to oral pain medications. He was provided with 
pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis, and he 
ambulated on POD1 with assistance. Appropriate home medications 
were restarted and dressing changes were coordinated with 
primary urology team and plastic surgery team. Diet was advanced 
regular and his blood pressure medications were titrated for 
tighter control, although he continued to rise above SBP 150.

had acute onset of right great toe pain w/ erythema and calor.

internal medicaine were consulted with regard to his 
uncontrolled hypertension and the new onset of what this likely 
"gout." The remainder of the hospital course was unremarkable. 
Mr. ___ was discharged in stable condition, eating well, 
ambulating independently, and with pain control on oral 
analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with 
no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. The patient was 
given explicit instructions to follow-up in one week for

Discharge Instructions:
Do NOT shower until cleared by Dr. ___.

Do NOT engage in sexual activity (intercourse, masturbation) for 
at least six weeks and until cleared by Dr. ___.

Pain Medicine
For Mild Pain: 
Take acetaminophen,which is Tylenol. Take 2 of the 325 mg 
tablets of Tylenol every 4-to-6 hours for pain. Do not take more 
than 4,000 mg of Tylenol in 24 hours. 
For Strong Pain: 
You may be given a prescription for a narcotic pain medicine.
Take this exactly the way your doctor tells you to.
Narcotic pain medicine may make you sleepy and lightheaded.
Do not drink alcohol, drive, or use machinery while you are 
taking narcotic pain medicine. 
As your pain lessens, decrease the amount of pain medicine you 
are taking.
Do not drink alcohol, drive, or use machinery while you are 
taking narcotic pain medicine.
Home Medications
Please resume all of your home medicines except for your 
aspirin, which should resume when cleared by Dr. ___.

Constipation
Narcotic pain medicine can cause constipation. During the 
first month, it is important to keep your stools soft. 
To make it easier to have a bowel movement:

Drink extra fluids.
Eat foods high in fiber like fruits, vegetables and whole 
grains.

Take a stool softener like docusate. Docusate is also called 
Colace®. You have been given a prescription for Colace®. You can 
also buy it over the counter which may cost less. 

You may also take another laxative like Senna, prune juice, 
Milk of Magnesia, or Metamucil. 

Diet
You may not be as hungry as you usually are for several weeks. 
This is normal and will pass. Do not force yourself to eat. 
Do not drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain medicines. 
Do remember to drink plenty of water which is ___ glasses a 
day. 
Activity 
Walking is encouraged. Climbing stairs is ok. Do not do any 
strenuous exercise like aerobics, running or weight lifting for 
4 weeks.
Do not lift more than 10 pounds for 4 weeks unless your 
urology surgeon says it is ok. Ten pounds is as heavy as a 
gallon of milk.

Driving
Do not drive if you are taking narcotic pain medicine. Once 
you are no longer taking narcotic pain medicine, you may resume 
driving if you are no longer experiencing pain, weakness or 
other discomfort that would impair your ability to drive safely. 
This usually takes about 1 week. If you are still in pain or 
have weakness at 1 week, do not start driving until this 
resolves.

Possible Problems 
Please call for fevers above 101 degrees, especially if 
accompanied by shaking chills. 

WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
o-Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on 
routine care and hygiene

o-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

o-DO NOT allow anyone outside your urologist/team 
representative remove your Foley for any reason.

o-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time. The leg bag (if 
provided)  is for short-duration periods and the bag must be 
emptied frequently.

o-Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your 
safety-but of course you may be a passenger

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It has been a pleasure taking part in your care at the hospital. 
You were admitted because you were having bleeding from your 
penis. We think that a tear occurred in the urethra when your 
catheter accidentally came out at rehab. You continued to have 
bleeding at the hospital, especially with movement, and the 
urology team removed your catheter and cystoscopy was performed. 
Bleeding was seen near the end of the urethra, and a larger 
catheter was placed that helped slow down the bleeding. You had 
clear urine over most of the admission, including the last few 
days of the admission. You required transfusions. 

Additionally, you had findings of increased potassium in your 
blood and injury to your kidney. These both improved by the time 
of your discharge.

WHAT YOU SHOULD DO AFTER LEAVING THE HOSPITAL:
1. Work on building up your strength at rehab
2. Keep your catheter in until you are evaluated by the 
urologists in their clinic
3. Continue the decreased dose of atenelol. Discuss with your 
primary care doctor whether to increase it
4. Do not take aspirin or lisinopril until your doctor tells you 
to

___, it has been a pleasure taking part in your care, and we 
wish you the best.
- Your ___ care team

Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. ___, You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery Service on ___ after a fall sustaining left sided rib fractures. You were given pain medication and watched closely to make sure you were able to take deep breaths. You were seen and evaluated by the physical therapists who recommend that you have ongoing physical therapy at home. You are now ready to be discharged home with the following discharge instructions: * Your injury caused left sided rib fracture ___ which can cause severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of the pain. * You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and notify your physician. * Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures. In order to decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 times every hour while awake. This will help expand the small airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that pool in the lungs. * You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and deep breathing. * Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short periods may ease the pain. * Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid and fiber intake if possible. * Do NOT smoke * If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side effects so make sure your doctor approves. * Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation around your ribs (crepitus). You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc). 8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). If you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to continue at your previous dose while taking this medication. ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS. 9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up appointment in two weeks. 10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, wound checks. 11. Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the podiatric surgery service, 
transferred from an outside hostpial on ___ for a 
surgical site infection, right hallux.

Throughout her hospital stay, the patient remained afebrile with 
stable vital signs; pain was well controlled with oral pain 
medication on a PRN basis.  The patient remained stable from 
both a cardiovascular and pulmonary standpoint. He was placed on 
vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and flagyl while hospitalized. On 
hospital day 2, she was seen by the infectious disease team who 
recommended a 6 week course of ancef for cultures growing MSSA. 
Patients intake and output were closely monitored and noted to 
be adequate. The patient received subcutaneous lovenox 
throughout admission; early and frequent ambulation were 
strongly encouraged.

At the outside hospital, the patient received 2 positive tests 
with +HCG in her urine.  The test was repeated here, and while 
it was negative, the serum HCG remained elevated. The Gynecology 
was consulted who recommended obtaining a pelvic ultrasound 
which was negative for a pelvic mass. They recommended she 
follow up with gynecology for a further outpatient workup and 
would contact her in regards to her blood work as well as an 
appointment time.

The patient was subsequently discharged home on hospital day 3. 
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home with services. The 
patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions 
with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge 
plan.

Home With Service
 
Facility:

Discharge Diagnosis:
R foot infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted 
to the Podiatric Surgery service after your right foot surgery. 
You were given IV antibiotics while here. You were also found to 
have elevation of a hormone in your blood known as HCG, or human 
chorionic gonadotropin hormone. We discussed this with the 
gynecologists who recommended an ultrasound of your pelvis which 
was normal. The gynecologists evaluated you and recommended that 
you follow up with them as an outpatient. You are being 
discharged home with the following instructions: 

ACTIVITY:
There are restrictions on activity. Please remain weight bearing 
as tolerated to your right foot in a surgical shoe until your 
follow up appointment. You should keep this site elevated when 
ever possible (above the level of the heart!) 

No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS:
Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s).
New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toes.
Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever 
greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus 
draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these 
or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR.

Exercise:
Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks.
No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next ___ days.
Try to keep leg elevated when able.

BATHING/SHOWERING:
You may shower immediately upon coming home, but you must keep 
your dressing CLEAN, DRY and INTACT. You can use a shower bag 
taped around your ankle/leg or hang your foot/leg outside of the 
bathtub. You should not get your foot wet as this can result in 
worsening infection. You should change your dressing every other 
day by applying gauze with betadine to your wound with a kerlex, 
or gauze wrap to your foot.

Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for 4 
weeks after surgery or until cleared by your physician.

MEDICATIONS:
Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the 
medications you were taking before surgery. 
Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you 
should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check 
with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel 
that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may 
use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite 
suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small 
balanced meals throughout the day. 

DIET:
There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. 
Poor appetite is not unusual for several weeks and small, 
frequent meals may be preferred.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
Be sure to keep your medical appointments. 
If a follow up appointment was not made prior to your discharge, 
please call the office on the first working day after your 
discharge from the hospital to schedule a follow-up visit. This 
should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days 
after discharge. Normal office hours are ___ 
through ___.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR 
QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE.

myeloablative induction for possible allogeneic stem cell 
transplant.  Patient started induction chemotherapy on ___ 
with cytarabine and idarubicin (7+3) according to protocol.  Her 
dasatinib was held.  Her ANC nadir was ___. Her course was 
complicated by fevers for which she was started on vancomycin 
and cefepime and her PICC line was removed.  Blood cultures,

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Accelerated Phase Chronic Myeloid Leukemia: Patient was 
treated with busulfan/cytoxan conditioning per protocol.  She 
experienced some nausea and emesis which was controlled with 
zofran.  Stem cell transplant was performed. Her course was 
complicated by neutropenic fever and she was treated with 
antibiotics. She remained culture negative. She developed 
esophagitis and was found to be negative for CMV but esophaheal 
biopsy suggested esophageal GHVD and also had evidence of skin 
GHVD. She received a tapered course of steroids and improved. 
She also developed intense headaches while she was 
thrombocytopenic. Head CT showed no acute intracranial 
hemorrhage or mass effect, with a few vague dense areas noted in 
the brainstem/posterior fossa, likely being artifactual. Her 
headaches resolved. She was discharged to the oncology 
apartments and will follow closely with the ___ and 
her primary oncologist.
.
#. Hypertension.  On admission, patients metoprolol was 
continued but her valsartan was held out of concern for renal 
toxicity with chemotherapy.  Her blood pressure trended up 
during her conditioning and her metoprolol dose was increased. 
Subsequently nifedipine was also added and she was discharged on 
nifedpine and metoprolol with good blood pressure control. She 
had serial EKGs performed given her cardiac history, and her 
cardiac status should continue to be monitored as an outpatient. 


.

Brief Hospital Course:
#N/V/D: the pt p/w reported having several loose stools and 
sporadic vomiting throughout the past week prior to 
presentation. She also reported decreased po intake since 
___ with accompanying nausea/vomiting. Additionally, pt had 
hx suggestive of upper GI GVHD. She was started empirically on 
methylprednisolone 30 mg IV BID, in addition to her Budensonide 
3 mg PO TID, and cyclosporine 125 mg IV q12 for possible GVH 
colitis. Zofran and omeprazole were ordered for her 
nausea/vomiting.  Stools were sent for o&p, bact cultures, viral 
cultures, and clostridium difficile toxin.  Due to her 
continuing diarrhea, CT abdomen done on HD3 which showed 
uncomplicated ileocolitis with continuous involvement of distal 
ileum up to proximal transverse colon just beyond the hepatic 
flexure, suggestive of graft versus host disease or 
infectious/inflammatory etiologies.  The pt. was placed NPO on 
HD3 for colonoscopy, but given her poor PO intake while in the 
hospital, was evaluated and started on TPN by HD4.   While on 
the high dose steroids, the pt's diarrhea did not improve much, 
and she wast started on empiric abx therapy with metronidazole  
500 mg IV qday and levofloxacin 750 mg IV qday (as she was 
allergic to cefepime/possibly penicillins) on HD4.  Stool 
studies all came back negative for infectious etiologies of her 
diarrhea.  Bx results from her colonoscopy were negative for CMV 
but positive for severe graft versus host colitis throughout the 
colon.  Her antibiotics were discontinued, and she was started 
on mycophenolate mofetil 1000 mg po BID and her cyclosporine was 
increased from 175 mg po BID to ___ qAM/qHS.  Her 
diarrhea began to improve, TPN was dc'd on HD 9, and she was 
discharged home on HD12 on CSA, MMF, and IV methylprednisolone 
for control of her GVH colitis.  
.  
#Hx of CML s/p alloSCT: she was continued on immunosuppressive 
therapy per above.  Additionally, she was continued on ppx 
therapy with changes in her home fluconazole to PO voriconazole 
___ concern of hepatic interaction, continuation of her 
Acyclovir 400 mg q12hr, Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO MWF, 
and ursodiol 300 mg BID.  No further issues were encountered 
during her hospital stay.  She was discharghed home on 
acyclovir, and voriconazole.  SMX/TMP was held due to 
administration of pentamidine while in house.  Will f/u with her 
hematologist/oncologist as an outpatient for adjustment of her 
medications.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital due to nausea, vomiting, and 
diarrhea for several days duration.  You had a CT scan of you 
abdomen which showed inflammation.  You were given medications 
for a possible infection in your colon for several days, as well 
as medications for possible Graft Versus Host Disease of the 
colon.  You were evaluated by colon specialists 
(gastroenterologists) who performed a procedure to look at the 
inside of you colon and take biopsies (colonoscopy).  It was 
determined that your diarrhea was NOT from an infection, but due 
to Graft-Versus-Host-Disease (a complication that can happen in 
people with allogenic stem cell transplants).  You were placed 
on large doses of immunosuppressants (Methylprednisolone, 
Cyclosporin, Mycophenolate Mofetil, and Budenoside) to stop your 
immune system from attacking your colon.  Your diarrhea began to 
improve, you were placed on a full low bacteria diet, and 
discharged from the hospital.
.

units blood. She was admitted from clinic for steroids and

Presents with a 5 day hx of nausea, vomiting and 3 days of loose 
stools. Pthad been feeling unwell since ___. this 
started with abdominal pains in the central abdomen which were 
intermittent cramping pains lasting a few minutes and then 
returning. There was no radiation and at that point there was 
mild nausea and following breakfast vomited x1 non-bilious and 
no blood. The pain was associated with eating and drinking and 
had no relieving factors but worse when drinking water. The 
pains have been intermittent since and have been at worst a 
___. On ___ the pains and nausea persisted and 
vomited x1 in the same pattern after eating cereal.
___ vomited x1 with dinner and started having loose stools. 
She has opened bowels 2x per day -stool was not watery but a lot 
softer and there was no blood - she normally opens her bowels 
once per day. Appetite has not been good since her transplant 
and this was mildly worse over the past week. She notes 
abdominal pain today and is worse on mobilising. She has only 
had one bowel movement today. She has been able to drink 
sufficient fluids. At clinic, her ecchymoses on her arms were 
felt to be worse although the patient herself has not noticed a 
significant difference.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with CML, s/p allogeneic SCT D 163 (on discharge) with 
post-transplant period complicated by upper and lower GI GVH 
(biopsy ___, s/p treatment with steroids, currently on 
cyclosporin 50 in am, 25 in pm and atovaquone, who presents with 
persistent nausea, vomitting, and diarrhea. Anemic on 
presentation and transfused 2 units of RCC and following a 
seemingly inadequate response on lab tests received a further 2 
units. Started on IV methylprednisolone for ? GVHD and converted 
to an oral steroid taper. Cyclosporin level increased due to low 
level. Deranged LFTs noted and will be repeated in community. 
Found to have an enterobacter UTI and commenced on a 3 days 
course of oral levofloxacin.
.
#Nausea, vomiting and diarrhea: Presented with 5 days of 
symptoms which were improving on admission. For concerns of GVHD 
(see previous history) she was started on IV methylprednisolone 
30mg bid and this was converted to an oral prednisone taper 
following resolution of symptoms by the day after admission. PRN 
ondansetron for nausea. She was found to have moderate LeukE on 
UA although there were only 3WBCs on urine microscopy. She was 
commenced on a 3-day course of oral levofloxacin for her UTI 
(note sensitive to ciprofloxacin on sensitivity testing). Stool 
cultures were negative.
.
#Anemia: She was noted to have a Hb/Hct of 7.1/20.2 in clinic 
and was transfused 2 units RCC. Post transfusion HCt was only 
20.5 (cause unclear) and she received a further 2 units RCC with 
post transfusion labs Hb 9.9 HCt 29.1. Retic count was suitably 
elevated for degree of anemia and other hemolysis screen was 
negative.
.
# CML #/p stem cell transplant: continue acyclovir 400 mg Tablet 
q8 and atovaquone [Mepron] 750 mg/5 mL Suspension 10 ml by mouth 
daily. Will follow with Dr ___ on ___.
.
# Possible GVHD: Her symptoms were thought to perhaps represent 
mild GVHD although the presence of a UTI may be the cause. She 
was started on a IV methylprednisolone and converted to an oral 
steroid taper. Her cyclosporin dose was increased to 50mg am 
75mg pm following a low cyclosporin level of <30. Continued 
budesonide.
.
#Elevated LFTs: She was noted to have deranged LFTs on admission 
which were not present on previous laboratory testing. There was 
evidence of a transaminitis and increased during admission. She 
will have her blood repeated on ___ with results faxed to Dr 
___.
.
# Likely peripheral neuropathy: Tingling in hands and feet, 
absent AJs and decreased temp sensation to mid shins 
bilaterally. Likely secondary to chemo.
.
#HTN: continued metoprolol tartrate 50 mg Tablet bid and 
nifedipine [Nifediac CC] 90 mg Tablet Sustained Release DAILY

LIVER OR GALLBLADDER US (SINGLE ORGAN) Study Date of ___ 
8:36 AM 
FINDINGS: Normal liver parenchymal echogenicity. There is a 
well-demarcated 1.5 x 1.2 x 2.5 cm hyperechoic focus adjacent to 
the portal vein in the right lobe of liver. The appearances are 
typical of an area of focal fatty infiltration. No suspicious 
liver lesion is identified. Echogenic sludge is identified 
within the gallbladder. No biliary dilatation. The common duct 
measures 3 mm maximally. Normal appearance of the pancreatic 
head and body. The tail was poorly visualized due to overlying 
bowel gas (2.5 cm). The left, middle and right hepatic veins 
appear normal on Doppler examination. In addition normal flow 
was seen within the right, main and left portal veins. Normal 
appearance of the IVC and superior mesenteric vein. Of note, 
there is persistent splenomegaly with the spleen measuring 18 cm 
in long axis. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of portal vein or hepatic vein thrombus.  
2 2.5 cm area of focal fatty infiltration adjacent to the 
proximal 
intrahepatic portal vein. 
3. Small gallstones 
.

of ___ 12:56 ___

and proximal jejunum which may be inflammatory or infectious in

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with CML, s/p MRD allo SCT ___ with 
Busulfan/Cyclophosphamide. Her post-transplant course was 
complicated with GVH of the upper and lower GI tract that 
required hopitalization for IV steroids and increased 
immunosuppression. She was admitted for investigation of 
worsening LFTs. She was treated with high dose IV 
methylprednisolone, oral Mycophenolate mofetil and increasing 
cyclosporin doses. She quickly developed symptoms suggestive of 
GI GVHD with cramping ___ pain, nausea and vomiting. LFTs 
worsened during admission but she did not necessitate a liver 
biopsy due to considerable improvement in these following 
increased immunosuppression. The general picture was that of 
severe multi-organ GVHD. Her GI symptoms worsened with abdominal 
pain and profuse watery diarrhea and she had a CT scan which 
demonstrtaed confluent small bowel enteritis. At this point she 
was placed on bowel rest and administered TPN. GVHD was 
confirmed at endoscopy and biopsy where mucosa was noted to be 
friable and extensively ulcerated in keeping with severe GVHD. 
Her cyclosporin was titrated up and her symptoms improved 
although diarrhea persisted despite a considerable period of 
bowel rest on TPN. Her Hb/HCt had been slowly falling and her 
stool was found to be guaiac +ve felt likely 2o to her bowel 
inflammation. She was found to have a swollen left arm shortly 
after a PICC line was placed and there was evidence of an 
extensive LUE DVT extending to the subclavian vein. This was 
treated conservatively as anticoagulation was felt to be 
inadvisable in the setting of her continued bowel inflamation 
and guaiac +ve stools. Due to problmes of low cyclosporin levels 
her cyclosporina nd mycophenolate were changed to IV on ___. 
WBC count progressively dropped ? cause and she may need a bone 
marrow biopsy soon if her counts do not improve. She was 
continued on IV methylprednisolone mycophenolate and cyclosporin 
w/continued TPN for bowel rest. Blood glucoses high and 
titrating up insulin in TPN in addition to addingNPH low dose 
BID on ___. Gradually, diarrhea improved and pt was able to be 
transitioned slowly to PO medications. Levels of cyclosporin 
were monitored to ensure therapuetic range and absorptions. 
Slowly pt's diet was also advanced and at discharge pt was off 
TPN. Closes follow-up was planned on ___.
.
# Rising LFTs:  This was found to be liver GVHD.  Progressively 
settling following GVHD treatment. Mildly elevated on previous 
admission in week prior to current admission. She was initially 
asymptomatic although latterly developed severe diarrhea, nausea 
and vomiting. Her steroids initially oral prednisone were 
increased to IVMP 30mg bid and cyclosporin was gradually 
uptitrated. She had ___ U/S ___ which showed focal fatty 
infiltrate and nil else. Bil rose from 1.6 on ___ and 
transaminases were progressively rising. MRCP on ___ showed 
hemosiderosis of liver and spleen, thickening of duodenum and 
___ jejunum in keeping with inflammatory/infectious etiology 
and a small stone in GB. Seen by hepatology ___ and lab 
investigations for vit D,  Hep B/C/Adeno/CMV/HHV6/EBV PCRs, Hep 
A Ab, HSV Ab. These all came back -ve save vit D level which was 
low and seh was sterted on vitamin D supplementation. Put on 
bowel rest and started on TPN. Bil rose from 1.6 to 5.7 on ___ 
with improved transaminases. By repeat on ___ Bil level had 
dropped to 5.1 and by ___ Bil dropped to 2.9 with improved 
transaminases. She therefore did not go for liver bx. LFTs 
continued to trend down with high levels of immunosuppression. 
Slowly immunosuppression was titrated down and LFTs remained 
stable as diarrhea continued to improve. Transition to PO 
fluconazole resulted in rise in LFTs w/out evidence of other 
worsening GVHD symptoms so pt was restarted on home 
voriconazole. LFTs will continued to be monitored as meds are 
titrated on an outpt basis.
.
# CML: s/p allo SCT. She continues to recover from her 
transplant. Guaiac +ve stol ___ and transfused 1 unit 
___. Transfusion goal HCt >25 Plt >20. 
.
# GVHD ___ pain, nausea and  vomiting and elevated LFTs): 
Previous significant upper and lower GI GVHD. She ws found on 
this admission to again have severe GVHD in his case involving

methylpred 30mg bid. Whilst she was asymptomatic on admission, 
she quickly developed abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting felt 
likely to be GVHD. Increased cyclosporin to 75mg bid, added

Increased mycophenolate to 1g bid on ___. Cyclosporin 119 and

125mg bid ___ and 150mg bid ___ due to persistently low 
levels and felt that this was likely due to poor absorption from 
the gut. SShe had suprapubic tenderness with diarrhea as of ___ 
- NOT peritonitic. Initially felt to be ? inadequately treated 
UTI (Enterobacter in UCx in week prior and Rx levo for 3 days). 
Rpt UA and UCx were -ve. Started on oral cipro ___.. Due to 
diarrhea was changed to IV cipro/metronidazole ___. MRI showed 
duodenitis/jejunitis ? infectious ? inflammatory. Supportive IV 
fluids where given and then TPN was started for nutritional 
support. High stool output. Seen by GI ___ who recommended

___. ___ ___ showed small bowel enteritis 
encompassing most of small bowel with no dilatation. UGIE and bx

base and could be consistent with known history of GVHD. IV

# L UE DVT: Swollen L arm post PICC insertion. Had U/S and

overload. Monitor nutritional status and PO intake as well as GI 
symptoms of GVHD

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital because of rising liver 
function tests and concern that you were experiencing GVHD 
(rejection symptoms). You had recently been admitted for nausea, 
vomiting, and diarrhea and had responded to immunosupressive.

you on bowel rest, giving you IV forms of your medications and 
supporting you with IV nutrition. Your symptoms gradually 
improved and your diet was able to be slowly advanced. Your 
immunosupressive meds were also titrated to help prevent future 
flairs without oversuppresion of your immune system and bone 
marrow.

PATHOLOGY:
Muscle biopsy, r4 rectus femoris muscle:
Inflammatory myopathy, see note.
Note: Section showed myofibers with prominent inflammatory 
infiltrate composed of foamy macrophages, lymphocytes, and 
plasma cells.  Degenerative and regenerative fibers are seen.  
In some areas, myofibers are replaced by adipose and connective 
tissue, consistent with a subacute clinical picture. CD3 labeled 
prominent T cell infiltrate with numerous CB8 positive cytotoxic 
and scattered CD4 positive helper cells, while CD20 labeled B 
lymphocytes are rare in perivascular zones. CD68 highlighted 
abundant macrophages, some involved in myophagocytosis. The 
findings would be consistent with GVH myositis in the clinical 
context of CML status post alloSCT and history of GI and liver 
GVH disease. GVH myositis is indistinguishable histologically 
from sporatic polymyositis. Further studies including 
biochemical panel will be reported as an addendum.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with CAD s/p CABG, accelerated phase CML s/p 
allo SCT ___ complicated by upper and lower GI GVHD ___ 
and liver GVHD ___ presenting from OSH electively intubated 
for hypoxic and hypercarbic failure in the setting of myopathy. 
.
# Hypercarbic hypoxic respiratory failure: Pt was initially 
electively intubated given diffuse myopathy affecting 
respiratory muscles. Pt was managed on endotracheal intubation 
for 11 days before being trached on ___. Her ___ NIF has 
remained (-14)-(-18). During trials on trach collar, she has 
maintained her oxygen saturation and respiratory rate, however 
her blood pressure elevates and she reports subjective feelings 
of dyspnea and fatigue. Goal now for weaning her from the vent 
is treatment of her diffuse myositis to improve respiratory 
failure in the long term with gentle weaning to trach collar.
.
# Motor weakness: Based on muscle biopsy, inflammation is 
consistent with GVHD.  Muscle biopsy shows impressive 
inflammation despite having been on steriods prior to biopsy. 
Muscle strength appeared to initially improve on steroids, 
though now has been stable x 1 week. Following muscle biopsy, 
she was started on cyclosporine 25mg IV BID and received 1 dose 
of IVIG. She has had minimal improvement in her strength and is 
aware that this will be a prolonged recovery process.
.

organism. We do recommend repeat CT chest in ___ weeks for

frustrated by her current condition and long term recovery that 
is necessary. We have deferred starting an SSRI but this should 
be reconsidered outside of an acute hospitalization.
.

Her CBC has been stable and she has not required any recent 
transfusions. Threshold for transfusion would be platelets <10, 
hct <25
.

consulted and felt that her purpura was due to trauma and her 
coagulopathy.  The bullae were probably the result of hemorrhage 
into thin skin. They were drained and per derm, continued with 
light pressure dressings to prevent re-accumulation.
.

managed at home on amlodipine 5mg, and metoprolol succinate

amlodipine 5mg ___, metoprolol tartrate 100mg q6hr, and 
captopril 12.5mg TID. She has been noted to get hypertensive to 
170s when on trach collar. We would expect this to resolve as 
she becomes more comfortable on the trach collar and her 
strength improves. It would be possible to up titrate her 
captopril if she requires.
.
# DVT: Pt has bilateral DVT, however in setting of diffuse 
ecchymoses and hematomas, heparin drip was held. Pt had CTA at 
outside hospital to r/o PE and had an IVC filter placed.  She 
was placed on compression stockings to avoid further 
complications of thrombophlebitis.
.

.

and suspect that given decreased muscle mass, she may be 
supratheraputic from SQ heparin alone. Further work up is 
pending, including ___, anti-cardiolipin antibody, and

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of 
accelerated CML s/p allo-MRD SCT ___ complicated by GVHD of 
the liver, gut, myositis necessitating intubation due to 
respiratory muscle weakness.  She presented with worsening 
blood-streaked diarrhea and elevated LFTs, with hospitalization 
complicated by multiple DVTs and resulting BRBPR caused by 
heparin gtt, with BRBPR, and recurrent C. diff infection.
.
#. DIARRHEA: ___ GVHD and recurrent C diff. Patient has been 
having blood-streaked diarrhea since admission likely secondary 
to GVHD, which progressed to BRBPR with clots after starting 
heparin gtt for DVTs (see below). Heparin was discontinued, but 
patient with continued diarrhea. On ___ C. diff toxin was 
found positive. Pt has had multiple episodes of C diff in past, 
and prophylactic PO vanco had been discontinued on ___. She 
was started on IV flagyl on ___ for her positive C diff), then 
switched to vanco 500mg PO q6hrs per GI recs (used for recurrent 
c diff: 250-500mg PO q6hrs x14 days, then taper). Diarrhea 
progressively improved after this. Patient also has chronic gut 
and liver GVHD. She had EGD and colonoscopy on ___, which 
showed 2 whitish cecal plaques/nodules with biopsy showing focal 
active ileitis, rare apoptotic crypt cells in 
ileum/ascending/transverse colon consistent with (but not 
specific for) GVHD. Also had ileocecal valve nodules composed of 
"predominantly fibrinopurulent exudate consistent with ulcer and 
a very minute strip of surface epithelium". EGD/colonoscopy 
biopsies were found negative for AFB, fungi, CMV, viruses. For 
her C diff, patient is discharged on Vancomycin 500mg PO q6 
hours for 14 days (first day = ___, last day = ___. After 
this, she should restart suppressive therapy: vancomycin 250mg 
q6 hours chronically. For her GVHD, she is discharged on 
prednisone 30mg by mouth daily, and cyclosporine 50mg by mouth 
twice daily. 
.
#. BRBPR: pt admitted with blood-streaked stools, found likely 
secondary to GVHD (confirmed by colonoscopy on ___. When 
heparin gtt was started for multiple ___ DVTs, patient developed 
frank BRBPR with clots. This resolved after discontinuing 
heparin gtt; patient guaiac negative afterward. She was started 
on enoxaparin 40mg BID for DVT prophylaxis with no ensuing 
complications.   
.
#. ELEVATED LFTs: Patient has known GVHD of the liver.  LFTs on 
admission showed elevated AST, ALT and Alk Phosph, found likely 
___s voriconazole, which she is taking for h/o 
paelomyces (___). Her cyclosporine was uptitrated from 25 
BID to 50mg qAM and 75mg qPM. When cyclosporine was decreased to 
50BID, her LFTs rose again (AST 59, ALT 72, Alk Phosph 178). 
**Cyclosporine was increased/decreased/not changed....***
.
#. GVHD: manifested as gut, liver, and muscle GVHD. During 
hospitalization her cyclosporine was increased from 25mg BID to 
50mg BID as it was felt that her diarrhea on presentation was 
from GVHD. Her prednisone was decreased to 30mg by mouth daily. 
Due to her muscle GVHD (diagnosed by rheumatology), patient is 
extremely weak in her ___ flexor muscles. She will continue 
physical therapy at rehab. She was also incidentally found to 
have diffuse airway narrowing consistent with possible early 
bronchiolitis obliterans on chest CT on ___, although no 
clinical signs/symptoms and currently appropriately treated with 
steroids and cyclosporine. 
.
# MULTIPLE ___ DVTs: patient had left ___ swelling during 
hospitalization. ___ on ___ showed multiple BLE DVTs 
involving common femoral, superficial femoral, popliteal and 
posterior tibial and peroneal veins on L>R. ___ swelling L>R. Pt 
started on heparin gtt overnight ___, with a goal PTT of

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with a history of CML s/p allo stem cell 
transplant in ___ complicated by GVHD and pulmonary 
Paecilomyces infection who presented with several days of new 
cough found to be RSV positive.  
.
# Dyspnea - Patient presented with SOB which worsened despite 
treatment with azithromycin. CT chest showed evidence of 
multifocal pneumonia. She was initially started on levofloxacin 
and vancomycin. The infectious disease team was consulted. 
Respiratory viral screen returned positive for RSV. Patient was 
treated with Palivizumab. Antibiotics were discontinued. 
Respiratory symptoms improved. Patient was discharged with plans 
to treat cough and nasal congestion symptomatically and follow 
up with her hematologist/oncologist and infectious disease 
specialist as scheduled. 
.
# GVHD: continued Azathioprine, cyclosporine, prednisone. Her 
prednisone dose was increased to 40 mg during the week of 
admission. It was tapered down to 30 mg ___ at time of 
discharge. 
.
# History of Paecilomyces Pulmonary Infection: Patient's 
voriconazole was changed to posaconazole given concern that it 
may be contributing to elevated LFTs. 
.
# History of DVT: Patient on Coumadin. INR fluctuated likely in 
the setting of many medication changes. Patient was discharged 
with alternating doses of 5 mg and 2.5 mg ___. She has plans 
to have her INR checked on ___ at her PCP's office.  
.
# Hypertension: continued home dose Metoprolol, Captopril, and 
amlodipine
.
# History of Clostridium difficile colitis: continued oral 
Vancomycin at prophylactic dosing
.
# Infection Prophylaxis - Continued Bactrim and acyclovir
.

- no labs pending at time of discharge
- patient's INR will need close monitoring and Coumadin dose 
will likely need further adjustment 
- patient full code on this admission
