Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is ___ with accelerated CML s/p allo transplant 
___ complicated by GVHD, pneumonia, myositis, and DVTs who 
initially presented with fatigue, diarrhea, pancytopenia in the 
setting of Cellcept and Ponatinib therapy.

# Diarrhea: Patient presented with 4 weeks of watery diarrhea 
with ___ bowel movements daily and poor appetite. Symptoms were 
most likely secondary to cellcept toxcity or ponatinib toxicity. 
Colon biopsy results were consisted with shallow crypts that are 
typically seen with GVHD or cellcept toxicity. While GVHD is a 
possible etiolgy, chronic GVHD is much less likely to present 
with acute diarrhea. An extensive infectious work up including 
norovirus, CMV, cdiff, adenovirus, parvovirus, HHV6, and O&P 
were negative. Ms. ___ improved with decreased cellcept 
dosing. She was transitioned from 1000mg BID to ___ BID at 
time of discharge. She continues to have ___ loose bowel 
movements daily. However, she continues to trend in a positive 
direction at the time of discharge. She did require 2 weeks of 
TPN but is now tolerating a PO diet at the time of discharge.

# Pancytopenia: Pt was noted to have progressive pancytopenia on 
outpatient labs over weeks preceeding admission. Pancytopenia is 
thought to be secondary to ponatinib toxicity as all cell lines 
improved after holding drug. Ms. ___ has experienced 
pancytopenia on previous TKI treatments as well. She was also 
transitioned from bactrim to atovaquone for PCP ___. A 
bone morrow biopsy was hypocellular but without concern for 
recurrent CML. A Graft chimerism study notable for 100% donor. 
Pt did also have HSV oral lesion and there may have been a 
component of HSV marrow suppression as her counts also improved 
with acyclovir therapy. Ponatinib is held at the time of 
discharge.

# Nephrotic syndrome:  The patient presented with acute on 
chronic CKD with creatinine around 2 this admission. Her 
creatinine has been gradually uptrending over the last year. It 
was never worked up and thought to be secondary to TKI therapy. 
She was found to have 4+ proteinuria this admission with low 
serum albumin and elevated triglycerides. A  renal biopsy was 
notable for acute on chronic microangiopathic disease, 
glomerular sclerosing and fibrosis of kidney. Etiology of 
changes remains unclear but differential is broad including 
effects of TKI treatment. There was no hydro or obtruction on 
renal us. Complement levels were normal and no serum 
cyroglobins. She was started on losartan 100mg daily and 
lisinopril 5mg for proteinuria. Pt was also started on aggresive 
IV diuresis for anasarca with improvement in fluid status. She 
will be discharged on 40mg PO Lasix with goal of maintaining 
within 2kg of her discharge weight, which was 143.6 lbs. 
Creatinine was stable around 2 at time of discharge. 

#Dyspnea: Patient promoted dyspnea during admission but never 
developed hypoxia. Symptoms were initially thought to be 
secondary to pulmonary edema and did improve with initial 
diuresis. However, symptoms did not completely resolve. A CT 
Chest was notable for some scattered ground glass opacities and 
a 4 mm right upper lobe nodule. PFTS show mixed obstructive and 
restrictive physiology. Fungal work up unrevealing. Pulmonology 
recommended a course of azithromycin for atypical pneumonia with 
follow up CT scan in 1 month. Dyspnea continued to improve at 
time of discharge following course of azithromycin. She was also 
started on pulmonary prophylaxis with FAM: daily fluticasone, 
azithromycin 3x/wk, monteleukast every other day.

#R lower extremity pain: Pt noted to have partial DVT of right 
superficial femoral vein which is unchanged from prev study in 
___ and most likely represents remnent from previous distal 
DVT which were treated with 6 months of anticoagulation. 
Vascular surg evaluated vascular appearing lesion on right lower 
extreity and are uncertain regarding etiology. ___ be secondary 
to smaller superficial thrombi in smaller leg veins. Recommend 
continued warm compresses, compression,and elevation of leg. 
Further anticoagulation at prophylactic dosing should be 
discussed as an outpatient once platlets are stable.

# Seizure like activity: Pt has 3 episodes of right neck 
twitching and mental status changes on ___ which appeared 
seizure like to staff. There was no tongue biting or generalized 
activity. An MRI Head was normal and LP without concern for 
bacterial infection. Viral cultures were all negative from CSF. 
An EEG was notable for encephalopathy without epileptical 
discharges. Pt experienced no further concerning neurologic 
changes following ___.

# HSV:Pt promoted oral pain on admission and was found to have 
several ulcerative lesions. An oral swab of lesions was positive 
for HSV. Symptoms and ulcers improved on acyclovir. She will 
continue prophylactic dosing as an outpatient.

#CML: Ms. ___ is status ___ allogenic transplant in ___ 
with recurrent disease in late ___. Disease has currently been 
well controlled on ponatinib with BCR-ABL PCR .09. However,has 
now been discontinued as drug toxicity outweighing benefits of 
treatment. As noted above, repeat bone marrow bx this admission 
without concern for recurrent disease. Chimerism study showed 
100% donor.

# GVHD: Has had GI  and skin involvement in past in addition to 
myositis. Has been well controlled on current MMF and prednisone 
dosing. While there was initial concern for GVHD as etiology to 
current presentation, it is uncommon to have diarrhea with 
chronic GVHD. Cellcept and prednisone doses were decreased this 
admission. She will need to closely monitor with recent decrease 
in immunosuppresion. 

#HTN: Ms. ___ had poorly controlled hypertension this 
admission. Most likely related to pregressive kidney disease. 
She was started on losartan, which was uptitrated to 100mg with 
good BP control by discharge.

#Hypogammablobulinemia: Likely ___ nephrotic syndrome and 
protein wasting. At admission, IgG level was 82 and she received 
an IVIg transfusion at 0.4g/kg. On ___, she received a second 
IVIg transfusion at the same dose for an IGg level of 300. 
During the second transfusion, she had some mild upper back pain 
and chills, which resolved with slowing the infusion.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of ___ at ___. 
___ came in for several weeks of watery diarrhea which we 
believe is due to cellcept toxicity. We decreased your dose of 
cellcept with improvement of your symptoms. ___ were also found 
to have a condition called pancytopenia, which means low number 
of blood cells. We believe your CML medication ponatinib caused 
this and your blood counts improved when we discontinued this 
medication. 

___ were also found to have worsening kidney function this 
admission. The cause of your kidney problem is unclear but may 
also be due to the drug ponatinib. ___ were placed on losartan, 
which will help the kidney function better. ___ will continue to 
follow up with Dr. ___ as an outpatient.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o F with hx of accelerated phase CML s/p sibling allo D0 
___ presenting with diarrhea x 4 days and nausea/decreased 
PO intake w/ weight loss over the past 1 month.  

# CML
CML s/p sibling allo D0 ___ complicated by GVHD.  No longer 
on TKI given multiple side effects.  Previous chimerism and 
BCR-ABL gene rearrangement study shows no residual disease 
however repeat test showed increased level of BCR-ABL gene.  
Here mycophenylate was stoooped to increase graft versus. 
leukemia effect.  We continued her current prednisone regiemtn 
15mg alternating with 20mg.  Her acyclovir and atovaquone were 
continued. 

# Nausea/Weight Loss
History of 1 month of worsening nausea and decreased PO intake 
correlated with 5 pound weight loss.  Concern for upper GI GVHD 
given decrease in steroids and nausea.  EGD and flex sig 
negative for signs of GVHD.  Her gastric empyting study was 
inconclusive.  Her symptoms improved with zyprexa and zofran.  
She was able to tolerate a diet at time of discharge and her 
symptoms were well-controlled.
 
# Sinus Congestion
Concern for sinus infection given symptoms and immunocompromised 
state.  CT sinus shows mucosal thickening w/o bone involvement.  
She was started on levofloxacin for a total of 14 days of 
treatment.  Her symptoms were imporved with afrin, flonase, and 
saline irrigation.  She will follow-up in ___ clinic in 1 month.

# Diarrhea
Presents with diarrhea x4 days and overnight had more non-bloody 
watery diearrhea.  Most likely secondary to viral or bacterial 
gastroenteritis.  However could be due to GVHD and recent 
decrease in prednisone dosing. Also could be medication side 
effects from mycophenylate.  On previous admission, had diarrhea 
and her mycophenylate dose was decreasd with improvement in his 
symptoms.  Her TKI was also disconinued during this admission.  
Diarrhea has been improving and flex sig was without signs of 
GVHD.  Stool studies were negative for infection.  On discharge 
her diarrhea had resolved.
 
# Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis 
Elevated bicarb w/ hypercholemia most likely due to combination 
of chronic kidney diease, diarrhea, and NS fluids.  We started 
oral bicarb replacement and her serum bicarb level normalized at 
time of discharge.

# Acute on Chronic Renal Failure
Elevated Cr to 2.6 from baseline 1.9-2.3 likely pre-renal 
etiology secondary to diarrhea and poor PO intake.  Also could 
possibly be due to renal GVHD.  Improved with fluids to 1.8.

# HTN
Her lasix, losartan, metoprolol, and amlodipine were continued.

# CAD
We continued here ASA 81.

IMAGING
-------
TTE ___
IMPRESSION: Hyperdynamic left ventricular systolic function. No 
clinically significant valvular regurgitation or stenosis. 
Indeterminate pulmonary artery systolic pressure. Suggestion of 
pulmonary artery diastolic hypertension.  Compared with the 
prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the left ventricular 
systolic function is now hyperdynamic (LVEF previously 55-60%). 

Pharmacological Stress MIBI ___
INTERPRETATION: Left ventricular cavity size is normal.  Rest 
and stress perfusion images reveal uniform tracer uptake 
throughout the left ventricular myocardium.  Gated images reveal 
normal wall motion. Septal wall motion compatible with prior 
CABG.  The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 65% 
post stress.
IMPRESSION: Normal myocardial perfusion study.

CT Abdomen/Pelvis ___
IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of PTLD.  
2. Soft tissue nodules in the left lower quadrant most likely 
represent the sequela of subcutaneous injections.

CT Chest ___
IMPRESSION:
1. As compared to ___, no lung nodules have newly 
appeared.  The
pre-existing lung nodules, including the minimal ground-glass 
nodules in the upper lobe, are all constant, unsuspicious in 
morphology.  If the patient is not at high risk for cancer, the 
lesions do not require further followup, given that their 
dimension is below 4 mm.
2.  Status post CABG, no lymphadenopathy, no pleural effusions.

CXR ___
ET tube is in a standard position.  NG tube tip is out of view 
below the 
diaphragm.  Cardiomegaly is stable.  Increasing opacities in the 
right 
perihilar region and right lower lobe are worrisome for 
worsening pneumonia.  Component of pulmonary edema is stable.  
Left lower lobe pneumonia is stable.  There is no pneumothorax 
or large pleural effusion.  There are low lung volumes with 
stable widened mediastinum  due to engorgement of vessels. 

CXR ___:
The patient is currently not intubated.  The right internal 
jugular line tip is at the right atrium and should be pulled 
back approximately 3 cm.  Heart size and mediastinum are stable. 
 Lungs are essentially clear.  No pleural effusion or 
pneumothorax is appreciated, although cannot be entirely 
excluded. 

Muscle Biopsy ___:  Final Report Pending

CT Chest Without Contrast ___:  Newly appeared massive 
bilateral opacities, predominantly ground-glass in attenuation, 
with subtle areas of consolidation.  Accompanying airways 
disease and small pleural effusions with atelectasis. 

EMG ___:  Abnormal study. There is electrophysiologic 
evidence for a moderate, generalized myopathic process with 
denervating features. In addition, the data are suggestive of a 
moderate, generalized, axonal, sensorimotor polyneuropathy. 
Based on the limited repetitive stimulation studies performed, 
there is no evidence for a disorder of neuromuscular junction 
transmission, including myasthenia ___. Compared to the 
previous study dated ___, there has been an improvement 
in motor response amplitudes and worsening in sensory response 
amplitudes.  

 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE:  

Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o F with history of accelerated phase CML 
s/p sibling allo transplant on ___ complicated by upper and 
lower GI GVHD ___, liver GVHD in setting of reducing 
immunosuppression ___, GVHD related myopathy resulting in 
weakness and respiratory failure ___ who presented for 
presyncope. Her lightheadedness improved significantly with IV 
fluids and she had no further episodes of presyncope. She had 
elevated creatinine above baseline that resolved with IV fluids. 
She was found to have an elevated troponin that trended down 
thought to be likely due to demand ischemia in the setting of 
anemia in addition to poor clearance in the setting of acute on 
chronic kidney injury. Her BCR-ABL load was elevated compared to 
prior levels and her prednisone immunosuppression was decreased 
to improve control of her CML. She was also found to have an 
elevated EBV viral load with concern for PTLD/lymphoma and had a 
CT Torso which showed no evidence of PTLD. She received 1 dose 
of rituximab on ___ and tolerated well.

On reduction of the pt.'s prednisone, she developed severe 
myalgias and respiratory distress thought to be ___ muscle 
weakness, hypervolemia, and flash pulmonary edema with BPs in 
220s/110s. She was transferred to the ICU, required intubation, 
and was diuresed.  She was extubated and her respiratory status 
returned to baseline. She was found to have both a new 
consolidation on CXR evaluated by both the pulmonary service and 
infectious disease service who both recommended a course of 
antibiosis for HCAP. She also had an elevated troponin during 
this episode. Cardiology evaluated pt and determined her to have 
an NSTEMI in the setting of elevated troponin and new focal wall 
motion abnormality on echocardiogram. She continued to have 
myalgias and had a muscle biopsy and EMG to better assess the 
cause of her myalgias. ___ results indicate no signs of 
active GVHD or GVHD myasthenia ___. Final results are 
pending. She remained hemodynamically stable and was discharged 
to rehab on her admission dose of prednisone.
 
ACTIVE ISSUES

# Acute Myalgias and Muscle Weakness:  On admission, pt. reports 
diffuse muscle weakness and myalgias.  Following reduction of 
prednisone from alternating 15mg/20mg daily, pt. had significant 
worsening of symptoms.  CK was mildly elevated.  For concern of 
worsening symptoms ___ to ongoing levofloxacin (has been 
associated with increased risk of tenosynovitis in pt.'s on 
chronic steroids), this medication was discontinued.  An EMG was 
done showing no evidence of GVHD induced myasthenia ___.  
___ muscle biopsy performed on ___ of the left biceps 
femoris biopsy returned negative for any evidence of 
inflammation.  The most likely etiology of the patient's 
symptoms were thought to be ___ profound deconditioning with a 
possible component of steroid induced myopathic fibroatrophy 
given ongoing steroids over the last ___ years.  GVHD less likely 
given no evidence of myositis on ___ path, although pt.'s 
physical exam is somewhat consistent with chronic GVHD. 

# Respiratory Failure:  Following reduction of patient's 
steroids, pt. developed profound muscle weakness.  In this 
setting, she became hypoxic and later hypertensive with BPs in 
220s/110s.  She had a presumed episode of flash pulmonary edema 
which resulted in her transfer to the ICU and subsequent 
intubation.  Pt. was diuresed significantly and extubated 
without issue.  She was thought to be volume overloaded 
secondary to initial resuscitation following her pre-syncopal 
presentation.  Pt. continued to respond well to diuresis and was 
transferred back to the medical floor.

# Hospital Acquired Pneumonia:  Pt. had a new consolidation on 
CXR on this admission.  Started on HCAP coverage with 
vanc/meropenem.  The patient initially responded well and was 
d/c'ed off vanc.  Given concern for worsening pneumonia and 
respiratory distress, pulmonary was consulted for possible 
bronchoscopy.  ___ then recommended cardiology evaluation given 
ongoing elevated troponin and question of ischemic changes seen 
on TTE and EKG.  ID also saw pt. and recommended continuation of 
levofloxacin for total of 5 day course for atypical coverage and 
meropenem for total of 8 day course.  For concern that 
levofloxacin was contributing to pt.'s myalgias/ tendonitis, pt. 
was discontinued 1 day earlier than completion of full course.  
At time of discharge, pt. had ongoing improving cough.  She had 
a repeat CXR (___) negative for consolidation or pulmonary 
edema.  

# NSTEMI:  In the setting of episode of flash pulmonary edema, 
pt. had an elevated troponin.  Cardiology evaluated the patient 
who recommended a repeat TTE which revealed showed decrease in 
EF to 40% and akinesis of the anteroseptal wall.  Given her 
known CAD, this was thought to most likely be related to either 
a type 1 primary coronary event or type 2 demand ischemia in the 
setting of recent hypertensive emergency and flash pulmonary 
edema.  Given that pt. was a poor cath candidate with ongoing 
acute on chronic kidney injury, will proceed with medical 
optimization at this time.  As such, pt. was discharged on ASA 
81mg Daily, metoprolol and amlodipine for afterload reduction.  
A statin was held at this time given ongoing myalgias.  Her 
losartan was held for resolving acute on chronic kidney injury.  


# Admission Troponin elevation:  Pt. had admission Troponin peak 
at 1.07, CK-MB 11. Patient did not have chest pain at this time, 
but did report dizziness and dyspnea which may be her anginal 
equivalent. ECG on admission was not suggestive of ischemia.  
Pt. evaluated for ACS but noted to have downtrending trops in 
setting of resolving anemia and resolving acute on chronic 
kidney injury.  Initial TTE showed hyperdynamic function 
consistent with her volume depleted status.  In the setting of 
known CAD, pt. also had a persantine stress MIBI which was 
negative for evidence of malperfusion/ischemia.  Likely cause of 
admission troponin elevation was thought to be due to demand 
ischemia in the setting of anemia in addition to poor clearance 
in the setting of acute on chronic kidney injury.  

# Poor appetite:  Patient not taking good PO at home. Signs of 
anasarca on exam with diffuse dependent edema.  Pt. states that 
she is eating more on this hospitalization compared to any other 
time recently.  Denies nausea/vomiting, abdominal symptoms, 
diarrhea.  Pt. was started on marinol for appetite stimulation 
but developed excess sedation.  This medication was 
discontinued. 

# Anemia:  On admission, pt. found to have Hct drop from 27 to 
19.  She received fluids in clinic of unknown quantity.  No 
history of bleeding.  Anemia work-up was negative for hemolysis 
with normal TSH level.  Pt. did have a retic count which was low 
given the level of anemia consistent with decreased production 
likely ___ pt's CML.  Her Hct remained stable after initial 
transfusion throughout the remainder of admission.

# Presyncope/lightheadedness:  Pt. presented with orthostatic 
hypotension in the setting of poor PO intake and ongoing 
antihypertensive/diuretic therapy making hypovolemia the most 
likely etiology. Given troponin elevation, considered cardiac 
etiology however stress MIBI negative.  Her lightheadedness 
resolved after giving IV fluids.  Her home furosemide and 
amlodipine were discontinued.  The patient was discharged on a 
reduced hypertensive regimen as described in transitional 
issues. 

# Acute on chronic kidney injury:  On admission, pt. was found 
to have creatinine elevated to 2.6 from baseline of 1.5 to 2.0.  
Likely pre-renal given hypovolemia with orthostasis.  She 
received IV fluids and her creatinine returned to baseline.  Pt. 
then had second episode of acute on chronic kidney injury ___ 
poor forward flow in the setting of flash pulmonary edema and 
NSTEMI.  Her renal function returned to baseline with diuresis.  
She was noted to have an elevated uric acid at this time which 
dramatically decreased following one dose of rasburicase. 

# CML
Accelerated phase CML s/p sibling allo D0 ___ now relapsed 
CML.  BCR-ABL returned slightly elevated compared to prior.  We 
continued prophylaxis on home acyclovir, atovaquone, fluconazole 
at renal dosing.  Her prednisone was attempted to be reduced to 
15mg daily to improve control of CML with evidence of increasing 
BCR-ABL.  The pt. did not tolerate this as above.  She has a 
repeat BCR ABL and kinase domain mutation pending.  TKI should 
be considered as an outpatient.

# Elevated EBV Viral Load
EBV was elevated on last admission and more elevated on this 
admission.  HHV6/Parvo B19 negative.  For concern of 
PTLD/lymphoma, pt. was evaluated with CT Torso which showed no 
evidence of PTLD.  Pt. given 1 dose of rituximab on ___ and 
tolerated it well.  

# Sinusitis 
Pt. received course of levofloxacin with resolution of symptoms.

Dear Ms. ___,

elevated both on admission and during your hospitalization.  The 
ultrasound of your heart initially was normal as well as a

currently pending.  Your condition improved and you were 
discharged with close follow-up.

All the best,

Dear Ms. ___,

You presented to us with laboratory abnormalities most likely

to your kidneys. You are being discharged on new medications,

lowered your steroid dosage gradually and stopped at prednisone

The right central venous line tip is at the cavoatrial

___ TTE
The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild 
to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
near-akinesis of the septum, and hypokinesis of the basal-mid 
anterior wall. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left 
ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. The mitral valve 
leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is 
seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The 
estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is 
no pericardial effusion. There is an anterior space which most 
likely represents a prominent fat pad. 

IMPRESSION: Regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction 
consistent with LAD ischemia/infarction. Mild mitral 
regurgitation. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___ and

similar (septal function was described as mildly hypokinetic on 
the most recent study but it was severely hypokinetic then 
also). The function of the mid to distal inferior wall has 
improved. Mild mitral regurgitation is seen.  

PATHOLOGY:
___ IMMUNOPHENOTYPING
Increased number of blasts. In a context of patient's known CML, 
this is concerning for acute blast crisis.  Correlation with 
clinical findings and morphology (see separate report 
___ is recommended.  Flow cytometry immunophenotyping 
may not detect all abnormal populations due to topography, 
sampling or artifacts of sample preparation

___ Bone marrow bx
 Chronic Myelogeneous leukemia - Blast phase (CML-BP), see note.
Note: This represents acute myelegenous transformation of the 
patient's
previously diagnosed CML; ie., CML-BP. CD34 and CD117 are 
increased and
highlight blasts occupying estimated 70-80% of the overall 
cellularity.
 CD20 highlights rare B cells.  CD3 stains interstitial T 
lymphocytes.
CD42 is present in the megakaryocytes, which do not appear 
increased.
TdT is negative.  MP0 is not expressed in blasts.  Glycophorin
highlights erythroid precursors, but is negative in the blasts.

___ Skin bx
PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS:

Skin, left mid back; punch biopsy:

 - Mild spongiosis with dyskeratosis, patchy interface 
inflammation and
focal intra-epidermal eosinophils,  with superficial 
perivascular
mononuclear cell infiltrate and dermal eosinophils (see 
comment).
 - No fungal organisms identified on a PAS stain.
 - Multiple tissue levels examined.

Comment:  The histologic differential diagnosis includes both a
hypersensitivity reaction and graft versus host disease. The 
presence
of eosinophils is compatible with the clinical suspicion of a 
drug
eruption, although they do not exclude graft versus host 
disease.
Clinical correlation is recommended.

 

 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with CML s/p sibling allo D0 ___, complicated by chronic 
GVHD with gut, liver, muscle involvement presenting from ___ 
clinic with hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, hypercalcemia, ___ on 
CKD and pancytopenia, now with conversion to AML.
 
#CML/AML: BCR/ABL trended up from 0 to 2 to 5 to 104 to 162. 
Presented with hyperuricemia and pancytopenia likely due to 
conversion to AML and rapid cell turn over. No evidence of 
bleeding. Hemolysis unlikely with normal coag studies and Tbili. 
 Retic count 1.8 with retic index 0.88% showed poor red cell 
production. CMV/EBV/HHV6 negative. BM bx shows conversion to AML 
with as much as 65% blasts on smear with absolute blast count as 
high as 1200 and 0% neutrophils. Treated with 12 days of 
nilotinib with no improvement. Given continued decline and poor 
prognosis, transitioned to comfort measures only after which she 
expired. 

#Cough/HCAP: Patient had intermittently productive cough for ___ 
weeks with negative workup on last admission including CXR, CT 
Chest, V/Q scan, rapid resp viral panel. Clear lung exam, 
negative CXR at rehab prior to admission. RRV panel and cx, 
beta-glucan, galactomannan negative. BNP >40K so volume overload 
potentially played a partial role especially given LVEF 40-45% 
on TTE. PE unlikely as patient not hypoxic, no evidence of right 
heart strain on EKG, no evidence of infarct on CT Chest; 
regardless, anticoagulation held in setting of thrombocytopenia 
and no hemodynamic compromise. CT showed ?infectious process, in 
the setting of worsening cough/resp status portable CXR showed 
likely LLL PNA. On ___ patient met ___ SIRS criteria 
(tachycardic, tachypneic, low WBC) so cx drawn and started on 
empiric vanc/meropenem. Received benzonatate, codeine, 
guaifenesin-dextromethorphan as well as levalbuterol/ipratropium 
nebs prn for symptomatic relief. With continued worsening 
respiratory status patient started on morphine for SOB O2 
supplementation prn. Given prognosis, she was transitioned to 
comfort measures only with withdrawal of abx, scopalamine patch, 
and morphine gtt, on which she expired. 

#Hypercalcemia: Baseline high 8s-9s, on admission 10.7. Unclear 
etiology, given elevated alk phos in the setting of CKD could 
have increased bony release of calcium though increased bone 
turnover would likely cause a higher phosphate level. PTH 6 
which rules out hyperparathyroidism and makes hypercalcemia in 
the setting of worsening CML more likely especially with Vit D 
wnl but PTHrP elevated. Received IVF, furosemide, ___ dose 
pamidronate ___ and calcitonin ___ while calcium 
carbonate/Vit D held and calcium downtrended to 8.4.

#UTI: Found to have citrobacter/klebsiella UTI on culture taken 
after patient began to appear septic with ___ SIRS signs. 
Infection was covered by meropenem rx'ed for putative PNA. Foley 
catheter was left in place for comfort and abx discontinued when 
patient transitioned to comfort measures only. 

#CHF: Patient has known CHF likely of ischemic nature given CAD, 
found to have persistent LVEF 40-45% on TTE ___. Increased 
volume with IVF for hypercalcemia tx led to increasing dyspnea 
treated with oxygen supplementation, which improved after 
diuresis and PNA tx as above. At this point, IVF held as calcium 
dropped and for comfort reasons. 
 
#DVT in LLE: Left superficial femoral vein DVT found on last 
admission, discharged on SQ heparin for tx. Previously presented 
with acute worsening of LLE edema but now reduced compared to 
prior admission. LLE U/S shows unchanged partially occlusive 
clot of proximal superficial femoral vein. Anticoagulation held 
given thrombocytopenia, IVC filter placement held given 
stability of clot and goals of care. 

#Hyperuricemia: Uric acid on presentation 9.5. Pt treated on 
last admission with rasburicase and started on allopurinol and 
febuxostat. Discharged with uric acid 8.7. Febuxostat held on 
this admission due to drug rash. Elevated uric acid possibly due 
to worsening renal function in the setting of hypovolemia but 
given rising BCR-ABL and known CML->AML progression likely due 
to rapid cell turnover. Elevated uric acid unlikely to be 
contributing to poor kidney function given no urate crystals on 
urine sediment. Treated with rasburicase x1, uric acid dropped 
to but rose to 9.6 over several days. Allopurinol discontinued 
after patient transitioned to comfort measures only. 

#CKD: Baseline Cr 1.5-2.0 due to thrombotic microangiopathic 
injury with severe interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy 
possibly related to TKI shown on renal biopsy ___. Cr 2.2 on 
last discharge, presented with Cr 2.9. Most likely prerenal in 
the setting of poor po intake and hypovolemia; elevated uric 
acid unlikely to be causing renal damage after improvement with 
fluids and no urate crystals. Cr worsened to 2.5 after several 
doses of IV lasix. Urine output decreased ___. Further 
diuresis held, no further IVF or intervention to improve kidney 
function after transition to comfort care only. 

#GVHD: Known skin, gut, liver, muscle involvement. Aldolase 
mildly elevated consistent with known muscle disease but 
improved from ___. Rash likely drug related over acute GVHD 
per derm bx. Continued on prednisone 10mg then transitioned to 
4mg IV solumedrol BID given inability to tolerate PO prior to 
discontinuation of steroids given goals of care. 

#CAD s/p CABG: History of ?NSTEMI in past, ___ TTE with 
preserved EF 55%. ASA held due to thrombocytopenia. 

#Nutrition: Patient's weight has fallen from 141 to 127 lbs 
since ___, likely ___ poor PO intake. Copper level wnl, 
B6 low. Supplemented with ensure while taking PO prior to 
transition to comfort care.  

#Hypertension: 
-Stable on metoprolol and amlodipine until transition to comfort 
care at which point both rx dc'ed. 

Patient sadly died overnight ___ with her family

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of chronic 
anxiety and dysthymia who is brought to the emergency department 
by EMS due to worsening symptoms of depression, irritability, 
and expressed suicidal ideation. 
  
  
1. LEGAL & SAFETY:  
On admission, the patient signed a conditional voluntary 
agreement (Section 10 & 11) and remained on that level 
throughout their admission. She was also placed on 15 minute 
checks status on admission and remained on that level of 
observation throughout while being unit restricted.
  
  
2. PSYCHIATRIC
#Major Depressive Disorder 
At the time of presentation, the patient had difficulty fully 
describing her current mood state, almost to the point of 
alexithymia. She did endorse recent fatigue, poor sleep, poor 
appetite, anhedonia, decreased motivation, diminished 
concentration, and passive suicidal thoughts. While she denied 
suicidal plan or intent, she did note that she had recently felt 
worried that she may lose control and do something unsafe. 
Collateral from her boyfriend, in addition to patient's 
appraisal of her own functioning, was concerning for recent 
deterioration and heightened irritability and depressed mood. On 
initial exam, she had a restricted affect and made minimal eye 
contact with interviewers. 
  
Her presentation appeared most consistent with major depressive 
disorder, but there was additionally an element of 
trauma-related symptoms contributing to her presentation. 
Patient has a history of sexual assault and also described 
arguments with boyfriend evoking memories from childhood when 
she observed her mother/stepfather arguing. 

She reported previous medication trials of fluoxetine, 
citalopram, and duloxetine which were discontinued either due to 
ineffectiveness or side effects. She was started on Wellbutrin 
XR 150mg daily and Hydroxyzine 25mg BID:PRN anxiety/insomnia. 
She reported feeling jittery, anxious, with racing heart on 
Wellbutrin XR 150mg so was transitioned to Wellbutrin SR 100mg. 
She tolerated this well with no reported side effects. Over the 
course of her admission, she engaged in treatment, including 
individual therapy as well as groups focused on coping. She 
reported improvement in her mood and energy level. She denied 
any suicidal ideation, reporting that she was no longer in a 
dark place. She had a less constricted affect and was brighter 
and more reactive. At the time of discharge, she was 
future-oriented, looking forward to getting back to work. 
  
  
3. MEDICAL
#Chronic pelvic pain: Patient reported intermittent right-sided 
pelvic pain exacerbated by urination, bowel movements, and 
intercourse. She denied heavy or irregular menstrual bleeding 
and stated that she usually does not take anything for the pain, 
as ibuprofen and Tylenol have never seemed to help. Patient has 
had discussions about endometriosis with doctors in the past but 
has never been definitively diagnosed. She reports that her 
symptoms are currently at baseline and tolerable. She declined 
offer for PRN pain medication during this admission.
  
  
4. SUBSTANCE USE: Patient reported intermittent marijuana use.  
She was provided with counseling regarding marijuana use and 
possible negative impact substance use has on her anxiety/mood. 
  
  
5. PSYCHOSOCIAL
#) GROUPS/MILIEU:  
The patient was encouraged to participate in the various groups 
and milieu therapy opportunities offered by the unit.  The 
patient often attended these groups that focused on teaching 
patients various coping skills.  She was also noted to be social 
with her peers in the milieu and pleasant with staff members. 
  
#) COLLATERAL CONTACTS & FAMILY INVOLVEMENT:
Patient provided verbal permission to contact her outpatient 
therapist ___ ___ and her 
outpatient PCP (Dr. ___ ___. Providers were 
contacted for collateral information and for discharge planning. 
Patient also gave verbal permission to contact her boyfriend  
___ who provided the primary team with 
collateral information.
  

INFORMED CONSENT: The team discussed the indications for, 
intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of 
starting Wellbutrin and Hydroxyzine, and risks and benefits of 
possible alternatives, including not taking the medications, 
with this patient.   We discussed the patient's right to decide 
whether to take this medication as well as the importance of the 
patient's actively participating in the treatment and discussing 
any  questions about medications with the treatment team, and I  
answered the patient's questions.  The patient appeared able to 
understand and consented to begin the medication.
  
  
RISK ASSESSMENT
On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an 
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon 
worsening functioning with passive suicidal ideation, fears of 
losing control and doing something unsafe.  Her static factors 
noted at that time include history of trauma and abuse, chronic 
mental illness, chronic pain (fibromyalgia, myofascial pain 
syndrome, chronic pelvic pain) .  The modifiable risk factors, 
which included lack of outpatient treaters, passive suicidal 
ideation, acute mood episode, and medication noncompliance 
(history of discontinuing several antidepressants due to side 
effects) were also addressed at that time.  The patient engaged 
in individual and group therapy focusing on coping skills during 
her admission; she was also started on Wellbutrin which she 
tolerated well and outpatient follow up was scheduled.  Finally, 
the patient is being discharged with many protective factors, 
including future-oriented thinking, willingness to seek help, 
and sense of responsibility to family.  Overall, based on the 
totality of our assessment at this time, the patient is not at 
an acutely elevated risk of self-harm nor danger to others.

Brief Hospital Course:
# R sided numbness and urinary complaints
- Ms. ___ was admitted to neurology.  Metabolic, infectious and 
toxic evaluation did not reveal any significant abnormalities.  
Her neurologic exam showed sensory changes in the right trunk 
and leg, but there was also functional overlay on admission.  
She underwent Brain and C-spine MRI which revealed evidence of 
lesions suggestive of a demyelinating disease, including 2 
active, enhancing lesions at c6-7 and t10-11.  Her sensory 
changes are more likely to be explained by the T10-11 lesion, 
although not completely. Overall, her findings are suggestive of 
an acute flare of a new Multiple Sclerosis diagnosis.  She 
underwent Lumbar puncture in ___ (after unsuccessful attempt on 
floor), which revealed mild WBC elevation of 6 and 10, but was 
otherwise benign.  

She was felt to have likely Multiple sclerosis and was started 
on high dose steroids: Methylprednisone 1g x5 days.  Though she 
continued to have sensory symptoms, she was otherwise doing 
well, ambulatory and felt to be safe for discharge.

Outpatient appointment arranged with Dr. ___ outpatient 
MS management.  Notably, on the day of discharge, ___ CSF 
cultures was growing a single colony of gram positive Cocci.  
This was felt to be a contaminant as neither her clinical 
picture, symptoms or other objective labs support an infectious 
meningeal process.  However, Ms. ___ was informed of this 
Positive CSF culture prior to discharge and was counseled by the 
provider for concerning symptoms including headache, confusion 
or neck stiffness.

# Psychiatry
- Ms. ___ has an extensive history of anxiety and depression.  
While in the hospital, she demonstrated this significantly and 
was very stressed about the entire hospitalization.  She 
endorsed poor social support.  Given clinical concern, she 
briefly had a 1:1 sitter, though she never endorsed SI.  
However, this was discontinued after being evaluated by 
psychiatry.  She was started on Citalopram 20mg PO QD during 
this admission.  Her outpatient PCP ___ was 
contacted and agreed to manage her Citalopram.  She agreed to 
continue to see her psychotherapist on an outpt basis.

Discharge Instructions:
You were hospitalized with 1 week of right sided sensory change 
and urinary incontinence.  While in the hospital, you were on 
the neurology service.  To further clarify your symptoms, you 
underwent an MRI of the Brain and the upper spine which revealed 
evidence of "Demyelinating disease", most likely multiple 
sclerosis.  Based on the MRI image, there was evidence of an 
"acute flare" causing your symptoms as well as evidence of 
older, more chronic lesions.

You then underwent a Lumbar Puncture (spinal tap) for evaluation 
of the protein in your spinal fluid.  This labwork was still

Brief Hospital Course:
Global Assessment:
___ years old female with self reported depression, anxiety, 
multiple prior psychiatric hospitalizations and 1 prior SA, also 
with PMH of multiple sclerosis, L sensorineural hearing loss, 
migraine headaches, and HTN presenting with several 
neurovegetative sx of depression and SI in the setting of 
financial and psychosocial stressors. Etiology of presenting sx 
was unclear as clinical picture was complicated by patient's 
affective lability, hypervigilence, and preoccupation with 
injustice/persecution. Ddx was initially broad, but the pt did 
very well during her stay and appeared to suffer from complex 
PTSD w/ co-morbid depression and personality d/o traits.

#. Complex PTSD / Depression / Personality d/o traits: 
On admission, she reported sx of depression and anxiety, was 
passively suicidal and very irritable, with affective lability 
and demonstrated pervasive distrust and preoccupation with 
injustice and feelings of persecution. This persistent during 
first couple of days of hospitalization, but seemed to improve 
some after team started antidepressant medication and helped to 
address some psychosocial stressors. Patient was medication 
compliant, though complained Celexa caused sedation and this 
medication was subsequently administered at night. Patient began 
attending groups and found them helpful, but on multiple 
occasions felt violated or provoked by staff and become very 
upset, perseverative and difficult to console. 

Overwhelmingly, her initial sx of irritability/lability subsided 
and so did her paranoia.  She was able to make good 
relationships on the unit w/ others and was very positive w/ 
staff and primary team.

Safety: Patient remained in good behavioral control  throughout 
this hospitalization, except for outbursts in response to 
feeling persecuted or violated by staff, but she did not require 
physical or chemical restraint. The patient remained on 15 
minute checks, which is our lowest acuity level of checks.

GENERAL MEDICAL CONDITIONS
# Multiple sclerosis: Reports neurologic sx including imbalance 
and ___ numbness/tingling. Symptoms were monitored and no new or 
acute exacerbation of symptoms occurred on the unit. Patient has 
f/u appointment with Dr. ___ neurology on ___. 

# HTN: BP remained wnl. We continued pt's home Amlodipine.

# Back spasm/pain: pt reported using Baclofen in the past but 
prefer nonpharmacologic measures this hospitalization. She was 
given pen Ibuprofen for pain.

PSYCHOSOCIAL
#) MILIEU/GROUPS
Ms. ___ was initially reluctant to participate in groups.  As 
time went on, however, she attended many social groups and was 
quite visible in the dayroom. She especially liked the music and 
meditation groups.  
She never engaged in any unsafe behaviors. The pt ate all meals  
in the milieu, had some trouble sleeping though this improved 
with celexa at night. She had occasional angry outbursts when 
felt provoked, but was largely cooperative with unit rules.

#) FAMILY CONTACTS
None - pt refused despite our repeated recommendations to 
involve someone from the outside in her hospital course

#) COLLATERAL
Spoke with patient's therapist at ___ - she viewed the 
pt as having depression and PTSD.  Had been recommending psych 
f/u and mood stabilizer for some time.  We discussed this w/ the 
pt who was adamantly opposed to any medication other than an 
SSRI and also refused f/u with psychiatry; preferring to keep 
her care w/ her PCP and therapist.

LEGAL STATUS
The pt signed in on CV

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the 
manufacturer of this prosthesis

-ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
doctor.

-over the next several days you may experience some increased 
swelling of your phallus (and scrotum) resembling a semi-rigid 
phallus (semi-erect); this is "normal" from the prosthesis and 
related surgery/edema. This may be accompanied by discoloration 
(ecchymosis) involving the phallus and the scrotum; this too is 
normal and will gradually resolve.

-Please remove the surgical dressing over penis and/or under 
scrotum on post-operative day two: no further wound care is 
needed and you may leave the wound open to air. 

-Please keep your phallus at midline, pointed toward your 
umbilicus, taped in place with protective gauze/pads (if 
necessary) for the next ___ days. Of course you may point it 
downward for voiding.

-Use a jock-supporter/strap or jockey-type briefs or tight, 
tighty-whities to facilitate this; Subsequently you may 
transition to loose fitting briefs or boxer-briefs for 
support--they should be cotton and/or breathable.

-Do NOT use prosthesis for 6 weeks and until explicitly advised 
by your urologist

-Complete a 7 day course of antibiotics as directed 
(Ciprofloxacin/Cephalexin)

-You may shower, but do NOT bathe, swim or otherwise immerse 
your incision.

-Do NOT lift anything heavier than a phone book and no sports, 
vigorous physical activity (including sexual).

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. Max daily Tylenol 
dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol (acetaminophen)

-Do NOT drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do NOT 
operate dangerous machinery. 
For your safety, please do NOT DRIVE FOR ONE WEEK AFTER SURGERY 
or unless otherwise advised. 

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool "softener"- it is NOT a laxative

-Resume your home medications, EXCEPT HOLD NSAIDs (aspirin, and 
ibuprofen containing products such as Advil & Motrin, Excedrin) 
for ONE week or until you see your urologist in follow-up OR you 
are explicitly advised to resume sooner by your PCP, ___ 
or Cardiologist.  DO NOT RESUME medications like VIAGRA, LEVITRA 
or CIALIS.

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ after falling at the nursing home, 
when you arrived in the emergency room, multiple radiology 
studies were done, which showed that you did have any bleeding 
your head or any other broken bones.  However, since you were 
still complaining of neck pain, even though the CT scan of the 
bones in your neck was normal, they were unable to remove the 
cervical collar.  Since no one had seen you fall, we were 
concerned about caused the fall, as a result we also did an 
echocardiogram to look at the function of your heart and 
monitored the rhythm of your heart while you were in the 
hospital.  The only concerning finding during your 
hospitalization was that when we restarted your atenolol, your 
heart rate decreased into the 30's while you were sleeping, and 
only increased into the 40's when you were awake, as a result we 
stopped this medication since we were concerned that this could 
have contributed to your fall.   

Please call your doctor or return to the hospital if you have 
any other falls, experience a change in your vision, headaches, 
chest pain, palpitations or any other concerning symptoms.

Studies:
.
CT Abd - IMPRESSION: 1. Unchanged moderate intra- and 
extrahepatic biliary dilation with smooth tapering of the 
hepatic duct below the insertion of the cystic duct. Gallbladder 
distension is likely related to the ductal process rather than 
acute cholecystitis given the lack of wall thickening or 
pericholecystic fluid but clinical correlation is advised. 2. 
Possible 12-mm hypodensity in the head of the pancreas which is 
most likely focal fat deposition and is unchanged from the prior 
study. A mass cannot be entirely excluded and MRCP could be 
obtained if clinically relevant. 3. No findings to explain a 
sterile pyuria. 4. Colonic diverticulosis without evidence of 
acute diverticulitis. 5. Marked degenerative changes of the 
thoracolumbar ___ with further cortical destruction of the T9 
vertebral body. 
.
MR ___ - 1. Findings involving the T9 vertebral body, as on 
the prompting CT, likely represent a relatively acute 
osteoporotic compression fracture with very prominent fracture 
cleft. 2. While there is no significant loss of height, there is 
some retropulsion of its dorsal cortex with possible impingement 
upon the exiting right T9 nerve root. 3. Associated abnormality 
of, particularly, the right anterolateral paraspinal soft 
tissues at this level, with an overall appearance most 
suggestive of associated hemorrhage/granulation tissue, with no 
finding to specifically suggest a neoplastic process. 4. Bone 
marrow signal abnormalities involving the contiguous T10 
vertebral body, supporting underlying osteoporotic nature of 
this process, related to axial- loading injury. 5. Several 
chronic thoracolumbar vertebral wedge deformities with 
retropulsion, as detailed; in particular, there is significant 
spinal canal narrowing at the T12-L1 level, with deformity of 
the distal spinal cord but no discrete signal abnormality. 6. No 
other pathologic focus of enhancement seen to specifically 
suggest neoplastic disease. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female past medical history of dementia, 
hypothyroid, hip replacement presenting from outside hospital 
with concern for new T9/T10 fracture status post fall who 
developed fevers in the ED.  
.  
#. Mechanical Fall: Initially there was concern for T9/T10 
Fracture at ___. The pt was transfered to ___ for 
orthopedics ___ eval who determined that the fracture was not 
acute. They recommended a TLSO for comfort only. Due to concern 
for possible malignancy, the patient underwent MRI scan of the 
___ on ___ which showed a relatively acute osteoporotic 
compression fracture with very 
prominent fracture cleft but no evidence of neoplastic disease. 
The patient was in a significant amount of back pain initially 
and received a combination of opiates, toradol, standing tylenol 
and lidocaine patch. In discussion with the patient's nursing 
facility it was determined that this pain was not much changed 
from the patient's baseline and that at the nursing facility the 
patient receives oxycontin 30mg BID. The patient was placed on 
this regimen with good improvement in pain although continues to 
have difficulty with turns/sitting/deep breahing. The TLSO brace 
was not yet ready at time of discharge. Discharged with plan for 
further pain management per provider at ___. Of 
note, a vertebroplasty was discussed to help palliate the 
patient's pain however it was decided that the risks outwighed 
benefits in this ___ year-old woman.
.  
#. Fever: The patient develoepd a fever to 102.0 in the ED. No 
clear source was identified initially. A UA showed pyuria 
however no bacteria and was nitrite negative. A CT torso at 
___ without evidence of pulmonary infiltrate.  Pt 
arrived to floor with foley in place, per records it was placed 
at ___ prior to transfer. This foley was removed on 
admission to the floor. Blood and Urine cultures remained 
negative and a respiratory viral screen including influenza was 
negative. The patient was afebrile throughout the remainder of 
her hospital course. 
.  
#Dementia- Pt severely demented at baseline per family. In the 
hosiptial she was oriented to eprson and place. At times able to 
answer questions appropriately. Continued on home donepezil.
.  
#Hypothyroidism- Continued home levothyroxine.
.
#. Transitional Issues:
1) Pain control: Optimize pain regimen with PO medications and 
can consider vertebroplasty as outpatient if not improving.
2) Orthopedics reccomended a TLSO brace for comfort. The brace 
was not yet ready at time of discharge. Can consider ordering at 
___.
3) Was saturating ~90% on RA. Most likely due to splinting from 
pain. On 2L O2 NC on discharge. 
4) Discontinued Seroquel as patient was overly sedated in-house. 
Can re-start if alertness improved at nursing facility.

Brief Hospital Course:
Summary: This is a ___ yo female with h/o ETOH dependence who 
presented to ___ and found to have acute pancreatitis 
whose course c/b CT contrast infiltration into R wrist who was 
transferred to ___ for management of possible wrist 
compartment syndrome.
.
# Alcoholic Pancreatitis: The patient presented with severe 
epigastric pain, an inability to tolerate PO, and abnormal LFTs. 
She was found to have hyperbilirubinemia, transaminitis, 
hyponatremia and an anion gap metabolic acidosis. She was given 
IV fluids and IV morphine for pain control. Over the course of 
her stay, the patient started to tolerate a regular diet without 
nausea and vomiting. Her pain was better controlled and her LFTs 
trended to normal ranges. The patient was discharged with 16 
pills of Percocet and told to followup at her scheduled 
appointment or sooner with her primary care doctor if she 
requires more pain control. 

# ETOH Dependence/Withdrawl: The patient reportedly had been 
drinking heavily over the past year. During her stay, she 
developed increased anxiety, tremulousness, fever, and 
tachycardia. She was started on a CIWA scale and required PO 
Valium to help her. She also reports vivid nightmares. Social 
work consulted with the patient and suggested resources for her 
to explore as an outpatient. The patient has a desire to quit 
alcohol, but has too many life stressors. She was given Valium 
20 mg PO on discharge.

# Right Wrist Swelling: Orthopedics hand surgery evaluated the 
patient and thought that her swelling was possibly due to 
compartment syndrome. They recommended against surgical 
intervention and suggested keeping the arm elevated and 
controlling her pain. With elevation, the pain subsided. The 
hand always remained neurovascularly intact and had normal 
pulses/strength/sensation on discharge. Ortho hand said to 
followup PRN in their clinic.

Normocytic anemia: The patient continued to have a normocytic 
anemia. It was stable throughout her stay. If it persists, it 
will likely need to be assessed as an outpatient. On discharge 
her Hct was 34.8. 

Depression/anxiety: The patient has poor social support and 
psychiatric issues and uses alcohol to cope with her problems. 
Social work spoke with the patient and provided outpatient 
resources. She was given a three day supply of Ativan 1 mg BID: 
PRN anxiety.

Uninsured: The patient reports having no insurance and said it's 
difficult to fill prescriptions and see doctors. ___ social 
worker here linked the patient to a state-sponsored health 
insurance plan.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old female history of bipolar disorder, ___ 
transferred from MICU/medicine s/p OD of neurontin, depakote, 
alcohol; event possibly suicide attempt in the setting of 
numerous psychosocial stressors and being unable to obtain her
prescription medications.

Axis I: GAD, History of bipolar, polysubstance abuse, r/o MDD 
Axis II: deferred
Axis III: s/p Depakote and neurontin overdose

parents, lost custody of children, multiple psych issues. 
Axis V: 30

#). Anxiety: Pt reports long history of severe anxiety with 
chest pressure, racing thoughts, diaphoresis, inner feeling of 
restlessness previously treated with numerous high-dose 
medication (thorazine, seroquel, neurontin). 
- Although akathesia was certainly on the differential, pt 
described feelings of restlessness prior to initiation of 
antipsychotics. In addition, stated anxiety sxs were best 
controlled on neurontin, thorazine, seroquel.  
- Due to concerns of polypharmacy in the setting of two prior 
overdoses, we initially held the patient's Depakote, Neurontin, 
Thorazine, and continued Seroquel 150 mg bid. 
- Started mirtazapine 30 mg qhs for anxiety and depression, 
however, pt continued to c/o severe anxiety symptoms. Eventually 
added Luvox that was tapered up to 150 mg qhs as well as 
thorazine 75 mg tid and 175 mg qhs, Neurontin 600 mg tid, and 
atenolol that was tapered to 50 mg po qd with careful monitoring 
of BP and HR. 
- Pt expressed concern that she would not be able to receive 
thorazine as an outpatient, so d/c'ed thorazine and started 
perphenazine 8mg tid, 16 qhs with significant improvement in 
anxiety symptoms. 

#). Ethanol dependence/PSA: Per OMR, pt reported drinking 
approximately 2 pints of hard liquor per day. Also h/o opiate 
dependence.
- CIWA scale initially started. Vital signs remained stable 
throughout hospitalization with no complications. 
- group/milieu therapy.

#). Depression, History of bipolar disorder: difficult to assess 
validity of diagnosis at this time, as the patient's only period 
of sobriety was during her pregnancies. However, no evidence of 
mania on this admission and no clear history of mania in the 
past. 
- The patient met diagnostic criteria for MDD, but has been 
abusing alcohol to control her anxiety symptoms. To target 
depressive and anxiety symptoms, we started mirtazapine and 
Luvox. 
- Held lithium and depakote therapy, particularly considering 
the hx of recent SA per overdosing. 
 
#) s/p overdose of depakote and neurontin: clinically stable. 
LFT's normalized, last depakote level= 30's. Not 
encephalopathic. 
- Patient remained medically stable throughout this admission.

able to maintain her safety throughout the admission on q15 
minute checks

2. PSYCHIATRIC:
#) Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood  
___ is a ___ year old man, active service member 
___ Corps), with no significant PMH, PPHx of depression, 
sexual trauma, one previous near suicide attempt by hanging in 
___, no prior hospitalizations, who was brought in by ambulance 
after suicide attempt by cutting his neck with knife in the 
setting of alcohol use. Patient seen by trauma surgery in ED - 
sutures were placed and patient was medically cleared. Patient 
reported that primary stressors included family turmoil, 
holidays, and alcohol use. 
. 
On initial interview, Mr. ___ endorsed feeling ___ 
from family and friends at home, namely life outside ___ the 
___, which was exacerbated upon his return home for the 
holidays. He finds support from his friends in the military who 
have similar experiences, though does not feel that he can 
connect to
his former friends or family members. He states that after an 
argument with his family, he impulsively decided to attempt 
suicide by cutting his throat but expressed on initial 
evaluation remorse and guilt. He reported feeling grateful to be 
alive. On exam patient appeared calm, cooperative, with 4 cm 
laceration w/ 7 sutures placed overlying R carotid. Patient 
appeared initially dysthymic and tearful when discussing events 
leading up to hospitalization. He denied nonetheless any 
suicidal ideation, intent, or plan. Cognitive and neurologic 
exam were both unremarkable. 
. 
During the course of his hospitalization, Mr. ___ 
persistently denied any depressed mood, anhedonia, hopelessness, 
insomnia, or poor PO intake with no symptoms concerning for 
neurovegetative signs of depression. He endorsed an intact sense 
of self worth and was future oriented. Two family meetings were 
held with patient's family to discuss concerns, future 
treatment, and recommendations to increase communication within 
the family. Patient reported that by the end of his 
hospitalization, he felt more comfortable communicating with his 
family and felt surprised that his parents were vulnerable, 
sensitive, emotional, and able to empathically listen to his 
concerns. The team communicated with patient's ___ team 
including his lieutenant responsible for coordination of 
appointments; per his ___, patient will have robust 
supports in place upon return. During hospitalization, team 
additionally discussed minimizing alcohol use which appears to 
be a trigger. 
. 
Diagnostically, presentation appeared consistent with adjustment 
disorder w/ depressed mood as patient did not endorse persistent 
depressed mood/ anhedonia, neuro-vegeative symptoms, or any 
hopelessness/helplessness. Prior to discharge he denied any 
suicidal thoughts and appeared future oriented. His suicide 
attempt served the function of garnering family attention and 
was an expression of his distress, given this was a high 
lethality method of self harm but also equally high rescue given 
that the act was performed in the setting of acute intoxication 
and in front of his family. Patient does endorse some hx of 
trauma and subsequent nightmares/flashbacks, but his current 
presentation does not appear to be in the setting of post 
traumatic stress disorder. Prior to discharge, patient was 
intermittently tearful during family meeting but overall 
euthymic, with reactive affect and positive outlook regarding 
future. We had a very positive meeting with ___ and ___ 
prior to d/c where they were all able to acknowledge the need to 
communicate better.
.

RISK ASSESSMENT & PROGNOSIS
 . 
Patient has risk factors concerning for risk of self harm 
including recent suicide attempt, male gender, hx of trauma, 
alcohol use, and limited coping skills. However, patient has 
multiple protective factors and risk factors that were modified 
during the course of this hospitalization including 
establishment of outpatient providers, coordination of care, 
stronger family support, with patient expressing an intact sense 
of self worth, future oriented thought process, and patent 
appearing more help seeking in nature. As such patient's risk of 
harm to self per SAFE-T tool is now low.

Brief Hospital Course:
Reason for Admission: low grade fever and chills at dialysis. 

___ yo M w/ h/o ESRD ___ to PCKD, on dialysis and recent 
admission for E. coli bacteremia who presented with chills and 
low grade fevers at dialysis session while on outpatient 
antibiotic (ceftazidime) regimen, now on vanc (___) and zosyn 
(___) with no growth in blood cultures to date. 
.
Active Issues:
# Low grade fevers- Patient was admitted for a temperature of 
99.8 at dialysis in the ___ week of treatment for e.coli 
bacteremia. Patient has been afebrile throughout admission and 
cultures drawn in the hospital had no growth.  Additionally 
cultures from ___ Dialysis unit from 
48hrs, 4 days and 7 days prior to admission had no growth.  
Because of this, it was felt that the patient's line could be 
left in place.  During admission, patient was treated with 
vancomycin (___) and zosyn (___). Patient had a history 
of osteomyelitis and endocarditis in ___, so these were 
evaluated with a TTE, TEE (requiring conscious sedation) and a 
CT spine which did not show evidence of current endocarditis or 
osteomyelitis. ID followed this patient throughout the admission 
and felt that given lack of fevers, negative blood blood 
cultures, and no obvious source, they felt he could go back to 
prison without antibiotics.
.  
# ESRD: Pt gets MWF dialysis, which was continued throughout the 
admission. Renal transplant service was made aware of patient's 
admission, as they are planning to create a brachiocephalic 
fistula for dialysis. Pt is on transplant list, transplant 
surgery elected to defer surgery while patient is being worked 
up for infection.  Continued home sevelamer, doxercalciferol and 
given lenient renal diet (per patient insistence) and was fluid 
restricted (1L/day). Patient will be seen by trasnplant shortly 
after discharge.
.  
# Joint pains: Pt w/ chronic pain of back, as well as L ankle 
and L great toe, which he attributes to gout. Patient remained 
on allopurinol during admission. Was not started on colchicine, 
and renal fellow recommended against this medication in ESRD 
patients. Ortho consult felt his back pain may be secondary to 
sacroiliitis. A pelvic xray did not show any fracture, 
dislocation, or acute osteo. A CT spine of his back did not show 
signs concerning for osteomyelitis either. Patient was continued 
on his home regimen of MS contin 30mg BID for chronic pain as 
well as started on NSAIDs for management of pain. Additonally 
complaining of locked DIP and PIP joints bilaterally, which was 
not actively assessed as an inpatient. Patient has outpatient 
follow up with orthopedic surgery.
.
# Hypertension: Patient's blood pressure ranged from the 
120s-140s in the hours after dialysis, to the 160s-190s in the 
day and a half leading up to the next dialysis session.  Patient 
c/o frequent HAs with elevated pressures and had an episode of 
vomitting with a BP of 177/90. During this time, pt had no 
papiledema or AMS. A CT head was negative for intracranial 
process and HA improved with hydralazine. Patient required 
several additional doses of hydralazine and lisinopril, and on 
the day prior to discharge, his standing lisinopril was 
increased from 5mg to 10mg PO daily with improved BPs 
(140s/80s). 
.  
Chronic Issues:
# Hepatitis C: Chronic hep C with prior interferon treatment. He 
is not currently being treated.  
- defer to outpatient management  
.  
# Anemia: Hct ranged from ___ throughout admission, baseline 
appears to be around 28. Secondary to chronic renal disease.  
Stable. Epo was held during admission for concern of possible 
history of parathyroid cancer. We were not able to locate 
records from his operation (only were able to determine from 
___ that it occurred in ___ in ___, 
___ prior to discharge.  After further discussion with 
nephrology, it was not felt that this distant and questionable 
history of cnacer should be a contraindication to epo so they 
were going to give instructions to resume epo in their sign-out 
to the patient's local hemodialysis center.
.  
# Lung nodule: 8 mm nodule in left base, new from prior studies. 
Will need follow up with non-emergent chest CT scan for further 
characterization as an outpatient.
.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you were having low 
grade fevers during your dialysis session.  You were being 
treated for a bacteria in your blood at your outpatient dialysis 
unit for the past 2 weeks, and so we were worried that the 
antibiotics you were on were not treating your infection.  While 
you were in the hospital, we gave you 2 strong antibiotics.  You 
did not have a fever in the hospital and we never found any 
bacteria growing in your blood.  The blood drawn at your 
dialysis unit also never had any bacteria growing in it. We did 
some imaging of your back and heart because we were concerned 
that you may have an infection in either of these areas, however 
there was no evidence of infection on these studies.  Because 
there is not evidence that you are still infected, we have 
stopped your antibiotics.  It is common to have low grade fevers 
while getting dialysis, so this may be a chronic event for you. 
If you remain afebrile over the next week (with a temperature 
not greater than 100.4F), you should be able to have a fistula 
or graft placed soon.  We have made an appointment with your 
transplant surgeon, Dr. ___, for next week (see 
details below), so that you will have close follow up and so the 
procedure will be done as soon as possible.

You were noted to have a lung nodule of unknown significance on 
CXR. You should follow up with your PCP and should be scheduled 
for an outpatient Chest CT to follow this.

Please continue your home medication as prescribed.  You no 
longer need to take Ceftazidime, the antibiotic you were getting 
at dialysis.

The following changes have been made to your medications:
- please INCREASE lisinopril to 10 mg daily
- please START ibuprofen 400 mg every 8 hours, if this isn't 
managing your pain, you can increase to 600 or 800 mg every 8 
hours.  Please be sure to take ibuprofen with food, do not take 
it on an empty stomach.
- please STOP taking ceftazidime.  There is no active evidence 
of infection, so you do not need any antibiotics right now.

The rest of your medications have not changed.  Please continue 
to take them as originally prescribed.

Endplate erosion with loss of disc height at L5-S1 levels, with

osteomyelitis. Additionally there is a disc bulge and bilateral

foramina narrowing and compression of the L5 nerve roots and

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old incarcerated male with ESRD secondary to Polycystic 
Kidney Disease on HemoDialysis with recent E. coli bacteremia 
diagnosed by Blood culture from outside hospital on ___ 
believed secondary to HD line infection, presented this time 
with fevers, chills/rigors, found to have 1 out of 4 bottle E 
coli bacteremia. He was stable and discharged on Bactrim for 1 
week. 
.
# Fevers: Patient admitted to ___ for the third time in the 
past month with fevers and rigors. Patient last had 
blood-culture proven E. coli bacteremia in ___. The 
source of infection is most likely the tunneled right-sided HD 
line, but blood cultures during this admission only grew E. coli 
in one bottle, so contamination of the sample by multiple 
hospital admission acquired skin flora cannot be ruled out and 
bacteremia cannot be ruled in. Patient's history is also 
significant for chronic osteomyelitis of his lumbar spine, but 
no acute infection was evident on MRI. Patient was initially 
treated wtih ceftazidime in the ED, broaded to 
vancomycin/cefepime, and after the culture returned GNR, 
narrowed to cefepime only. After speciation and sensitivity 
returned, and given question of bacteremia, patient was treated 
conservatively with Bactim DS once a day at evening for a total 
of 7 days without need for a line change at this time.
.  
# ESRD: He continued to receive MWF dialysis in-house. Renal 
transplant service and Transplant surgery were aware of pt on 
previous admission and were informed of current admission. 
Patient continued his home sevelamer, doxercalciferol, renal 
caps, and renal diet in-house.  
.  
# Chronic joint pains: Patient has chronic pain of back, knees 
and ankles which he attributes to gout. Previous ortho consult 
felt his back pain may be secondary to sacroiliitis, pelvic xray 
did not show any fracture, dislocation, or acute osteomyelitis, 
and CT spine did not show signs concerning for osteomyelitis 
either. Diagnosis of gout is questionable given chronicity of 
pains, location, and pain without signs consistent with acute 
gout flares. Rheumatology at the ___ has seen the patient and 
doubts gout. Have been unable to attain original documentation 
of how the gout was diagnosed, but pt was most recently treated 
for a flare in ___ with prednisone, ___, and 
allopurinol. MRI of lumbar spine was done this admission and 
showed signs of chronic osteomyelitis and bilateral neural 
foramina narrowing and compression of the L5 nerve roots and 
abutting the S1 nerve roots, likely the source of the pain. No 
evidence of acute osteomyelitis was seen. Patient's pain was 
controlled with his home regimen of MS contin and allopurinol.
.
# Hypertension: Controlled in house with home dose of lisinopril 
and metoprolol.
.

2. Replacement of HD catheter once antibiotic course is

Brief Hospital Course:
___ M with ESRD on HD, HTN, chronic osteomyelitis and multiple 
admissions for fevers presenting with fever following HD.

# Fevers - Patient has had multiple admissions for transient 
fevers, often following HD, with blood cultures occasionally 
positive for E.coli.  Fevers only began once tunnel catheter was 
placed, after AVF clotted.  ESR and CRP are at patient's 
baseline so unlikely acute on chronic osteomyelitis.  In 
addition, patient had no worsening of his low back pain.  
Radiography showed stable process as well. CXR showed no acute 
cardiopulmonary process.  Patient given vancomycin/cefepime x1 
in ER.  Overnight on HD1/2 patient spiked fevers to 103.2 and on 
HD2, tunneled catheter line was pulled and patient was started 
on vancomycin and ceftazadime with dialysis. Patient was given a 
line holiday for 2 days prior to replacement of line.  Line tip 
culture grew strep viridans, coag negative staph, non hemolytic 
strep and corynebacterium consistent with skin or oral flora. 
Blood cultures were negative to date on the day of discharge.  
Patient was afebrile following removal of HD line and did not 
have further fevers.  He completed a 7 day course of vancomycin 
and cefepime following the discontinuation of the HD line.  
Other potential sources of occult infection were investigation 
with a CT abdomen, prostate ultrasound, WBC tagged scan and bone 
scan.  All of these studies were negative for infection.  

# ESRD on HD - Patient gets dialysis ___. 
He was continued on his home sevelamer, doxercalciferol and 
nephrocaps while inpatient. He was dialyzed on ___ 
prior to removal of original tunneled HD line, and spiked a 
fever to 105.  The line was removed following dialysis and 
patient had a "line holiday" until ___ when a 
new tunneled cath was placed without issue.  Patient was 
dialyzed on ___ and ___ as scheduled following 
replacement of catheter.  He had no fevers during or following 
dialysis.  Patient has follow-up scheduled with surgical team 
regarding AV fistula v graft.

# Leukopenia/Thrombocytopenia - Has had WBC as low as 2.8 back 
in ___, this appears to be the first time platelets have 
dipped so low. Patient recently on bactrim which ended 1.5 weeks 
ago, and working diagnosis was residual thrombocytopenia due 
this antibiotic.  In addition, with history of HepC, may be due 
to decreased liver function.  Platelets initially trended down, 
but were increasing above admission levels at the time of 
discharge.

# Chronic pain - Has chronic joint pains which have been 
associated with gout in the past. Also with history of chronic 
osteomyelitis as above.  Pain was at baseline and well 
controlled on home regimen of amitriptyline, MS contin 30mg BID, 
ropinirole.  
  
# Hypertension: Patient was intiially continued on lisinopril 
and metoprolol at home doses.  On HD 4, blood pressures were 
elevated, likely in the setting of volume overload due to 
dietary indiscretions and no HD over the weekend.  Patient was 
given hydralazine 25mg q6h, and following dialysis with removal 
of 4.5L, pressures remained elevated.  Lisinopril was increased 
to 40mg daily as well and patient was discharged on hydralazine 
and new dose of lisinopril.   Consider titrating off of 
hydralazine as full effect of lisinopril is seen.
  
# Hepatitis C: Chronic hep C with prior interferon treatment 
dc'ed for GI bleed and ineffectiveness. He is not currently 
being treated.  
  
# Anemia: On prior admission Hct ranged from ___ throughout 
admission, baseline appears to be around 28, secondary to 
chronic renal disease and possibly iron deficiency.  Hematocrit 
remained at baseline throughout admission.

# Transitional issues:
- Please titrate down and discontinue entirely if blood 
pressures well controlled on increased dose of lisinopril.
- 8-mm rim calcified nodular opacity within the left lung base 
noted on CXR, patient will need a non-emergent CT scan to better 
evaluate  
- Patient will have follow-up with surgical team regarding AV 
fistula/graft.  This should be done as soon as possible to avoid 
further tunneled line infections.

Mr. ___ is a ___ w/ ESRD s/p deceased donor renal

# Dyspnea
# ?Acute CHF Exacerbation 
The patient presented with a history of orthopnea & dyspnea w/ 
CXR findings of bilateral effusions & pulmonary vascular 
congestion consistent with fluid overload state. His weight was 
noted to be higher recently from prior discharge. No medication 
non-adherence or dietary changes although the recent addition of 
sodium bicarbonate may be contributing due to increased Na load. 
Patient's blood pressures were uncontrolled & likely further 
increased his left-sided afterload. A TTE on ___ revealed 
elevated PCWP and E/E' with preserved EF. Overall patient 
reported symptomatic improvement with diuresis and his daily 
weights continued to trend down. Although there are no concerns 
of rejection based on a bland urine sediment and an unremarkable 
renal ultrasound, the etiology of the patient's volume overload 
may have been in part also been caused by worsening renal 
function as evidenced by creatinines in the 4s compared to his 
baseline of creatinine in the 3s. Patient was diuresed with IV 
furosemide PRN and transitioned to oral diuretics. His 
electrolytes are monitored and repleted as needed. His labetalol 
was increased to 600 mg 3 times daily and he was continued on 
his nifedipine 30 mg daily.

# ___:
# ESRD w/p transplant c/b chronic rejection:
Cr 4 on presentation, up from discharge 3.2 on ___. His elevated 
creatinine may be cardiorenal in etiology given clinical context 
and possible end-organ damage in setting of hypertension but 
worsening overall renal function cannot be ruled out given lack 
of significant improvement with diuresis. His renal US had no 
evidence/concern for hydronephrosis and there was less concern 
for rejection at this time given bland urine and lack of 
characteristics findings on renal US. The patient's renal 
function was trended daily. He was continued on his 
immunosuppressive regimen of mycophenolate, tacrolimus, and 
prednisone. His tacrolimus levels were trended daily. He was 
continued on atovaquone prophylaxis. His MAPs were maintained 
above 65. He is also continued on calcium and cinacalcet. Sodium 
bicarbonate was held in the setting of his volume overloaded 
state. His blood pressure was better controlled as noted.

# HTN:
The patient was noted to have systolic blood pressure readings 
in the ___. He was previously on losartan & labetalol last 
hospitalization but losartan was held on discharge given 
persistent hyperkalemia. At that time, labetalol dosing was 
increased to 400mg TID from 200mg BID & nifedipine ER 30mg QD 
was initiated. No evidence of renal artery stenosis in 
transplant kidney as though no changes in resistive indices. The 
patient's labetalol was increased to 600 mg 3 times daily and he 
was continued on nifedipine along leading to better blood 
pressure control.

# Mild Hyperkalemia:
Patient presented with mild hyperkalemia and on review of 
records, it appeared that patient was chronically mildly 
hyperkalemic. His hyperkalemia improved with ongoing IV diuresis 
with Furosemide. 

# Normocytic anemia:
His home hemoglobin was similar to baseline values in setting of 
end-stage renal disease. His CBCs were trended daily and he did 
not require a blood transfusion during his hospitalization.

# GERD:
Continued on his prior dose of ranitidine.

# Insomnia:
Continued on his prior dose of amitriptyline. His ramelteon was 
held due to concerns of possible toxicity to the renal 
transplant.
