Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a history of ESRD ___ PCKD s/p 
deceased donor renal transplant (___) c/b chronic allograft 
dysfunction, now back on HD since ___, HCV s/p Harvoni, and 
HTN who presented with left flank/hip/testicular pain. 
Infectious work up was unremarkable. MRI spine was notable for 
degenerative disc disease, likely causing radicular pain. 
Chronic pain service and orthopedic surgery were consulted and 
recommended ongoing pain management. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#Left flank/hip/back pain, severe uncontrolled pain
#Neuropathic pain
The patient presented with ___ weeks of left flank pain that 
then moved into his left hip, thigh, groin and left testicle. 
Initial evaluation was notable for CVA tenderness and left 
testicular tenderness concerning for UTI/nephrolithiasis vs 
epididymitis. CT abd/pelvis showed an atrophic kidney without 
nephrolithiasis or pyelonephritis and testicular ultrasound was 
equivocal for epidimyitis. He was initially started on broad 
spectrum antibiotics, which were discontinued after urine 
culture, GC & chlamydia returned negative. Given persistent 
pain, MRI L-spine and pelvis were done, demonstrating L5-S1 
changes c/w chronic spondyloarthropathy ___ ESRD vs sequela of 
prior discitis, as well as severe left-sided L4-L5 neural 
foraminal narrowing. The L4-L5 was felt to be the etiology of 
his pain given the correlating location. Chronic pain service 
and orthopedic surgery were consulted and provided recommends 
for pain management. He was continued on oxycodone, 
amitriptyline and started on tizanidine as well as lyrica with 
improvement in his pain. He will follow up in the ___ spine 
clinic for further management. 

#ESRD ___ PCKD s/p renal transplant c/b rejection now on HD
Presented with moderate volume overload, particularly noted to 
have bilateral pleural effusions on CXR. He underwent multiple 
daily sessions of dialysis with improvement and then was 
transitioned to his normal regimen. He had significant weight 
gain between sessions and required tighter fluid restriction, 
which should be continued as an outpatient. Additionally, his 
home prednisone and tacrolimus were continued.

#Acute hypoxic respiratory failure
#Acute pulmonary edema
Patient noted to have rapidly worsening hypoxia one evening 
during his hospitalization briefly requiring a non-rebreather. 
Repeat CXR showed significant pulmonary edema with bilateral 
effusions. He was started on a nitroglycerin gtt and underwent 
urgent bedside dialysis overnight with improvement in his 
clinical status. He was rapidly weaned to room air and remained 
stable for the remainder of the hospitalization. 

#NSTEMI
Troponin 0.08 on admission and continued to rise to 0.45 in the 
setting of fluid overload and acute hypoxic respiratory failure. 
EKG showed borderline submillimeter ST depressions in I, V5-V6 
(different from baseline), which was stable/improving on serial 
EKGs. He denied having any chest pain during this time. 
Cardiology was consulted and felt the presentation was 
consistent with type II NSTEMI due to fluid overload. Follow up 
TTE did not demonstrate a wall motion abnormality. Ultimately, 
cardiology decided against stress test at this time. He was 
discharged on his home aspirin with the addition of atorvastatin 
and metoprolol. 

#Atrial fibrillation 
Noted to be in atrial fibrillation on ___, which rapidly 
resolved within hours to a day. This was a new diagnosis for the 
patient, felt to be ___ fluid shifts vs less likely cardiac 
ischemia. TSH normal. His home labetalol was switched to 
metoprolol and his heart rate and rhythm remained stable. Given 
a CHADSVASC of 1, anticoagulation was not started.  

#Access
Newly placed fistula with some ulceration. He should follow up 
with Dr. ___ in Nephrology to evaluate as an outpatient. 

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Hypertension
He was continued on his home nifedipine. He refused several 
daily doses of labetalol, stating the dose was too high. Given 
new episode of atrial fibrillation, possible cardiac disease, 
and normotensive pressures without labetalol, he was switched to 
metoprolol and remained stable on this regimen.  

#Normocytic anemia 
Hemoglobin stable from prior, felt to be ___ anemia of chronic 
disease ___ ESRD
and iron deficiency. He was continued on his on iron 
supplementation. 

#GERD
- Continued ranitidine 

#BPH
- Continued tamsulosin

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___!

Why you were admitted to the hospital:
- You were having pain in your side, back, hip and groin

What happened while you were here:
- Infectious work up was unremarkable - specifically you had no 
infection in your urine or testicles 
- There was concern for a kidney stone though imaging did not 
show this so it was felt to be less likely
- MRI of your back showed narrowing and pressure on the nerves, 
which was felt to be the cause of your pain 
- Orthopedic spine surgery and the pain service were consulted 
and assisted with pain management
- Additionally, you had significant fluid overload (fluid in 
your lungs), requiring oxygen and repeat dialysis sessions 
- Lab tests showed that there was additional stress on your 
heart. You should continue taking your heart medications as 
prescribed. 

What you should do once you leave the hospital:
- Please continue taking your medications as prescribed
- Please follow up at the appointments outlined below 

Sincerely,

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is as ___ incarcerated male with ESRD
secondary to PCKD s/p failed kidney transplant in ___ and on HD
___, Hepatitis C (treated), HTN, hx of osteomyelitis/
endocarditis per chart review, and carotid stenosis who is
presenting with approximately 4 months of worsening bilateral
hand and unilateral foot pain swelling and skin breakdown. 

He reports no known antecedent trauma to his hands and his feet
but has had progressive pain and discoloration of two fingers on
his right hand, one finger on his left hand, and right big toe.
He reports trying to seek help earlier but was unable to get
medical attention at his ___ facility. The pain has
progressively gotten worse to now ___ pain, limiting his
ability to ambulate and use his hands.

Regarding his ulcers, per outpatient notes, Mr. ___ has a 
long
history of manipulative and self-injurious behavior. The wound 
on
the right hand started as a small cut likely from trimming his
finger nails. Without adequate wound care or dressing changes,
this progressed into a blister and then further progressed to 
the
necrotic lesion.

He had an ultrasound of the right subclavian to rule out 
thrombus
and an echo which showed no vegetations. ANCA panel and
cryoglobulins were negative. He had a period where the hand
became edematous and erythematous, with elevated ESR and CRP and
was treated with IV vanco and ceftaz with improvement in the
wound appearance, edema and erythema. Despite this, he continued
to be non-compliant with wound care.

He was seen by Vascular Surgery at ___ and on ___ an
arteriogram was done there showing:

The right subclavian artery axillary and brachial arteries were
all widely patent.  The right ulnar artery was the primary
outflow to the hand as the radial artery occluded in the distal
forearm.  On the left the subclavian axillary and brachial
arteries were all widely patent.  There was reversal of flow
distal to the fistula, the fistula filled very quickly.  With
fistula compression the ulnar artery had improved flow and was
the primary runoff to the hand as the radial artery occluded in
the mid forearm.  Of note, there was significant sluggish flow
throughout all of his vessels concerning for a possible central
source.

Dr. ___ performed the study, had no good explanation
for the very sluggish flow in this patient whose last EF was
normal. There were no treatable lesions as above.

Dr. ___, the transplant physician who has been managing his 
left upper extremity fistula, felt that ligating the fistula 
would be recommended in this setting to optimize flow to the 
left hand and help healing as much as possible, although patient 
has declined in the past. This may be an elective option in the 
future.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a history of ESRD ___ PCKD s/p 
deceased donor renal transplant (___) c/b chronic allograft 
dysfunction, now back on HD since ___, HCV s/p Harvoni, and 
HTN who presented with bilateral digital ulcers, with imaging 
concerning for possible osteomyelitis. Broad workup sent to rule 
out vasculitic process and embolic source. Presentation 
ultimately thought secondary to peripheral vascular disease with 
associated dry gangrene of the digits.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: 

# Foot/Hand ulcers
# Concern for osteomyelitis
Patient presented with worsening pain, swelling, and necrotic 
changes of the R index/middle and L index fingers in the setting 
of progressively worsening chronic hand ischemia. Duration seems 
likely ___ months, as not noted on prior admission discharged in 
___. Per outpatient notes, injury was apparently incurred and 
resulted in worsening appearance and apparent concern for 
superinfection which was treated with IV Vanc/Ceftaz at ___ 
additionally, reportedly ANCA and Cryoglobulins were sent and 
were negative. When not improved, patient was sent to ___ 
where arteriogram shows sluggish flow without evidence of a flow 
limiting lesion. This may be seen in the presence of a central 
lesion or can also be seen in advanced heart failure, however EF 
was noted to be preserved. Broad differential was considered for 
decreased perfusion and vasculopathy including peripheral 
arterial disease, embolic (hypercoagulability, infectious, 
central lesion) vasculitis(small/medium/large vessel 
involvement, cryoglobulinemia) with work up unrevealing. He also 
underwent CTA chest which did not show a central lesion in his 
aorta. He had ABIs of the lower extremities which showed 
significant vascular occlusive disease. Calciphylaxis was 
considered, dermatology was consulted but thought unlikely given 
isolated involvement of fingertips. For potential benefit of 
increased perfusion via vasodilation, nifedipine was uptitrated. 
Tacrolimus was discontinued after discussion with renal given 
limited benefit to graft and known side effect of 
vasoconstriction. Admission radiographs concerning for R digit 
osteomyelitis and as such MR was obtained which was not fully 
completed, but did not show osteomyelitis. Repeat MRI was not 
pursued as hand surgery did not think it would change 
management. Vascular surgery and hand surgery were consulted. 
Vascular surgery did not recommend intervention. Hand surgery 
felt his presentation was most likely consistent with dry 
gangrene related to his peripheral vascular disease and the 
fingers would likely self-demarcate/self-amputate. Pain was 
aggressively controlled with OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 15 mg 
PO Q8H:PRN Pain on discharge. He was also started on gabapentin 
100 mg daily as adjuvant medication which discussed with the 
nephrology team.

#Atypical pneumonia
Found to incidentally have multifocal opacities on CTA chest per 
above. He was asymptomatic without leukocytosis, fever, cough. 
Differential diagnosis for the opacities included vasculitis 
given the above workup, however was ultimately felt to be most 
consistent with an atypical pneumonia. He received azithromycin 

#ESRD ___ PCKD s/p DDRT ___ c/b chronic allograft dysfunction 
(antibody-mediated rejection ___, biopsy-confirmed chronic 
transplant glomerulopathy, interstitial fibrosis & tubular 
atrophy ___ 
Patient maintained on HD ___ schedule for dialysis. Discharge 
weight was around
148lb on prior admission. On admission 140lbs. Discharge weight 
140.1 lbs.
- Continued home nephrocap daily, Mg oxide 800mg daily, Calcium
Carbonate 500 mg PO BID, and Cinacalcet 30 mg PO DAILY, EPO shot 
once weekly, renal diet, fluid restriction 1.5L daily. 
Tacrolimus was discontinued given limited benefit to graft and 
known side effect of vasoconstriction. 

# Immunosuppression
Continued prednisone 5mg daily. Prior to admission tacrolimus 
2.5mg BID which is vasoconstrictive, held after discussion with 
renal. Continued PCP ppx with ___ Suspension 750 mg PO 
DAILY. 

#Hypertension
Uptitrated nifedipine to 30 daily.

#Afib:
Labetolol switched to metoprolol succinate 50 daily last

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  During your hospitalization, you had surgery to 
remove unhealthy tissue on your lower extremity.  You tolerated 
the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital.   Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a 
speedy and uneventful recovery.

LOWER  EXTREMITY AMPUTATION (bilateral first hallux) 
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

ACTIVITY 

You should keep your amputation site elevated whenever 
possible.It is very important that you put WEIGHT BEAR FOR 
ESSENTIAL DISTANCES ONLY UNTIL YOU ARE SEEN IN FOLLOW UP. 

MEDICATION

Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

You will likely be prescribed narcotic pain medication on 
discharge which  can be very constipating.  If you take 
narcotics,  please also take a stool softener such as Colace.   
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest 
an additional over the counter laxative. 

You should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for 
pain.  If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic 
pain medication.  You should require less pain medication each 
day.  Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter 
and prescription medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you 
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
You may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or 
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the 
incision is fully healed.  DO NOT SOAK YOUR INCISION.
After your shower, gently dry the incision well.   Do not rub 
the area. 

WOUND CARE:
Please keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that 
there is no pressure on the wound.    If there is no drainage, 
you may leave the incision open to air.  

Your staples/sutures will remain in for at least 3 weeks.  At 
your followup appointment, we will see if the incision has 
healed enough to remove the sutures. 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
Opening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your wound incision 

Redness, swelling or warmth in your wound.
Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening 
incisional/wound pain  

NO OTHER PROVIDER, EXCEPT YOUR VASCULAR SURGEON, SHOULD 
DETERMINE IF YOUR SUTURES ARE READY TO BE REMOVED FROM YOUR 
WOUND!   
IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, THE PROVIDER SHOULD CALL THE 
VASCULAR SURGERY OFFICE AT ___ TO DISCUSS.   THE 
SUTURES WILL BE REMOVED IN THE OFFICE AT YOUR FOLLOWUP 
APPOINTMENT WHEN IT IS DETERMINED BY THE VASCULAR SURGEON THAT 
THE WOUND HAS SUFFICIENTLY HEALED.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
POD#2  Tm 102.9 overnight (11pm)), UA sent which was negative, 
no further fever workup pursued given pod#1 and has not been 
using IS nor ambulating much.  No pulmonary sx, no urinary sx, 
likely atelectasis and continued to monitor closely.
POD#3 was tachycardic to Tm 101.9 at 3am, tachy to 114, 95%2L 
denied sob/pleuritic chest pain, reported that uses O2 at home 
sometimes, no urinary sx, reports ear pain, no calf pain. 
Incision c/d/i with small area of ecchymosis/erythema.  
Cxr/ua/blood cultures ordered with close monitoring for any 
changes in symptoms and to determine need for further workup 
with PE CT if does not improve given fever/tachy/O2 requirement 
overnight. Also received 1u prbc for drop in hematocrit.
POD#4 Tachycardia improved s/p prbc transfusion, decreased O2 
requirement overnight, afebrile, chest x-ray shows decreased 
lung volume, ua negative. Remained afebrile and asymptomatic 
with no further O2 requirement throughout day, was mildly 
somnolent, but A&Ox3 and easily arousable.  Incision c/d/i with 
___ erythema. Otherwise pain well controlled and no 
acute symptoms 

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.

Discharge Diagnosis:
RIGHT KNEE OSTEOARTHRITIS

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
removed will be taken out at your follow-up visit in three (3) 
weeks after your surgery.
7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).
9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.  
___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.
10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
visit in three (3) weeks.
11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Physical Therapy:
ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Treatments Frequency:
WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay 
to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or 
submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. 
Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if 
there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound 
regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow 
drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up visit in 
three (3) weeks.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old female with a history of multiple 
previous abdominal surgeries who presented this admission with 
abdominal pain and emesis. CT abd/pelvis revealed a small bowel 
obstruction with a transition point in the right lower quadrant 
adjacent to ventral hernia repair mesh.  She was made NPO, had a 
NGT placed to low continuous wall suction and started on IVF.  
On HD1, the patient passed flatus and had minimal NGT output, so 
her NGT was removed. Her admission EKG showed new ST depressions 
in the anterior, left axis and troponins were sent which were 
negative. CXR was unremarkable. 

On HD2, the patient was advanced to a regular diet which was 
well-tolerated. The patient was ordered oxycodone for a 
migraine. The patient was later febrile to 103,  urinalysis, 
urine culture and blood culture were ordered.  There was no 
leukocytosis.  CXR was unremarkable.  

On HD3, the patient reported facial and ear pain and she was 
diagnosed with acute sinusitis.  Given her allergy to 
penicillin, she was started on Azithromycin.  The patient has a 
history of migraines and PO fioricet prn was started. A social 
work consult was placed to address her current housing and 
coping issues. 

On HD4, the patient was again febrile to 103 at night time and 
she received acetaminophen with good effect.  On HD5, the 
patient reported her facial pain had greatly improved, was 
afebrile and reported no abdominal pain.  She had a bowel 
movement and was passing flatus. 

The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization; 
pain was initially managed with po oxycodone and acetaminophen.  
Oxycodone was discontinued as she reported her pain had 
improved. The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. The patient 
remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were 
routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and 
incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
The patient's intake and output were closely monitored.  The 
patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs of 
bleeding, of which there were none. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots were used during this 
stay and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge with the aid of 
___ interpreter services.  Teaching and follow-up 
instructions were discussed with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan. A follow-up appointment was 
scheduled with the patient's Primary Care Provider.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital with a small bowel 
obstruction. You were managed non-operatively and had a tube 
placed in your nose into your stomach to help decompress your 
abdomen.  Your obstruction resolved on its own and the tube was 
removed.  You are now having bowel function, tolerating a 
regular diet, and your pain is better controlled.  

You were also diagnosed with acute sinusitis, an infection of 
your sinuses which can cause facial pain and fevers.  You were 
started on an antibiotic called Azithromycin and will be 
discharged with a prescription.  

You are now medically cleared to be discharged home to continue 
your recovery.  Please note the following discharge 
instructions: 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY
___ year old woman with a PMH DM, HTN, HLD, Asthma, and multiple 
abdominal surgeries after a complicated oophorectomy, who 
presents with 2 weeks worsening epigastric pain and acute kidney 
injury. She was resuscitated with fluids with subsequent 
resolution of ___. Given persistent abdominal pain concerning 
for PUD vs gastritis, she underwent endoscopy on ___ which 
showed patchy erythema. Biopsies were taken, and she was 
discharged with close GI and PCP ___. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
===============
#Abdominal Pain, possible dyspepsia
Patient presented with 2 weeks of epigastric pain, worse with 
meals, unrelieved by PPI therapy. She has a prolonged history of 
abdominal
surgeries following an oophorectomy with subsequent sigmoid 
perforation. On admission, CT showed no evidence SBO or 
pathology at her previous anastomosis. She was empirically 
treated with IV antibiotics over concern for intraabdominal 
infection. However, she remained afebrile with no leukocytosis, 
with overall low concern for infection, so antibiotics were 
stopped upon arrival to the floor. Recal occult blood test was 
negative. Her pain is likely secondary to gastritis vs peptic 
ulcer disease. 

GI was consulted for endoscopy given her history of gastritis 
and failure of a PPI trial. Endoscopy was performed on ___ and 
showed patchy erythema. Biopsies were taken, and patient will 
follow up in GI clinic with Dr. ___ (fellow). Her home 
omeprazole 20 mg PO BID was continued. Dicyclomine was changed 
to four times a day. H. pylori antibody testing was negative.

#Acute kidney injury
Creatinine was 2.3 on admission, likely secondary to pre-renal 
zotemia, ___ to hypovolemia in the setting of poor po intake 
from continued abdominal pain. Her Creatinine was 1.0 on 
discharge. Furosemide was held on admission and at discharge. 
Lisinopril was held on admission and restarted at discharge. 

CHRONIC PROBLEMS
================
# Pancytopenia: Stable throughout admission. 

# HTN: Furosemide was held on admission and at discharge. 
Lisinopril was held on admission and restarted at discharge. 

# HLD: Home simvastatin was continued.

# Chronic back pain: Gabapentin was continued at reduced renal 
dose until resolution of ___. Tylenol and Tramadol were given 
PRN. 

# Asthma:
Home regimen was continued: Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus, 
Fluticasone Propionate, Cetirizine and Montelukast.

# Psych: Home regimen was continued: Fluoxetine, Clonazepam, 
Quetiapine

# Diabetes Mellitus: Lantus 20 units in the morning and HISS 
were given in the hospital. Metformin, glipizide and sitagliptin 
were held. She will resume her home regimen.

===================

Patient is a ___ with history of NASH, anemia/thrombocytopenia,

ACUTE ISSUES:  
==========================    
#FEVER:
#OCCIPTAL SCALP CELLULITIS:
#OCCIPTAL SCALP ABSCESS 
Patient presented with ___ of worsening occipital scalp
tenderness and swelling, found to have a 3-4cm area consistent 
with cellulitis. Patient was febrile to 102.7 in the ED, 
otherwise was without leukocytosis (neutrophilic predominant, no 
bands). Given signs of possible systemic toxicity (fever, 
borderline BP upon arrival to the floor), continued MRSA in 
addition to strep coverage with vancomycin which was then 
transitioned to cefazolin.  Additionally, due to persistent 
fever on antibiotics as well as neck pain, a CT neck, and torso 
were obtained which showed emerging abcess. Abscess developed 
with purulent discharge. ACS was consulted and she underwent 
I&D. A She did well and antibiotics were narrowed to cephalexin 
to complete ten day course from day of I&D, end date ___. 

#NAUSEA AND ABDOMINAL PAIN:   
Patient has a history of multiple intraabdominal surgeries, 
additional GERD/gastritis (taking meloxicam daily). No BM for 
over 24 hours upon admission. The patient complained of 
worsening abdominal distention with associated nausea/emesis. 
Etiologies considered were bowel obstruction vs. PUD vs. 
evolving gastritis vs. SBP with known history of NASH +/- 
cirrhosis. Of note, patient was admitted ___ with abdominal 
pain and nausea/vomiting, symptoms thought to be related to 
gastritis/PUD. RUQUS without e/o ascites. KUB without evidence 
of ileus or obstruction. The morning that the day team picked up 
the patient, her abdominal exam was significantly improved and 
she only had mild tenderness to palpation. There were no further 
issues with this. 

#ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY:  
Cr was previously ~1, though increased to 1.3 ___ iso ED 
presentation for N/V/D. Suspected prerenal iso GI losses and 
poor PO intake, exacerbated by ongoing ACE-I and furosemide 
administration. No signs of UTI on UA. s/p 3L IVF in ED. Held 
home lisinopril and furosemide. After further IVF and stopping 
vancomycin the patient's ___ resolved.

==========================
#THROMBOCYTOPENIA: 
#NORMOCYTIC ANEMIA: 
Chronic, possible related to underlying liver disease (reported

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

   It was a pleasure looking after you.  As you know, you were 
admitted with dizziness and back pain.  You were found to have a 
urinary tract infection which likely involved your kidney as 
well.  This may partly account for your back pain.   You were 
treated with intravenous antibiotics and switched to oral 
antibiotics once the urine cultures identified the bacteria 
(E.coli) and confirmed its sensitivity to the antibiotic you are 
being prescribed.
   
   Please complete the antibiotics (Cefpodoxime) for an 
additional 8 days to complete a 10 day course.  Otherwise, to 
avoid future urinary tract infection, please ensure that you are 
well hydrated and that your diabetes is in good control.  This 
will prevent future urinary tract infections from happening.  

 You were also found to be dehydrated and with mild acute kidney 
injury.  After hydration, your kidney function improved.  Please 
insure good oral intake of fluids and good control of sugars 
(higher sugars can lead to loss of water). 

 You may have a component of musculoskeletal back pain too.  For 
this, we recommend following with your medical doctor and taking 
acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed. 

There are otherwise, no changes to your medication.  We wish you 
a quick recovery!

Your ___ team.

# Afib with RVR
#?Junctional rhythm
On ___ noted to have wide complex rhythm on telemetry. 
Cardiology was consulted and it was felt that this rhythm 
represents conversion from Afib to wide rhythm to sinus. ___ be 
exacerbated by increased burden of afib in setting of infection 
and high dose of Sotalol.  Sotalol was discontinued. The patient 
had an episode of afib with RVR requiring IV metoprolol and Iv 
diltiazem. He then converted to sinus rhythm and remains in

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your admission to 
___. You were admitted with an infection of your right ___ 
toe. You were seen by the podiatry team and had an amputation of 
your ___ toe. You will continue daily dressing changes. The 
vascular surgeons did testing that showed you have adequate 
blood flow to your foot. We have scheduled outpatient follow up 
with the vascular surgery team. You were seen by the infectious 
disease doctors and they recommended long term intravenous 
antibiotics to treat a possible bone infection. You had a PICC 
line placed for these antibiotics. It is important that you do 
not put weight on your right foot. You have been prescribed an 
increased dose of your oxycodone. Opiate pain medications can 
cause constipation, respiratory depression, can be addictive and 
can cause death. It is important that you take the lowest 
effective dose for the shortest time possible.

While you were in the hospital, you also had an abnormal heart 
rhythm. You had an ultrasound of your heart (Echo) which showed 
normal cardiac function. Your sotalol was stopped. You should 
follow up with your cardiologist.

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital after a 
peripheral angiogram and for your left second toe infection. 

Instructions Regarding Peripheral Angiogram:
 To do the test, a small puncture was made in one of your 
arteries.  The puncture site heals on its own: there are no 
stitches to remove.   Please follow the recommendations below to 
ensure a speedy and uneventful recovery.
Peripheral Angiography
Puncture Site Care
For one week:
-Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot 
tub.
-Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around 
the puncture site. 
-Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. 
-Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the 
puncture site. 

You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the 
procedure.  You may leave the bandage off. 
You may have a small bruise around the puncture site.  This is 
normal and will go away one-two weeks. 

Activity 
For the first 48 hours: 
- Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure
For the first week:
-Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 
pounds
-Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold 
your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles.   Take care not 
to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, 
or moving your bowels.
After one week:
- You may go back to all your regular activities, including 
sexual activity.  We suggest you begin your exercise program at 
half of your usual routine for the first few days.   You may 
then gradually work back to your full routine.

For  Problems or Questions:
Call ___ in an emergency such as:
-Sudden, brisk bleeding or swelling at the groin puncture site 
that does not stop after applying pressure for ___ minutes
-Bleeding that is associated with nausea, weakness, or fainting.

Call the vascular surgery office (___) right away if 
you have any of the following. (Please note that someone is 
available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week)
-Swelling, bleeding, drainage, or discomfort at the puncture 
site that is new or increasing since discharge from the hospital
-Any change in sensation or temperature in your legs
-Fever of 101 or greater
-Any questions or concerns about recovery from your angiogram 

Instructions Regarding your Left Foot Surgery:

ACTIVITY:
There are restrictions on activity. Please remain heel weight 
bearing to your left foot until your follow up appointment. You 
should keep this site elevated when ever possible (above the 
level of the heart!) 

No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.

PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS:
Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s).
New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toes.
Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever 
greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus 
draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these 
or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR.

Exercise:
Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks.
No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next ___ days.
Try to keep leg elevated when able.

BATHING/SHOWERING:
You may shower immediately upon coming home, but you must keep 
your dressing CLEAN, DRY and INTACT. You can use a shower bag 
taped around your ankle/leg or hang your foot/leg outside of the 
bathtub. 

Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for 4 
weeks after surgery or until cleared by your physician.

MEDICATIONS:
Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the 
medications you were taking before surgery. 
Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you 
should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check 
with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel 
that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may 
use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite 
suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small 
balanced meals throughout the day. 

DIET:
There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. 
Poor appetite is not unusual for several weeks and small, 
frequent meals may be preferred.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
Be sure to keep your medical appointments. 
If a follow up appointment was not made prior to your discharge, 
please call the office on the first working day after your 
discharge from the hospital to schedule a follow-up visit. This 
should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days 
after discharge. Normal office hours are ___ 
through ___.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR 
QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE.

# Oral surgery complicated by L submandibular and lateral 
pharyngeal space abscess s/p I&D of left submandibular and 
lateral pharyngeal spaces (___): patient was transferred from 
OSH due to development of neck cellulitis associated with airway 
compromise following an oral surgery procedure. She was taken to 
the OR by OMFS for I&D and drain placement n ___ and was 
transferred to the MICU following the procedure for airway 
monitoring. She was initiated on IV clindamycin/vancomycin. 
Following the procedure she became acutely hypertensive 
requiring IV medication. She was evaluated by ENT with 
fiberscope with findings notable for pharyngeal edema; she 
received decadron 10mg TID x1 day with resolution of edema on 
repeat fiberscope. Given stability, she was transferred to the 
floor. She tolerated an advanced diet. She was continued on 
peridex mouth rinse BID. She was re-evaluated by ___ and her 
drain was pulled on ___. She was transitioned to a po regimen 
of clindamycin with plan to complete x14 day course. 

#Chest pain, likely takotsubo's cardiomyopathy: patient was 
originally called out to the floor on ___ however prior to 
transfer she developed crushing substernal chest pain. She was 
started on nitro gtt and received high-dose aspirin, metoprolol, 
atorvastatin, and was started on a heparin gtt. ECG was notable 
for inferior and posterior ST-segment elevations and reciprocal 
depressions. Cardiology was consulted and the patient was sent 
from the MICU for cardiac catheterization on ___ which was 
notable for 50% occlusion of D1, no interventions. Given no 
occlusive lesions, and given clinical picture of sudden onset 
chest pain and associated septal hypokinesis on echo, this was 
consistent with takotsubo's cardiomyopathy vs vasospasm. The 
patient was transitioned to 81 mg aspirin, 80mg atorvastatin, 10 
mg Q8H nifidipine (for vasospasm) with goal SBP <140; 
beta-blockers were initially avoided given low HRs. Echo on ___ 
notable for septal hypokinesis, repeat ECG notable for TWI in 
V1-V2. Due to persistent hypertension with above regimen, she 
was transitioned to carvedilol 6.25mg BID. She was discharged on 
asa, statin, and carvedilol. 

#Hypoxia: Patient developed new O2 requirement on ___, requiring 
uptitration of NC from 2L to 4L on ___. Her lung exam was clear 
bilaterally. She underwent CXR on ___ without acute process, and 
CTA on ___ with no acute processes. Concern for atelectasis vs 
aspiration vs splinting. She used the incentive spirometer 
successfully and walked with ___. She was weaned off O2 and 
remained stable. 

#Diarrhea: during hospital course, patient developed large 
volume, watery BMs assoc with urgency. Differential inlcu 
antibiotic-induced vs c diff vs infectious. Stool cultures were

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ due to swelling of your neck. An 
abscess, or pocket of infection, was found which was drained by 
the Oral Surgeons. The procedure went well; drain was placed 
into the abscess and you were started on antibiotics. You should 
continue to take clindamycin 300mg four times daily, your last 
day will be ___. You should continue Peridex mouth rinse 
swish and spit twice daily and change your dressing daily. You 
should continue to take Tylenol ___ up to four times daily for 
pain; please do not exceed 4gm per day as this can be bad for 
your liver.

After your procedure you were monitored in the Intensive Care 
Unit. The procedure went well; however following the procedure 
you were found to have ongoing swelling inside your throat. You 
received intravenous steroids which helped with the throat 
swelling. In addition, your blood pressure became very high and 
you developed severe chest pain; imaging and lab work showed 
that you had a myocardial infarction, also known as a heart 
attack. You were evaluated by the Cardiologists and a procedure 
called a catheterization was performed to look closely at the 
blood vessels in your heart. You were started on medications to 
help prevent future heart attacks; you will need to continue 
taking aspirin 81mg daily, atorvastatin 80mg daily, and 
carvedilol 6.25mg twice daily. You will need to follow up 
closely with a Cardiologist. 

Thank you for letting us be a part of your care!
Your ___ Team

# Acute pancreatitis
Patient has a questionable history of pancreatitis in ___ that 
developed after receiving morphine which raises suspicion for 
sphincter of oddi dysfunction. Since then she has been doing 
well with no admissions for pancreatitis until now. She now 
presents with epigastric pain radiating to back with elevated 
lipase above 3x ULN, consistent with pancreatitis. CT did not 
show any evidence of pancreatitis, however not always 
informative in early pancreatitis. Etiology is most likely due

trauma. She is not on steroids, and her triglycerides are 
normal. The patient was managed with bowel rest and IV fluids. 
Her pain resolved quickly an her diet was advanced which she 
tolerated without pain. She was counseled on alcohol cessation.

currently has LFT pattern consistent with hepatocellular injury 
likely due to ETOH intake. Should have repeat LFTs at PCP follow

TEE: Conclusions
The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. A 
very small left-to-right shunt across the interatrial septum 
consistent with a small secundum atrial septal defect is present 
at rest. A catheter is seen in the right atrium near the 
tricuspid valve. Overall left ventricular systolic function is 
normal (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear 
structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic 
regurgitation. No masses or vegetations are seen on the aortic 
valve. No aortic valve abscess is seen. The mitral valve appears 
structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. No mass 
or vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. No mitral valve 
abscess is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. There are two echodense structures on the tricuspid 
valve (probably on the anterior leaflet) consistent with 
moderate sized vegetations, each measuring approximately 1.1 
centimeters by 0.5 centimeters. Moderate eccentric tricuspid 
regurgitation. No abscess is visualized. There is no pericardial 
effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Two moderate sized tricuspid valve vegetations 
measuring 1.1 cm by 0.5 cm on the tricuspid valve. Moderate 
eccentric tricuspid regurgitation. No abscess of the tricuspid 
valve. Catheter tip visualized in the right atrium near the 
tricuspid valve. Recommend withdrawing the catheter 2 to 3 
centimeters to minimize risk of trauma to the tricuspid valve.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
 Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o female with a h/o regular ___ 
transferred from ___ with right sided MRSA 
endocarditis with persistently positive blood cultures
.
#) Endocarditis: she was transferred with a report of 
intermittently positive blood cultures for MRSA, a large 1x0.6cm 
vegetation on her tricuspid valve along with septic emboli in 
her lungs.  At the time of admission there was concern that she 
remained persistently bacteremic despite over a week of IV 
antibiotics.  Infectious disease was consulted and recommended 
removal of her PICC line, daily surveillance blood cultures, a 
TEE and continued treatment with linezolid pending daptomycin 
sensitivities.  After removal of her PICC line, all of her blood 
cultures drawn at ___ were negative, which was concerning for 
possible seeding of the PICC line causing continued positive 
blood cultures at the OSH.  In order for daptomycin 
sensitivities to be done a culture of the MRSA was transferred 
from ___ to the microbiology lab at ___ for 
daptomycin sensitivity testing, after the determination that the 
MRSA was sensitive to daptomycin her antibiotic coverage was 
changed to daptomycin.  On ___ she underwent a TEE that 
showed two moderate sized (1.1cmx0.5cm)  vegetations on her 
tricuspid valve, a small ASD,  but did find any evidence of an 
abscess or left sided involvement.  After the TEE was done 
cardiac surgery was consulted to answer the question about need 
for possible ASD repair, given the concern for possible 
embolization of part of the vegetation that could cross to the 
left side of the heart.  After evaluation by cardiac surgery 
they felt that she did not need a surgical intervention at this 
time but would need a repeat echocardiogram in ___ weeks.  At 
the time of discharge she needed to complete a 4 week course of 
IV daptomycin that began on ___.  
.
#) Pneumonia/Septic Emboli: per OSH records, CT scan with 
multiple septic emboli, nodular opacities and infiltrates and 
she initially had a 4L oxygen requirement.  At the time of 
admission a CT scan of her torso was done that showed numerous 
bilateral cavitary pulmonary nodules consistent with septic 
emboli.  As she was continued on her IV antibiotics her oxygen 
requirement and pulmonary status improved, to the point that she 
no longer had an oxygen requirement and her dyspnea was 
significantly improved.  
.
#) IV Drug Use: Patient with a history of IV heroin and cocaine 
use, up until the day prior to her admission at ___ 
___.  She was started on clonidine for help with her 
withdrawal symptoms.  With her history of IVDU and hepatitis C, 
all hepatitis serologies were checked as was HIV.  Her HIV was 
negative, and her hepatitis serologies showed that she was 
immune to hepatitis B but not A.  She was seen by social work 
who gave her information about outpatient treatment programs and 
she endorsed a desire to try to stop IV drug use after her 
discharge.  With a PICC in place she was screened for rehab 
placement, as she would not be able to leave the hospital with a 
PICC in place.  
.
#) Hepatitis C: Patient with h/o untreated Hep C, presumably 
from IVDU, this was confirmed by a positive Hepatitis C 
antibody, but her viral load was negative.  Given that she was 
not immune to hepatitis A, she was given the first vaccine in 
the Hep A series on ___, she will need to complete the 
series as an outpatient. 
.
#) Decreased Hearing: A few days into her hospital stay at 
___ she developed decreased hearing, which was thought to be 
due to combination of a bilateral otitis media and vancomycin 
ototoxicity.  In the hospital she was seen by ENT who felt that 
she had conductive hearing loss due to cerumen impaction.  After 
colace to help soften the ear wax, it was still unable to be 
removed, so she was set up with an outpatient ENT appointment 
for removal of the impacted cerumen.

flow and dilated right ventricle suggesting a signicant 
intracardiac shunt. Mild mitral regurgitation. Mild symmetric 
left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional 
biventricular systolic function. Dilated ascending aorta.
If clinically indicated, a TEE would be best able to better 
define the interatrial septum. A cardiac MRI would be best able 
to quantify the intracardiac shunt.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ right handed previously healthy 
male transferred from OSH with acute right cerebellar infarct in 
territory of right ___.  He presented to OSH after having an 
episode of dizziness, sweating, and nausea and vomiting.  He 
also had a feeling of being too weak to walk.   His neurologic 
exam is normal with the exception of very subtle dysmetria on 
the R side.  While at the OSH, after the administration of a 
nitro patch the patient developed an occiptal headache that was 
constant, with some relief with NSAIDs and tylenol.  

He was transferred to the ___ ICU, for concern about 
verterbral artery dissection and concern for possible edema in 
the posterior fossa.  A MRI/MRA was obtain that confirmed the 
location of a cerebellar infarct.  The MRA showed an occluded 
right vertebral artery.  It could not be determined from the fat 
suppression images if there was just an occlusion of the 
vertebral artery or a dissection.  An echo was also obtained 
which showed a moderate ASD with left to right shunting, with 
some dilation of the right ventricle.  Given this finding and 
the concern for a possible dissection, the decision was made to 
start the patient on a heparin drip with a bridge to coumadin.  
The patient did not have evidence on lower extremity doppler of 
any DVT.  A hyper coagulable workup was initiated.  He had 
negative dopplers of his lower extremities.  A follow up CTA was 
performed but the contrast was injected on the left side, and 
there was not significant enough flow to get a good image of the 
right vertebral artery. 

Cardiology was consulted and determined that the ASD would meet 
criteria for repair.  However they wanted to delay this repair 
until the patient has had his full course of coumadin.

The patient was transferred out of the unit to the floor on 
___. He was closely monitored on floor. He was started on 
lovenox injections for anticoagulation and put on coumadin, with 
goal INR of ___. He was advised to stop lovenox once the INR 
becomes therapeutic and follow with primary care doctor for dose 
adustemnt of couamdin. LDL was high 130 and he was started on 
simvastatin for that. He was advised to follow with cardiology 
for further management of ASD.

He was seen by physical therapy who suggested outpatient ___ for 
gait and functional stability for few days. His exam at 
discharge was significant for very mild cerebellar signs on 
right side.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  Mr. ___ was admitted and underwent
central line placement to begin therapy. His admission weight
was 113.8 kg and he received interleukin II 600,000
international units per kilo equaling 68.3 million units IV
every 8 hours times 14 potential doses. During this week he
received 10 of 14 doses with 4 doses held related to
increased trache secretions and probable pulmonary edema. He
was also noted to have early neurotoxicity, prompting further
therapy to be held. On treatment day #5, he was noted to be
restless overnight without improvement with Ativan. Frequent
safety checks were instituted per nursing policy.
Additionally on treatment day #5 increased trache secretions
and coughing were noted and the patient became dyspneic with
exertion. He was treated with albuterol with improvement. IV
fluids were reduced and diuresis with Lasix was initiated
with improvement in symptoms.

Other side effects during this week included nausea improved
with Compazine; development of an erythematous pruritic skin
rash; fatigue; diarrhea improved with Lomotil therapy; rigors
improved with Demerol; and flu-like symptoms.

During this week he had no acute renal failure noted. He
developed transaminitis with a peak ALT of 130 and peak AST
of 161. He developed hyperbilirubinemia with a peak bilirubin
of 4.6. He was anemic without the need for packed red blood
cell transfusion. He developed thrombocytopenia with a
platelet count low of 93,000 without evidence of bleeding. He
had an elevated CK level on admission with normal CK-MB and
troponin level. Throughout his hospitalization, CK level rose
to a peak of 635. His troponin remained normal despite
elevated CK. CK-MB was elevated at 13 with normalization by
the day of discharge. Additionally his CK level markedly
improved to 279 on the day of discharge. This was not felt to
be consistent with myocarditis. He had no coagulopathy or
metabolic acidosis noted.

He did develop urinary retention attributed to being off
Hytrin due to concern for hypotension. He had a Foley briefly
placed and this was discontinued prior to discharge with
normal voiding pattern. By ___, he was ready for
discharge to home.

You were admitted to the hospital due to coughing up blood. You 
were monitored closely, especially considering that you are on 
Coumadin, and you did not have any significant new bleeding.

for the next 5 days, and with cautious intensity.  Please follow 
up with your Oncologist to determine if further evaluation or 
managemetn is necessary. Please seek immediate medical attention 
if you have further episodes of coughing up blood, especially if 
the blood appears fresh and/or if it is in increasing 
quantities, or if you feel short of breath or chest pains.  You 
may continue to cough up old, thick, darker blood from your 
prior bleed, and this is OK as long as the quantity is small and 
decreasing in amount.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with metastatic renal cell carcinoma admitted 
with progressive headaches and right hemanopsia and found to 
have worsening hemorrhagic mass in the left parietal/occipital 
region and admitted to the ICU for medical management.
.
# Hemorrhagic brain metastasis: Patient with renal cell 
carcinoma, known brain metastasis, and currently on Lovenox for 
anticoagulation. Head CT on admission was remarkable for an 
enlarged edematous and hemorrhagic mass extending into the 
occipital and parietal lobes, which explained right homonymous 
hemianopsia. Anticoagulation was stopped and Neurosurgery was 
was consulted, who recommended no intervention until greater 
than 2 weeks after his last dose of Avastin. He was admitted to 
the FICU and monitored with serial neuro checks. Head CT was 
repeated which showed no progression for hemorrheage/edema. His 
blood pressure was initially controlled with a Nicardipine gtt 
(goal sBP 120-140) and his head of bed was maintained >30 
degrees. Repeat CT head imaging was stable. Per Neuro-Oncology 
he was started on Nimodipine for prevention of vasospasm, Keppra 
for seizure prophylaxis, and his Dexamethasone was decreased 
from 6 mg to 4 mg q6h. He remained stable and was transferred to 
the OMED service for further management.  His Dexamethasone was 
tapered and he was discharged on Dexamethasone 4mg Daily.  
Repeat MRI on ___ showed stable intracranial process.  On 
___ he had an episode of hypertension and was otherwise 
asymptomatic.  He was restarted on his home medications - 
hydrochlorothiazide 25mg PO daily and metoprolol tartrate 50mg 
PO BID.  His nimodipine was changed to PRN, but he did not 
require any doses and was not continued at the time of 
discharge.  His Right Homonymous hemianopsia persisted and is 
not expected to resolve.
.
# Increased intracranial pressure: Patient complained of 
worsening headache on admission and was bradycardic and 
hypertensive ___ components of ___ triad). HOB was 
maintained >30. Headache improved and experienced no change in 
neurologic examination to suggest herniation or increased ICP. 
Bradycardia and hypertension resolved. 
.
# Hypertension: Given concern for acute hemorrheage we aimed to 
maintain SBP 120-140. This was initially achieved with a 
Nicardipine gtt, which was turned off on hospital day 2. He was 
also initially continued on his outpatient Metoprolol Tartrate 
50 BID, which was held in the setting of starting Nimodipine for 
vasospasm to prevent relative hypotension.  On ___ he had an 
episode of hypertension and was otherwise asymptomatic.  He was 
restarted on his home medications - hydrochlorothiazide 25mg PO 
daily and metoprolol tartrate 50mg PO BID.  His nimodipine was 
changed to PRN, but he did not require any doses and was not 
continued at the time of discharge.  
.
# Pulmonary embolisms: Patient has a history of recurrent 
pulmonary emboli, and was previously anticoagulated with 
warfarin and then changed to Lovenox ___. Given hemorrhagic 
brain mets, future anticoagulation is contraindicated. Bilateral 
lower extremity ultrasounds were negative for DVT. He underwent 
placement of an IVC filter on ___ by Interventional Radiology 
to prevent future clot propogation. 
.
# Hemoptysis: Possibly related to multiple pulmonary metastasis 
in the setting of anitcoagulation. New pulmonary embolism is 
unlikely given absence of tachycardia or hypoxia. He was 
provided with humidified oxygen. His O2 saturations remained 
adequate on room air. 
.
# Acute on Chronic Kidney disease: Baseline Cr appears to be 
1.3-1.4. The patient's Cr was at baseline on admission, and 
increased in the setting of diuresis. He was bolused 500 cc of 
NS and repeat electrolytes revealed improvement in creatinine.  
His creatinine remained stable for the rest of his hospital 
stay. 
.
# Hyponatremia: Thought to be secondary to SIADH given 
underlying intracranial and pulmonary disease. Serum cortisol 
was normal. Urine lytes revealed sodium avidity with a highly 
concentrated urine, likely a mixed picture (dehydration with 
underlying SIADH). He was given IVFs with subsequent improvment 
in sodium.  At the time of discharge his Na was 136.
.
# Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma: Patient diagnosed with RCC 
after biopsy of metastatic pulmonary lesion. He has metastatic 
involvment of brain, spinal cord, lungs and larynx. In ___ he 
was treated with tracheostomy for laryngeal mass. Admission 
chest xray showed worsening of pulmonary metastatic disease.  
His hemorrhagic brain mass has been well controlled with steroid 
therapy.  He has stabilized since admission and is doing well.  
He will continue to receive dexamethasone in the outpatient 
setting and follow up with his outpatient oncologists.
.
# Chronic low back pain with neuropathy: Patient is on 
gabapentin and oxydonone for chronic low back pain and 
neuropathy. Gabapentin was initially held on admission to avoid 
sedating medications and pain was controled with oxycodone + 
oxycontin at home dose.  His pain was relatively well controlled 
and his gabapentin was restarted at the time of discharge.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment and Plan: A ___ year-old male with metastatic renal 
cell carcinoma w/ recent admission for hemorrhage or metastatic 
brain mass p/w syncopal episode likely ___ drug effect 
complicated by vasovagal event.
.  
# Syncope:  There was initial concern for medication induced 
syncope coupled with orthostasis.  His metoprolol was 
discontinued in order to ensure we are not blocking a 
physiologic tachycardia and we also stopped terazosin 5mg PO 
QHS.  We started lisinopril 5mg PO daily for blood pressure 
control.  He was encouraged to drink a lot of fluid overnight 
and he was asymptomatic overnight with no events on telemetry.  
BP has been stable on the new regiment of hydrochlorothiazide 
and lisinopril.  Orthostatics were negative and creatinine has 
trended back to baseline.  EEG was negative to rule out seizure 
activiity.  He was conitnued on his keppra.  He was scheduled to 
go back to Rehab, but after much conversation it was decided 
that he would go home to hospice.    
.  
# Chronic low back pain with neuropathy: Patient is on 
gabapentin and oxydonone for chronic low back pain and 
neuropathy.  His pain had been difficult to control and after an 
after a night with a pain crisis, and development of urinary 
retention we got a MRI of the L spine to rule out cord 
compression.  The patient had known mets in the area, but there 
was no signs of cord compression.  His medications were titrated 
up and he was eventually discharged on oxycontin 40mg PO Q12H, 
Oxycodone ___ PO Q4H:PRN and gabapentin 300mg ___ and 
500mg QHS.  His pain was much better controlled on this 
regiment. 
.
# Metastatic renal cell: Patient diagnosed with RCC after biopsy 
of metastatic pulmonary lesion. He has metastatic involvment of 
brain, spinal cord, lungs and larynx. In ___ he was treated 
with tracheostomy for laryngeal mass. Admission chest x-ray 
shows worsening of pulmonary metastatic disease and also with 
brain mets that recently hemorrhaged, but is now stable.  CT 
scan in the ED showed stable brain lesion.  EEG was done to rule 
out seizure related to hemorrhagic mass.  He was continued on 
keppra 500mg PO BID and dexamethasone 5mg PO Daily.  He was also 
continued on Avastin as scheduled.  
.
# Bilateral DVT: While in house the patient developed right 
lower extremity edema.  His RLE was tense, but pulses were 
dopplerable.  Duplex U/S showed Extensive right lower extremity 
DVT from calf.  vascular was consulted and given the 
extensiveness of the clot and inability to anti-coagulate given 
recent sub-dural hemmorhage that conservative management was the 
best option.  Compression stocking and ACE wrap and elevation of 
the right leg significantly improved the edema and pain.  A 
pneumoboot was placed on his left leg for DVT prevention, but 2 
days later he developed LLE swelling and repeat U/S showed 
extensive clot on the left.  It was treated similarly to the 
right.
.
# Goals Of Care: At the beginning of this admission, the plan 
was to stabilize the patient's syncopal symptoms and discharge 
back to Rehab.  After the developments of extensive bilateral 
clots, we had a goals of care discussion with his family.  He 
initially wanted to speak with his priest prior to making any 
decisions.  However, the following day, he decided to make 
himself DNR/DNI and wanted a palliative care consult.  
Palliative care became involved and helped a lot with pain 
control.  In addition, we decided to start screening the patient 
for hospice placement.  The wait was extensive and he was going 
to be discharged to Rehab and then to Hospice, but ultimately 
they decided they wanted to go home with hospice.  Home hospice 
was organized and he was sent home with hospice and follow up if 
he desired.
.
# Acute on Chronic Kidney disease: Creatinine 1.4 on admission, 
but 1.1 on Day 2 of admission with baseline 1.0.  Patient was 
likely intravascularly dry given rise in creatinine that 
resolved with fluids.  He had a bump in his creatinine to 1.4 on 
day 4 that again resolved with fluids and increased PO intake.  
At the time of discharge, he was hydrating well and on the day 
of discharge his creatinine was 1.1.
.
# hypertension:  Patient was normotensive during this admission. 
 His metoprolol 50mg PO BID and terazosin 5mg PO QHS was 
discontinued and lisinopril 5mg PO daily was started.  His BP 
remained within normal limits during the course of his hospital 
stay.  
.
# Pulmonary embolism: Patient with recurrent pulmonary emboli, 
previously anticoagulated with warfarin and then changed to 
lovenox ___. Given hemorrhagic brain metastasis, 
anticoagulation is contraindicated. Status-post IVC filter 
placement by ___.  Was placed on pneumoboots for the duration of 
his hospital stay. 
.

Brief Hospital Course:
#Cellulitis around the trach site: The development of the 
patient's cellulitis was thought to be due to recent 
instrumantation of the trach site (s/p flexible laryngoscopy and 
tracheoscopy on ___ by ENT. The patient received 1 dose of 
Keflex and 2 doses of vancomycin in the ED without improvement 
in the patient's symptoms, and thus was admitted. The patient 
was continued on IV vancomycin upon admission to the floor. With 
improvement in the erythema and swelling the patient was 
transitioned to oral bactrim double strength and augmentin 750mg 
every 12 hours. The patient was monitored clinically after the 
transition to oral antibiotics was made, and his erythema 
continued to improve. He was afebrile through the admission and 
blood cultures were monitored. Erythema markedly improved with 
antibiotics. The patient was discharged home with 9 more days of 
oral bactrim and augmentin to complete a 12 day course of 
antibiotics. 
.
#Metastatic renal cell: Patient diagnosed with RCC after biopsy 
of metastatic pulmonary lesion. He has metastatic involvment of 
brain, spinal cord, lungs and larynx. Currently on seizure 
prophylaxis. The patient was continued on his home doseing of 
Keppra- 500mg twice daily. The patient was also continued on 
dexamethasone 1mg daily during his hospital admission.  
.
#History of recurrent pulmonary embolism: Patient with recurrent 
pulmonary emboli, previously anticoagulated with warfarin and 
then changed to lovenox ___. Given hemorrhagic brain 
metastasis, anticoagulation is contraindicated. Status-post IVC 
filter placement by ___. For prophylaxis, the patient had ___ 
hose on at all time. He was also ambulatory through the 
admission. 
.
#Constipation: Likely related to narcotics. Patient was 
maintained on senna, colace and miralax. Mild of magnesia was 
also given to help with constipation.  
. 
#Chronic low back pain with neuropathy: Patient is on gabapentin 
and oxydonone for chronic low back pain and neuropathy. Home 
regimen was continued through the admission.   
.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay at ___ 
___.

You were admitted with cellulitis at your trachae site. You 
received Iv antibiotics. The redness receeded from the borders 
marked on your admission from to the emergency room. You 
breathing status was stable through the admission and was not 
compromised by the cellulitis at your trach site.

Please take all medications as instructed.

You are being discharged home on two (2) antibiotics that you 
will take for another eight (8) days to complete a full course 
of antibiotics. Take Bactrim Double Strength 1 tablet by mouth 
twice daily and take Augmentin (Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid) 1 
tablet by mouth every 12 hours. 

Please monitor your trach area for signs of worsening infection; 
these signs include worsening redness at the trach site, 
extension of skin redness, pain at the trach site, drainage from 
the trach site, swelling, fevers, and chills. If you start to 
have fevers or notice any worsening symptoms or have any 
concerns, return to the emergency department for further 
evaluation. 

Please keep all follow-up appointments as scheduled. These 
appointments are listed below. During your appointment with Dr. 
___ on ___ please have him re-evaluate the trach site.

Brief Hospital Course:
#Sepsis secondary to pyelonephritis
Mrs. ___ presented with pyelonephritis in the setting of 
recent nephrolithiasis s/p recent stenting and subsequent stent 
removal on ___. The patient was seen by Dr. ___ at 
___ on ___ who recomended lithotripsy and stenting at that 
time in the setting of her known nephrolithiasis. U/S showed 
persistent residual caliectasis for which she underwent 
cystoscopy and left distal ureteroscopy on ___. This did not 
reveal residual stone, rather a left ureterovesicular 
stricture/edema which was stented (6 x ___ double J). 
Impression was that she had ureteral stenosis/stricture as the 
result of an impacted UPJ stone. 

The stent was subsequently removed on ___ after which the 
patient presented to the ED with signs and symptoms concerning 
for pyelonephritis. Repeat CT A/P Non-Con (___) showed no 
evidence of nephrolithiasis, mild L. hydroureter w/ adjacent fat 
stranding (expected in setting of recent L. ureteral surgical 
manipulation) and no hydronephrosis. The patient was admitted 
for sepsis secondary to non-obstructing pyelonephritis and 
started on IV ceftriaxone initially. Following culture results 
with evidence of enteroccoccus growth the patient was 
transitioned to IV ampicillin. Upon clinical stabilization the 
patient was transitioned to oral augmentin to complete a full 10 
day course on discharge.  

#Migraines
Imitrex continued.

#Anxiety
Ativan 0.5 mg QHS PRN continued. 

#Hypothyroidism
Levothyroxine continued.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital and brought to the 
operating room on ___ where the patient underwent AVR (25mm 
tissue), MVrepair (32mm ring), and Ascending Aorta Replacement 
(28mm gelweave graft) with Dr. ___.  Overall the patient 
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring. POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert 
and oriented and breathing comfortably.  The patient was 
neurologically intact and hemodynamically stable on no inotropic 
or vasopressor support.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery.  Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued 
without complication.  Free water was restricted for mild 
hyponatremia, which improved prior to discharge.  He had a brief 
episode of rapid Atrial Fibrillation, which converted to SR with 
IV lopressor and titration of Atenolol. 
The patient complained of nausea and "wretching".  SLP evaluated 
the patient and he passed the swallow study without difficulty.  
The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for 
assistance with strength and mobility.  By the time of discharge 
on POD 5 the patient was ambulating freely, the wound was 
healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics.  The 
patient was discharged to ___ in good condition with 
appropriate follow up instructions.

giving bradycardia. Dose of atenolol decreased. Pt also had 2.2 
sec run of WCT (6 beats, CL 400ms). No Sx. Will follow with Dr.

hypovolemic hyponatremia as improved with IVF and improvement of 
hypotension, but then downtrended slightly with increased dose

cultures were unrevealing. No diarrhea noted to suggest c. diff.

added to regimen.

bibasilar atelectasis. Patient was afebrile throughout admission 
and leukocytosis resolved without intervention. He was treated

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ y/o F with a PMHx significant for Hep C c/b 
hepatocellular carcinoma (Childs A), hyperthyroidism who was 
recently admitted here for what is thought to be infectious 
colitis now presenting with ___.  

ACTIVE ISSUES
==============
# ___
Patient was recently admitted with infectious colitis and had 
normal renal function at that time.  She returned with ___ (Cr 
3.5) which was ultimately thought to be pre-renal in nature 
given her history of vomiting/poor PO intake and downtrending Cr 
with IVF.  On the day of discharge, her cr had downtrended to 
1.5.  Given that she has a history of hepatitic C, cryoglobulins 
were checked and were pending at the time of discharge, and 
subsequently returned negative. RF, checked as a marker for 
cryoglobulinemia, was WNL. Given significant improvement of Cr 
with hydration as well as resolution of nausea, vomiting, and 
diarrhea, pt was discharged with plans for Cr recheck within 5 
days of discharge. Hospital course and transitional issues 
including Cr f/u were discussed directly with covering PCP by 
telephone on the day of discharge.

# Nausea
Patient was admitted with complaint of two days of nausea with 
one episode of non-blood emesis.  Patient was given IV zofran 
and nausea/vomiting resolved over the course of her stay.  Given 
patient's report of leg weakness, her acute episode of 
hypertension, her past history of seizures and hyponatremia, as 
well as her intermittent nausea/vomiting/abdominal pain, if 
patient experiences another acute episode, testing for acute 
intermittent porphyria could be considered in outpatient 
setting.

# Black stools
Patient reported having "black stools" over the 24-hours prior 
to admission.  Hct upon admission was stable and HR was not 
elevated to suggest acute blood loss. She denied taking any iron 
or supplements which would turn her stool black. On discharge, 
patient reported that her stools were more formed compared to 
prior to admission, and were of normal brown color.  

# Elevated blood pressures
During prior admission, patient had elevated BPs to the 
systolics of 170s, she was asymptomatic at the time.  She was 
started on amlodipine 5mg PO daily but this was discontinued at 
her PCP appointment two days prior to admission given 
normotensive readings.  Upon admission patient's blood pressure 
was elevated to SBP 185 and she was reinitiated on amlodipine.  
On the day of discharge, patient was once again normotensive and 
amlodipine was discontinued. Markedly elevated BPs were likely 
associated with ___. She will followup with her PCP as an 
outpatient for further blood pressure monitoring.

CHRONIC ISSUES
================
#  Hyperthyroidism: Continued home dose propylthiouracil 
#  Hepatitis C c/b hepatocellular carcinoma: Thrombocytopenia 
and transaminitis at baseline.

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL SUMMARY
=====================
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of HCV s/p Harvoni c/b 
Childs A cirrhosis, history of prior hepatic lesion that 
spontaneously regressed on serial imaging, hyperthyroidism, and 
osteopenia who was transferred from ___ for continuity of care 
and biopsy. She initially presented to ___ with abdominal 
pain, nausea, and vomiting, where imaging showed a ~5cm liver 
lesion. She was then transferred to ___ where she had 
unsuccessful biopsy attempt, and therefore transferred to ___ for 
further workup and to see her regular providers. On arrival her 
symptoms had resolved. Radiology reread her images and 
recommended EUS-guided biopsy, lymphoma protocol (results 
pending). She had persistent hypertension after the biopsy that 
improved with medications. She also had tachycardia with 
exertion that improved with bolus of IVF. She was discharged 
with close follow up. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
=================
[ ] We recommend the PCP follow up on the biopsy results. The 
oncology team here will also call the patient to schedule follow 
up when the biopsy results. 
[ ] Follow up on plasma metanephrine level and consider 24-hour 
urine metanephrine for further workup of possible 
pheochromocytoma if her symptoms persists
[ ] Will need EGD as follow up for cirrhosis management of 
variceal monitoring
[ ] If ___ has persistently poor appetite, consider starting 
mirtazapine QHS for appetite stimulation
[ ] Please titrate blood pressure medications as needed. 

# CONTACT: ___, Daughter, ___

MEDICATION CHANGES
==================
Increased lisinopril from 5mg daily to 20mg daily 
Started amlodipine 7.5mg daily for hypertension
Started marinol 2.5mg BID for appetite stimulation
Prescribing Zofran ODT for PRN use 

ACUTE ISSUES
===========
# Liver lesion with extension into portal vein 
At ___, CT torso showed heterogenous liver mass with invasion 
into the portal vein. An MRI showed a heterogenously enhancing 
mass predominantly intravascular in the main portal vein. ___ was 
unable to do the biopsy due to the location. GI was unable to 
collect tissue via EUS. Their plan was to consult surgical 
oncology for biopsy but after discussion with Dr. ___ was 
transferred to ___ for continuity of care. On arrival she 
reported her pain, nausea, and vomiting had resolved. CDs were 
obtained from ___ and ___ radiologists reread the films and 
recommended EUS. The ERCP fellow did a biopsy (results pending). 
___ had nausea and vomiting after the procedure that resolved 
with Zofran. 

# Hypertension
Well controlled on presentation. She reports she was recently 
diagnosed with hypertension but upon review of her atria's 
records it appears that she has been hypertensive in the clinic 
for several years and has declined antihypertensive medications. 
SBP 200s after procedure likely secondary to nausea, vomiting, 
and pain. However, hypertension persisted despite uptitration of 
medications. Workup for pheochromocytoma was initiated with 
plasma metanephrines because patient reported recent episodes of 
sweating. She was discharged on higher dose of lisinopril and 
amlodipine. 

# Tachycardia
#Orthostasis
Intermittent tachycardia after the biopsy worse with activity, 
not sustaining. Likely volume depleted in the setting of poor PO 
intake. We bolused her with fluids which improved her 
orthostasis.

# Nausea/Vomiting
Nausea and vomiting after biopsy likely secondary to MAC during 
the procedure. Resolved with zofran. 

# Anorexia
Patient reported poor appetite for several weeks, perhaps 
secondary to malignancy. We started marinol and nutrition was 
consulted who felt she met criteria for severe malnutrition. 

CHRONIC ISSUES
=============
# Cirrhosis
No evidence of decompensation. Childs A. 

# Osteoporosis
Continued home alendronate

# Hyperthyroidism
Continued home PTU
