Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF SUMMARY STATEMENT:
=============================
___ w/ Afib, seizure disorder, systolic CHF, and dementia, who 
presented with altered mental status, had a cardiac arrest in 
the ED, and was admitted to the ICU for post-arrest management. 
Course was complicated by UTI and acute renal failure, and she 
improved with fluids and antibiotics. Code status changed to 
DNR/DNI. 

ACTIVE ISSUES:
=============================
# CARDIAC ARREST: Patient had transient episode of asystole in 
the ED after getting calcium gluconate/insulin/dextrose for 
hyperkalemia. ROSC achieved after brief (around 10 seconds) of 
chest compressions. Unclear precipitant but concerning 
elevations in aVR and depressions in lateral leads on EKG. 
Cardiac enzymes reassuringly negative. Long pause vs asystole 
potentially from calcium gluconate infusion in the setting of 
elevated dig level. Patient w/ known CAD and documented stents 
in RCA territory. EKG changes potentially demand in the setting 
of being hyperdynamic due to hypovolemia and infected. She was 
closely monitored on telemetry, and remained hemodynamically 
stable throughout rest of hospitalization. 

# URINARY TRACT INFECTION: Patient presented w/o documented 
fevers but with leukocytosis w/ neutrophilic predominance and UA 
suggestive of infection. CXR w/o acute process. LFTs wnl. No 
imaging evidence of pyelonephritis. Chronic ulcers to coccyx and 
___ as potential sources of infection.  New G-tube oozing at 
site, cultured- growing ___ albicans. IP adjusted 
bumper. Afebrile. She was thought to have a UTI, and was started 
initially on Vanc/Zosyn, and Vanc was stopped on ___. 
Vancomycin should continue for 7day course, to end on ___. 

# ___: Patient presented w/ Cr elevated to 4.3 and BUN 123 w/ 
anion gap metabolic acidosis and several electrolyte 
abnormalities including K of 7.3 prior to treatment. Initially 
oliguric.  UA c/w UTI and reportedly from daughter has been 
hospitalized from sepsis w/ urinary origin in the recent past 
resulting in some degree of chronic kidney damage. Electrolytes 
and kidney function improved with fluid resuscitation and 
pressors. Renal US without evidence of obstruction. K now 
normalized. At discharge, Cr was 0.9.
 
CHRONIC ISSUES: 
=============================
# HISTORY OF SEIZURES: Patient w/ baseline dementia but 
reportedly able to participate in conversations w/ family. About 
___ hours of noted increasing lethargy at her facility. NCHCT 
reassuringly w/o acute intracranial abnormality and non-focal 
neuro exam. She has multiple sources of potential toxic 
metabolic encephalopathy due to her presumed infection and acute 
renal failure. EEG with significant posterior predominant 
epileptiform discharges and triphasics. Improved with addition 
of phenytoin, which was discontinued prior to discharge. At 
discharge, she was stable on Keppra 1000mg POBID.

# Atrial fibrillation: Initially required levophed and was 
tachycardic to 110s on this. Rates have been in ___ off 
Levophed. Her digoxin was initially held in setting of ___, and 
was stopped. Her Metoprolol was also stopped due to soft blood 
pressures 
 
# Goals of care: Per patients daughter/HCP, patient has had 
repeated hospitalizations over the past year with more time 
spent in the hospital than outside of it. Code status changed to 
DNR/DNI on ___. Palliative care was consulted.

1. LEGAL & SAFETY:

agreement (Section 10 & 11) and remained on that level 
throughout her admission. She was also placed on 15 minute 
checks, our lowest checks status, and remained on that level of 
observation throughout her stay, while being unit-restricted.  

2. PSYCHIATRIC:
#) Major depressive disorder: 
On arrival to the unit, patient was tearful and endorsed 
"depressed" mood with labile affect. She did state that she was 
having suicidal thoughts about the "world being better off 
without me" before getting into the ___ water, and that then 
the tide swept her away. Stated that she was very happy to have 
survived, but that she was struggling with guilt surrounding 
hurting her husband and child. Also expressed remorse 
surrounding the idea of losing custody of her child. She was 
accepting of care, and able to contract for safety while on the 
unit. Denied any acute suicidal ideation, intent, or plan. 
Stated that in the past the medication that had worked the best 
for her was Prozac. She was maintained on trazodone 50mg PO QHS 
for sleep.
During her stay, her home Paxil was downtitrated and Prozac was 
started and uptitrated. She was increased to Prozac 20mg PO QD. 
Additionally, she was started on Depakote for possible 
hypomania. She was increased to Depakote 500 mg QHS. She 
reported improvement in mood, as well as increased ability to 
cope with her circumstances. Patient and her family were very 
pleased and relieved to have a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder 
as they strongly believe her past problematic behavior is 
accurately explained by this condition. At the time of 
discharge, ___ was attending groups, was interactive in 
the milieu, and was able to participate in individual therapy. 

On discharge, patient reports "better" mood, has euthymic 
affect, and denies any suicidal thought, intent, or plan. She is 
future-oriented, with plan to attend intensive outpatient 
program and live at her parents' house before trying to go back 
to work. She will be discharged to home on Prozac 20 mg PO QD, 
trazodone 50mg PO QHs and Depakote 500 mg QHS.

3. SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS:
#)Alcohol use disorder: 
Patient arrived to the ED with BAL 285, reported that she drank 
a pint of vodka prior to going into the ___. She was kept on a 
CIWA scale for withdrawal while on the inpatient unit, though 
she did not score. She reports a history of binge drinking, and 
states that she attended AA meetings a few times in the past, 
though not recently. She did attend AA and Smart Recovery while 
here on the unit. Was referred to both outpatient, and states 
that she plans to attend.

4. MEDICAL
#) Anion gap acidosis: Patient arrived to the ___ with an 
anion gap acidosis on serum testing, likely in setting of recent 
alcohol use. This resolved with conservative management in the 
ED. 

#) Hypothyroidism: Patient with TSH of 6.1 on admission to the 
inpatient unit. Her home Synthroid was increased to 50mcg PO QD. 
It is possible that hypothyroidism could have contributed in 
part to her mood episode.

5. PSYCHOSOCIAL
#) GROUPS/MILIEU:  
The patient was encouraged to participate in the various groups 
and milieu therapy opportunities offered by the unit.  The 
patients primary team met with her daily and various 
psychotherapeutic modalities were utilized during those times. 
She was increasingly able to engage in groups and therapy during 
her stay, as her mood and emotional lability improved. 

#) COLLATERAL CONTACTS & FAMILY INVOLVEMENT
A family meeting was held with the patient's mother, ___ 
___. The patient reported not wanting to be a part of 
this meeting, as she felt that it would agitate her further. 

#) INTERVENTIONS
- Medications: Prozac
- Psychotherapeutic Interventions: Individual, group, and milieu 
therapy.
- Coordination of aftercare: Intensive outpatient program

INFORMED CONSENT: The team discussed the indications for, 
intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of 
starting this medication, and risks and benefits of possible 
alternatives, including not taking the medication, with this 
patient.   We discussed the patient's right to decide whether to 
take this medication as well as the importance of the patient's 
actively participating in the treatment and discussing any  
questions about medications with the treatment team, and I  
answered the patient's questions.  The patient appeared able to 
understand and consented to begin the medication.

RISK ASSESSMENT
On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an 
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon 
attempted suicide attempt by drowning in the ___. 
Their static factors noted at that time include history of 
suicide attempts, chronic mental illness, history of substance 
abuse, Caucasian race, age, marital status.  She also had 
several modifiable risk factors addressed at that time, 
including disorganized and unpredictable behavior, hopelessness, 
agitation, recklessness, social withdrawal, limited coping 
skills, no established outpatient treatment, and active 
substance abuse. We addressed these risk factors by restarting 
her on Prozac, holding a family meeting, and connecting her with 
outpatient treaters and an intensive outpatient program. 
Finally, the patient is being discharged with many protective 
risk factors, including help-seeking nature, future-oriented 
viewpoint, sense of responsibility to family, lack of suicidal 
ideation, and family support. Overall, based on the totality of 
our assessment at this time, the patient is not at an acutely 
elevated risk of self-harm nor danger to others. Our prognosis 
of this patient is fair, given the above.

and/or speech which may be temporary or permanent, with possible 
treatment with stents and/or coils if needed. Additionally the 
indications, risks, and alternative management for possible 
intervention was explained.

The patient was brought to the interventional neuroradiology 
suite and placed on the biplane table in the supine position. 
Both groins were prepped and draped in the usual sterile 
fashion. A pre-procedure timeout was performed using two patient 
identifiers and verifying the procedure to be performed.

Access to the right common femoral artery was obtained using a 
19-gauge single-wall needle with 1% lidocaine mixed with sodium 
bicarbonate for local anesthetic. A 0.35 ___ wire was 
introduced through the needle, and the needle was removed. A 5 
___ vascular sheath was placed over the wire and connected to 
a saline infusion (mixed with heparin 500 units in 500 cc of 
saline) with a continuous drip. Through the sheath, a 4 ___ 
___ catheter was introduced and connected to a continuous 
saline infusion (mixed with heparin 1000 units in 1000 cc of 
saline). The following vessels were selectively catheterized, 
and arteriograms were performed from the following locations: 
Right common carotid artery, right internal carotid artery, left 
vertebral artery, left common carotid artery, and left internal 
carotid artery. After review of the study, the catheter and the 
sheath were withdrawn. Hemostasis was achieved using manual 
compression. The patient tolerated the procedure well without 
any immediate post-procedure complications.

FINDINGS:

RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: The bifurcation is normal. There is 
no evidence of a vascular malformation.

RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: The cervical, petrous, cavernous, 
and supraclinoid segments of the internal carotid artery are 
normal. There is a surgical clip identified in the region of the 
anterior communicating artery with no residual aneurysm 
identified. There is mild stenosis of the M1 segment of the 
middle cerebral artery and moderate stenosis of the M2 middle 
cerebral artery branches. Additionally there is moderate 
stenosis of the A1 segment of the anterior cerebral artery with 
a focus of luminal irregularity in its proximal portion. There 
is decreased parenchymal phase blood flow identified within the 
right anterior watershed vascular distribution.

At this point, the decision was made for an intervention. 5 mg 
of verapamil was gently infused selectively into the right 
internal carotid artery over 1 minute. A right internal carotid 
artery angiogram was then repeated at approximately 10 minutes 
after the infusion of verapamil which demonstrated residual 
mild-to-moderate narrowing of the right A1 segment of the 
anterior cerebral artery, and right M1 and M2 segments of the 
middle cerebral artery.

LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: The left vertebral artery and the left 
posterior inferior cerebellar artery appear unremarkable. There 
is no reflux identified into the right vertebral artery. The 
basilar artery appears unremarkable.

5 mg of verapamil was gently infused selectively into the left

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOR CRANIOTOMY/HEAD INJURY

Have a family member check your incision daily for signs of 
infection
Take your pain medicine as prescribed
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
excessive bending
You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed 
You may shower before this time with assistance and use of a 
shower cap
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, aspirin, Advil, 
Ibuprofen etc. 
If you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it 
as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing as 
ordered
- clearance to drive will be discussed at your post 
hospitalization office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

New onset of tremors or seizures
Any confusion or change in mental status 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities
Pain or headache that is continually increasing or not 
relieved by pain medication
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, drainage
Fever greater than or equal to 101° F

# OBSTRUCTIVE CHOLEDOLITHIASIS, CHOLANGITIS, RETAINED BASKET 
WIRE. Ms. ___ was admitted s/p ERCP (done at ___ 
Endoscopy) for cholangitis - however course was complicated by 
the retention of basket wire within the distal CBD.  She 
underwent ERCP here where sphincteroplasty was performed, basket 
wire was retrieved along with multiple CBD stones.  A CBD stent 
was placed to expedite clearance of any remaining stones/sludge. 

   She presented with leukocytosis, elevated LFTs, RUQ abd pain, 
pus from the CBD duct c/w cholangitis.  For this, she was 
treated with IV unasyn along with IV dilaudid and zofran PRN for 
pain/nausea control.  She did well after the ERCP procedure - 
and was able to tolerate a regular diet the same day.  She will 
need to complete 5 more day of ciprofloxacin and flagyl.  Due to 
loose stool and diarrhea (and recent iv antibiotics), the 
concern was for the possibility of C.diff.  Stool c.diff were 
sent - and extra doses of flagyl were prescribed in case the 
stool studies returned positive.  She should not take any 
aspirin, Plavix, NSAIDS, Coumadin for the following 5 days.  She 
will need a repeat ERCP 4 weeks for stent pull and 
re-evaluation.

consistent with gastritis.  A 14-day prescription of PPI,

postponed until the cholangitis is fully treated (and prospect

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure looking after you, Ms. ___.  As you know, 
you underwent an ERCP here to retrieve the wire basket stuck in 
the common bile duct.  You tolerated the ERCP here well: the 
wire was removed along with the stones within the common bile 
duct.  A bile duct stent was also placed to ensure adequate 
passage of biliary stones.   
   Please complete 5 days of ciprofloxacin and flagyl 
(antibiotics) to treat the infection within the bile duct.  
Thereafter, you can start the other antibiotics (prilosec, 
amoxicillin, clarithromycin) to treat H.Pylori.  Since treatment 
of H.Pylori is not urgent, you may elect to delay the H.Pylori 
treatment until there is enough time to recover from the 
cholangitis and ensure that you are not infected with C.diff.  
We will contact you with the stool Cdiff results. 
   You will be contacted by our ERCP department to schedule a 
follow up ERCP to remove the stent.

___ year old female with DMII, HTN, HLD, history of ICH w/ 
residual R-sided blindness and a recent stress MIBI suggestive 
of a small area of decrease perfusion that reversed with rest 
presented from her PCPs office with chest pain concerning for a

ACTIVE PROBLEMS
================
# Chest Pain
The patient presented with chest pain that she described as 
"pressure" in her neck. Given concern for coronary artery 
disease, troponins were checked (negative x3) and EKGs were 
obtained (no acute ischemic changes). A more robust history was 
elicited, which suggested that she feels this chest pain 
intermittently (no daily but several times per week) and has not 
noted any correlation with rest or exercise. She takes her 
sublingual nitroglycerin when she is feeling pain, which helps 
sometimes but not always. She also recalls some events that were 
relieved with rest and some that lasted for several hours. Based 
on this, it remains unclear if her chest pain is coronary in 
origin. She also had an echocardiogram that was unremarkable. 
Given the negative objective work up and the very questionable 
history of her chest pain, cardiac catheterization was deferred 
at this time. Her metoprolol succinate and lisinopril were 
continued, and she was started on 81mg aspirin daily (after 
consultation with neurosurgery). Consideration was made to 
initiate nitrate therapy, however he blood pressures remained 
too soft. This can be further considered in the outpatient 
setting.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with dementia, ischemic cardiomyopathy EF 50%, DM, CKD, 
and relatively recent diagnosis of urothelial carcinoma/bladder 
mass, admitted with increasing fatigue and somnolence for three 
weeks, eventually thought most likely related to MRSA UTI.
.
#Fatigue/somnolence - A broad differential was considered, 
including possible toxic or metabolic causes. The patient's 
electrolytes were normalized and folate, B12, TSH, free T4, RPR, 
and LFTs (including ammonia) were all checked and were within 
normal limits. An initial infectious workup was negative. The 
neurology service was consulted as the patient was initially 
referred in from neurology clinic and due to concern of dilation 
of the lateral ventricles on head CT. Their impression was that 
an element of NPH was a possible contributing factor to the 
patient's presentation, but that this was unlikely to be the 
only cause. Additionally, effective evaluation of NPH would 
require the patient to be as well and stable as possible, and 
able to walk, so that he could undergo detailed testing before 
and after LP with CSF removal. An additional complication was 
that the question of NPH had been raised to the patient when he 
was more lucid, and he declined to undergo evaluation stating he 
would not want surgery for shunt placement. Outpatient neurology 
follow-up was suggested. After several days in the hospital the 
patient developed a fever, and an ongoing infectious work-up was 
continued. A urine culture eventually grew out >100,000 colonies 
of MRSA. With treatment of this infection, the patient's mental 
status improved significantly, although his overall level of 
interaction and verbal communication remained fairly low. Per 
his son, this was close to his initial baseline several weeks 
before the deterioration leading to his admission. It seems 
likely that an element of depression may also be contributing to 
the patient's overall picture; consideration was given to 
possible initiation of pharmacotherapy (such as methylphenidate 
or mirtazapine), however ultimately this was deferred, at least 
temporarily, while the patient's other medical issues reach 
resolution.
.  
#Fevers/UTI: Beginning on the patient's third hospital day, he 
began experiencing fevers. An infectious work-up, including two 
UAs, was non-revealing. He received approximately two days of 
empiric vancomycin and Zosyn out of concern for impending 
clinical deterioration. Eventually his urine culture grew MRSA, 
and this was felt to be the source of his fevers. He was at risk 
for MRSA having had urologic procedures in the last few months, 
as well as Foley catheter placement during this hospitalization. 
His catheter was removed, his antibiotic therapy narrowed to 
vancomycin alone, and his fevers resolved. Several days later, 
lower-grade temperature returned (as high as 100.8). A repeat 
infectious and non-infectious work-up was again undertaken, 
which did not reveal a cause. Drug fever was felt to be a 
possibility, and vancomycin was stopped after seven days of 
total therapy. He promptly defervesced with this and had no 
further elevated temperatures prior to discharge. 
.
#RLE and knee swelling: This was first noted several days into 
the patient's hospitalization. It began with warmth and swelling 
of the patient's right knee. An x-ray was obtained demonstrating 
the presence of previously placed orthopedic hardware and 
degenerative changes. A RLE ultrasound was negative for clot. 
The right knee was tapped on ___ to differentiate between 
gout versus possible septic arthritis; the tap was consistent 
with gout. Over the next several days, the patient developed 
ascending edema of the RLE. A repeat ultrasound was again 
obtained, to evaluate both for thrombus or a possible 
compressive pelvic mass; neither of these were identified. In 
the last two days of hospitalization, the swelling appeared to 
improve mildly. Of note, the patient had been off his diuretics 
given his renal failure. If this swelling continues to persist, 
an abdominal CT scan should be considered, however this was not 
pursued prior to discharge given the patient's rapidly changing 
renal function.
.
#Acute renal failure: The patient's baseline SCr is thought to 
be approximately 1.3-1.4. At admission, his creatinine was 
mildly elevated at 1.6. His furosemide and ___ were held. His 
creatinine subsequently improved, however several days into his 
hospitalization he was noted to have an unexplained bump in both 
his SCr (peak 2.7) and his LFTs (predominantly a transaminitis, 
peak ALT 458, peak AST 867). The etiology of both these 
processes was unclear, however they appeared to be most 
consistent with an ischemic episode of some kind (of note, no 
hypotensive episodes, even mild hypotension, were ever 
documented). Cardiac biomarkers were cycled and an echo was 
obtained, both of which were non-revealing. The patient's renal 
function and LFTs improved (SCr back to 1.5). Later on his 
hospital course, his renal failure worsened again slightly; this 
was thought to be due to poor PO intake and responded to fluid 
administration.
.
#Transient rise in LFTs: Please see section on acute renal 
failure as above. This was thought to be related to transient 
hepatorenal ischemia, although the exact etiology was not 
completely clear.
.
#Poor PO intake/electrolyte abnormalities: The patient was felt 
to have poor PO intake throughout his stay, primarily related to 
his mental status. Without IV fluid support, he would trend 
towards a pre-renal, hypernatremic picture (serum Na 146 on day 
of discharge). The patient would respond well to feeding by 
family members and the nursing staff. It is hoped that with 
rehabilitation and further improvement in his mental status, his 
ability to take POs will improve.
.
#Aspiration: The patient is felt to aspirate his sections and 
oral intake frequently. He was empirically placed on a pureed 
and thickened diet, which seemed to improve this issue somewhat. 
His did not have a formal Speech and Swallow evaluation and it 
was thought unlikely this would change the nature of his care. 
He was not thought to have frank aspiration pneumonia at any 
point in his stay.
.
#Pruritus/rash: This was a chronic issue for the patient, 
beginning many months ago. Dermatology was consulted since the 
patient was itching his skin to the extent breakdown was 
occurring. Topical therapies, including triamcinolone as needed, 
were recommended and are included in the discharge medication 
list. 
.
#Conjunctivitis/corneal abrasion: The patient had seen his 
optometrist just prior to admission and was thought to have a 
left sided conjunctivitis. In the hospital, he was empirically 
treated with erythromycin ointment and tobramycin drops. His 
right eye was also bothering him, and ophthalmology was 
eventually consulted. The patient was found to have a right eye 
corneal abrasion, probably caused when the patient was 
scratching. An eye patch and keeping the eye lid closed were 
recommended; antibiotic drops were also initiated. The patient 
is scheduled for ophthalmology follow-up at ___ tomorrow, 
___.
.
#Hematuria/urothelial cell carcinoma: The patient had been 
previously known to have a bladder mass; this was diagnosed as a 
carcinoma by urine cytology shortly before admission. At 
admission, the patient was having significant hematuria. A Foley 
catheter was placed to allow for flushing of the bladder; his 
hematuria persisted, and he eventually required continuous 
irrigation for several days. In this setting, he required a 
total of three units pRBCs transfusion (two units, followed by 
an additional unit several days later). His hematuria improved 
significantly and all catheters were able to be discontinued 
within approximately the first week of his stay. The patient has 
planned urology follow-up for resection of the mass in the 
coming weeks.
.
#anemia: This was thought to be multifactorial in etiology 
(iron-deficiency, chronic blood loss, chronic disease). The 
patient's HCT ranged in the mid-20s for most of his stay, with 
one dip as low as 21 while he was having hematuria. This 
responded to RBC transfusion.  
.  
#Ischemic cardiomyopathy: The patient was felt to by dry to 
euvolemic during most of his admission, despite the holding of 
his furosemide (and ___ due to his ARF. He also tolerated the 
administration of several liters of fluid without any evidence 
of volume overload except, possible, his RLE swelling. An echo 
was checked and was unchanged. He was continued on his home beta 
blocker and ASA.
.  
#CAD: The patient's home ASA, beta blocker and statin were 
continued.
.  
#DM: The patient's home glipizide was held. He was managed with 
fixed dose/sliding scale insulin. 
.  
#HTN: As above, the patient's home beta blocker was continued 
but his ___ was held. He was mildly hypertensive during his stay 
but not to a degree that required intervention.
.
.
#Contact: If further information concerning this complex patient 
is desired, please contact ___, MD, ___, 
pager ___.

CTA Chest ___:
CTA CHEST: The pulmonary arterial vasculature is normally 
opacified to the subsegmental level, without evidence of filling 
defect to suggest pulmonary embolism. The aorta is normal in 
size and caliber without acute aortic pathology. The remaining 
great mediastinal vessels are normal.  
  
In the right lower lobe, there is a large consolidative opacity, 
measuring approximately 8.6 x 6.8 cm in maximum cross-sectional 
dimension (image 3:87).  Pulmonary arterial branches normally 
traverse through the consolidation area, compatible with the "CT 
angiogram sign". There are no pleural effusions or pneumothorax. 
No other pulmonary nodule or mass is noted.  
  
The heart is normal in size without pericardial effusion. The 
central tracheobronchial tree is patent. There is no 
mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy. 
  
The study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic diagnosis. A 
subcentimeter hypodensity in the right hepatic lobe (image 
3:106) is too small to be fully characterized and a sub-cm 
hypodensity in the left lobe of the liver (3:100) is likely a 
cyst. The right adrenal is not visualized. The left adrenal is 
only partially imaged, but no abnormality is noted. 
  
BONE WINDOW: There are no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions. 

  
IMPRESSION: 
1. No pulmonary embolism or acute aortic pathology. 
2. Right lower lobe airspace consolidation, with demonstration 
of the "CT angiogram" sign. Differential diagnosis includes 
pneumonia, bronchioloalveolar carcinoma, and lymphoma. Recommend 
followup imaging after treatment to ensure clearance. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with DM I, osteopenia, recent L olecranon fracture 
fix 2 weeks ago presenting with SOB, fever, cough, and found to 
have RLL opacity on CXR  
.  
# Fever: Pt presented with fever, cough, SOB, and pain on deep 
inspiration consistent with pneumonia.  CXR and CTA chest 
revealed RLL opacity concerning for PNA.  (In setting of recent 
surgery of olecranon fracture, CTA chest was performed to rule 
out PE.)  However, given atypical appearance of consolidation, 
malignancy could not be ruled out.  Pt was advised to have 
repeat imaging upon resolution of pneumonia and was scheduled 
for outpatient CT chest.  She was started on oral levofloxacin 
for CAP.  Gram stain of sputum revealed 1+ gram positive cocci 
in pairs; culture grew sparse commensal respiratory flora.  
Urine legionella was negative.  Despite her recent hospital 
stay, she was not started on treatment for HCAP as she appeared 
nontoxic and improved significantly over 24 hours on 
levofloxacin.  She was discharged home with instructions to 
complete a 7 day course of levofloxacin.  
.  
# Left olecranon fracture: Pt reported having been at an OSH for 
two days for surgery for her left olecranon fracture two weeks 
prior to presentation to ___.  Left arm was kept in a sling.  
She reported no pain in the arm.  Incision was clean, dry, and 
intact.  
. 
# DM type I: Pt had humalog insulin pump which was continued 
during her hospital stay.  Per protocol, she was evaluated by 
the ___ diabetes team and seen by the nutritionist.  Per 
___ recs, she was continued on her home pump settings as 
blood glucose remained grossly within target range.  She was 
continued on her home aspirin.  
.  
# Depression: No acute issues.  She was continued on her home 
citalopram  
.  
# Osteopenia: Pt had history of multiple fractures, most 
recently a fracture of her left olecranon which was repaired two 
weeks prior to admission.  She was continued on her calcium and 
vitamin D.  She was also taking alendronate once a week which 
should be continued as outpatient.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ F w/ PMHx of HTN, HLD, PVD, COPD, history 
of rectal cancer, and anemia who presented from cardiology 
clinic with symptoms of dizziness in setting of new onset atrial 
fibrillation found to have over-repletion of thyroid hormone, 
hospital course complicated by acute pulmonary edema.  

# Acute Pulmonary Edema: Early on the morning of ___, the 
patient woke up acutely short of breath and hypertensive to 
systolics of 200. A chest x-ray showed worsened pulmonary edema 
in RLL. She was treated with 40mg IV Lasix and a nitroglycerin 
drip. She required BiPAP and was transferred to the CCU where 
she was treated with 3 additional doses of 40mg IV lasix over 
the course of 2 days. She only required BiPAP for 6 hours, and 
was then weaned to nasal cannula oxygen supplementation. 
Nitroglycerin drip was weaned off and home dose amlodipine was 
restarted. Review of the TTE showed 3+ MR ___ etiology thought 
to be possible flail mitral valve leaflet) as the presumed 
cauase for the patient's acute pulmonary edema. The patient 
continued to received IV furosemide on the floor with 
improvement in oxygen requirement with the patient on RA on the 
day of discharge. The patient was transitioned to PO torsemide 
___. The patient was started on losartan for after load 
reduction as well as metoprolol. Weight on day of discharge: 
47.7kg.

# Atrial fibrillation: CHADS-2 score of 2; patient has never had 
a stroke or TIA in the past. Patient was rate controlled on 
metoprolol XL 100mg and converted to sinus rhythm on the morning 
of ___. Thyroid function testing revealed over repletion which 
may have been the etiology for new afib. Levothyroxine dose was 
decreased to 112mcg daily (from 135mcg). TFTs should be repeated 
in 6 weeks for discharge from ___ on this new dose.

providers (Cardiology and Primary care physician); given the 
patient's history of falls, the decision was made to use full 
strength aspirin for anticoagulation.  Patient's metoprolol was 
decreased to 50mg metoprolol XL in light of development of acute 
pulmonary edema. 

# Pyuria: Early during admission, patient had UA suggestive of 
UTI with 49 WBC and few bacteria. Urine culture with less than 
10,000 organisms. Patient received 3 days of ciprofloxacin.  

# MRSA cystitis: Patient had Foley catheter placed during 
admission while being digressed. The patient's UA was suggestive 
of UTI but patient without white count when debris noted in the 
Foley catheter. Foley was discontinued. Urine culture showed 
MRSA, and patient complained of symptoms of dysuria. 
Sensitivities showed that MRSA was sensitive to Bactrim DS BID; 
patient was started on Bactrim ___. Blood cultures 
pending; repeat urine culture at time of discharge pending. Plan 
for 7 day course of Bactrim DS BID with day one being ___.

# PVD: ASA 325mg PO daily. The patient was started on 
pravastatin, which she should continue as an outpatient.
 
# HTN: The patient's home amlodipine was discontinued during 
this admission, while metoprolol was started and adjusted. With 
the development of acute pulmonary edema (see discussion above), 
metoprolol was decreased and ___ (losartan) was started for 
afterload reduction. ___ as opposed to ACEi was started given 
the patient's underlying cough.
 
# Hypothyroidism: TSH 0.091, FT4 2.1, consistent with 
over-repletion. Decreased levothyroxine from 135mcg daily to 
112mcg daily. Recheck TFTs in 6 weeks from discharge from acute 
hosptialization and adjust dose appropriately.
 
# Anemia: CBC stable through admission. Continued home iron 
supplementation. Patient due for B12 injection per daughter 
which she received during this admission.

# Thoracic spine area skin breakdown: Patient with Mepilex 
placed. Trending exam. Encourage ambulation.

take full dose aspirin daily. The good news is that during your 
hospitalization your heart rate converted to normal rhythm. You 
will continue to take aspirin to reduce your stroke risk.

infection. You were started on antibiotics to treat the 
infection. You will complete a 7 day course of antibiotics.  

Please see your discharge paperwork regarding medication 
changes.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old pleasant lady who presents with history of 
worsening cough and shortness of breath on exersion as well as 
urinary frequency. The patient was previous prescribed 
levofloxacin and Z-pack prior to admission. However one day 
before admission her symptoms became worse prompting her to see 
her PCP who referred her to the ED. 

# UTI: Her admission labs were notable for a UA suggesting a UTI 
and an elevated Cr to 1.8. She was started on PO Cipro for a 
presumed UTI. First urine culture returned negative but pt still 
reported urinary sx so a second urine culture was sent and is 
pending at time of discharge. She completed a 5-day course of 
Cipro while in-house and her Cr improved with IV fluids. 
Discharge Cr was 1.1.   

# COPD exacerbation: pt's wheezing thought most likely to be 
COPD exacerbation. Her CXR excluded pneumonia, and her blood 
culture excluded sepsis. Since the patient recently finished a 
course of azithromycin prior to admission she was only started 
on a prednisone taper. She was discharged on a prolonged taper 
as discussed with her outpatient pulmonologist Dr. ___. 

# constipation: pt was put on bowel regimen including 
senna/Colace, lactulose, psyllium when she reported she had not 
had ostomy output for 5 days. She typically has ostomy output 
every 3 days. She will continue on senna/Colace in the 
outpatient setting. 

# urinary retention: pt was found to have persistently have high 
post-void residuals and required straight cathing. This was 
thought to be a chronic issue based on her history of UTIs and 
pyuria. She should be bladder scanned in rehab and will follow 
up with urology in the outpatient setting to discuss further 
workup. 

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

# anemia: hemoglobin trended down mildly but remained close to 
pt's baseline. Anemia is believed to be a combination of iron 
deficiency anemia and anemia of chronic disease. She received a 
unit of pRBCs for a  Hgb of 7.3, but should follow up with her 
primary care doctor about reinitiating EPO. 

# diastolic CHF: the most recent echo in ___ showed EF >55% 
and LVH with moderate to severe (3+) mitral regurgitation. The 
pt did not have s/s of CHF exacerbation in house. She was 
restarted on her torsemide at a reduced dose of 10 mg twice 
weekly. 

# anxiety: pt was discontinued from lorazepam and did not 
require treatment for anxiety

# HLD: continued home pravastatin 

# HTN: continued home metoprolol 

# hypothyroidism: continued home SYnthroid. TSH here was 3.2. 

# ostomy care: wound consult was placed for concern for sores 
around the ostomy site. The pt reports that in the past she has 
received chromalin spray that was helpful for addressing the 
sores. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUE:
=========================
- steroid taper: prednisone 40 mg for a total of 5 days then 
transition to prednisone 20 mg for another 5 days. Pt should 
continue on 30mg/day for 3 days, 20mg/day for 3 days, then 
10mg/day for 3 days, then 5mg/day for 3 days and follow up with 
Dr. ___. 
- Torsemide dose on discharge: 10 mg. Pt should take torsemide 
twice weekly as needed. 
- urine culture: pt has urine culture from ___ pending at time 
of discharge. Please follow this up. 
- urinary retention: pt found to have persistently elevated 
post-void residuals and required straight cathing. She seems to 
have h/o chronic urinary retention. She should follow up with 
urology for question of cystoscopy. She should get bladder scans 
TID and be straight cathed for PVR >500 at rehab. 
- EPO injections: pt found to have anemia of chronic disease and 
started on iron, B12 and folate supplements. Per discussion with 
pt, she should follow up with PCP to discuss whether to continue 
EPO injections for her anemia (she hasn't received any in about 
___ years). She did receive 1 U pRBCs while inpatient. 
- medication changes: consider discontinuing donepezil as pt 
does not appear to have dementia as she has relatively high 
functional status (able to use phone, engage appropriately in 
conversation etc). Pt's lorazepam was d/c'ed as she did not 
require it in house.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking part in your care while you were in the 
hospital. You were admitted because you were feeling short of 
breath. You were found to have a low sodium level, but this 
rapidly improved. You were given IV medication to remove fluid 
from around the lungs. You were also given antibiotics for a 
mild pneumonia. During the hospitalization, your heart rates 
increased, requiring adjustment of your medications as listed 
below. Your metoprolol dose was increased, and a drug, digoxin, 
was started. You also were noted to have abdominal pain and 
distension, and a nasogastric tube was placed to decompress your 
stomach, and improved your discomfort. At that time, a 
medication, diltiazem was stopped, as it was thought to be 
contributing to your stomach discomfort.

You likely developed a new mild pneumonia, and were treated 
first with and IV antibiotic, and one to take by mouth at the 
rehab. Your breathing was good without the need for additional 
oxygen at the time of your discharge from the hospital. Your 
abdominal discomfort improved as well.

WHAT YOU SHOULD DO AFTER LEAVING THE HOSPITAL:
1. Do not drink more than 1.5 liters of fluid a day
2. Drink only thickened liquids

Again, it has been a pleasure taking part in your care, and we 
wish you the best.

PRIMARY REASON FOR ADMISSION:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man with known CAD s/p multiple DES, mild 
AR, HTN, HLD, CKD, and HIV p/w resting chest pain relieved by 
nitro and EKG changes suggestive of ACS/unstable angina.
  
ACTIVE ISSUES:
# Unstable Angina:The patient presented with unstable angina and 
TW flattening. Trops negative x3. He underwent cardiac 
catheterization  that showed the LAD had mid-vessel disease with 
50% eccentric plaque, with large diagonal branch that was 
bifurcating. The proximal segment had 40% diffuse then 
bifurcated to an upper pole (with patent stent) and lower pole 
(with diffuse70-80% disease). The LCx had mid 90% focal lesion 
proximal to the OM1 origin. The proximal OM2 had 70% proximal to 
the bifurcation. RCA was tortuous with 40% disease at the 
proximal stent edge. He had successful PTCA and stenting of the 
mid LCX and placement of DES. Three days after his 
catheterization, he developed severe chest pain with ST 
depressions laterally so he was taken to the catheterization lab 
for a re-look via the radial artery where his stents were patent 
and there were no thrombus or changes. It was decided to treat 
him medically. His blood pressure regimen was modified (see 
below), his statin was changed to atorvastatin 80mg and he will 
be on lifelong asa and clopidogrel x ___ year. He will have a 
P-MIBI in ___ weeks to assess further his mid LAD and diag 
lesions.

# Acute on chronic kidney disease: The patient's Cr rose to 1.9 
in the setting of two cardiac catheterization. He received IVF 
and the Cr downtrended by discharge (1.7).

# Leg pain: On ___, the patient reported acute ___ left leg 
pain that radiated from his hip to his ankle. Pulse exam 
unchanged. His left femoral artery had been used for access for 
his first cardiac catheterization but this was on ___. He was 
initially started on a heparin gtt but given arterial and venous 
ultrasounds were normal, this was discontinued. The pain 
improved with morphine x1 and he was walking comfortably later 
in the day. This etiology of this pain was unclear (although 
patient has known HIV vasculopathy) but did not recur.

#Hypertension: The patient was hypertensive to the 190s during 
this admission. His amlodipine was increased to 10mg and he was 
started on carvedilol 25mg BID (instead of metoprolol) and 
hydralazine 75mg q6h (for afterload reduction). Imdur was 
continued at his home dose. He will need close monitoring of his 
blood pressure and may benefit from a renal ultrasound. He may 
also benefit fro ___ (review of records showed he had 
hyperkalemia in ___ while on lisinopril) once his kidney 
function normalizes.

# Diarrhea: The patient had intermittent diarrhea ___ bowel 
movements in a row) which is reportedly chronic and for which he 
takes loperamide. If this continues, he may benefit from further 
GI evaluation of his diarrhea.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
# HIV: CD4 count of 538. Continued on home regimen. 

# Hepatitis C: He is genotype 1A HCV c/b cirrhosis, stable 
without evidence of clinically significant portal hypertension 
or synthetic dysfunction

# Urinary retention: Continued home oxybutynin.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman with a history of CAD, 
HTN, CKD, diastolic HF, PVD, and HIV (last CD4 count 538 in 
___ who presents with chest pain.  

# Chest pain:  Patient reported substernal chest pain similar to 
the pain at the time his last DES was placed, very concerning 
for unstable angina.  His troponin was mildly elevated at 0.02 
(in the setting of CKD) but remained stable.  An EKG showed no 
ischemic changes.  Patient's chest pain resolved in the ED after 
SL NTG and morphine.  A myocardial perfusion study revealed no 
anginal type symptoms or objective evidence of myocardial 
ischemia.  His chest pain may have been related to underlying 
LVH in the setting of worsening anemia.  He was continued on 
ASA, Plavix, carvedilol, and pravastatin 20 mg daily and 
scheduled for follow-up with cardiology. 

# Diastolic heart failure:  Patient appeared mildly hypervolemic 
on admission but was euvolemic on discharge.  Lasix 40 mg was 
continued.  Given orthostasis and hyperkalemia, losartan was 
held and isosorbide mononitrate was reduced from 120 mg to 90 mg 
daily. 

# Chronic kidney disease c/b hyperkalemia:  Creatinine on 
admission was 2.1, stable from 2.0 in ___.  Creatinine in 
___ ranged from 1.3-1.5.  This likely represents progression of 
his underlying CKD.  K was 5.8 on admission, 5.5 on discharge.  
This was likely a combination of CKD and losartan, which was 
discontinued.  Patient was instructed to have labs rechecked on 
___ at ___'s office. 

# Hypertension:  Patient's blood pressure was well-controlled.  
He was continued on carvedilol, diltiazem, and hydralazine.  
Given symptomatic orthostasis, isosorbide mononitrate was 
decreased from 120 mg to 90 mg daily and losartan was 
discontinued.

# Anemia: H/H 8.8/27.6 from 9.6/30.8 in ___.  Likely related 
to known anemia of chronic disease, HIV, CKD.  No reports of 
melena or hematochezia, guaiac negative.  Chest pain may be 
exacerbated by anemia and patient may benefit from EPO.

# HIV:  Patient was continued on efavirenz, lamivudine 
(appropriately renally dosed), and abacavir.

Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital for chest pain. We gave you 
medications to help your heart and to treat your pain. Your 
chest pain improved. You were also found to have low blood 
levels, so you received 1 unit of blood cells. You underwent 
cardiac catheterization and a stent was placed in one of the 
vessels of your heart. After the catheterization, you were 
having some hand pain and swelling near the incision site. The 
hand specialists were consulted and assessed your hand regularly 
until the pain and swelling had improved. 

You were started on new medications including plavix 
(clopidogrel). It is very important that you continue to take 
this medication, as well as your home aspirin, to prevent clots 
from forming in your new stent. All of your medications are 
detailed in your discharge medication list. You should review 
this carefully and take it with you to any follow up 
appointments.

The details of your follow up appointments are given below.

It was a pleasure taking care of you.

The antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is a
clinical-pathologic correlation that includes a clinical
event(e.g. thrombosis, pregnancy loss, thrombocytopenia)
and persistent positive antiphospholipid antibodies
(IgM or IgG ACA ___ MPL/GPL, IgM or IgG anti-b2GPI
antibodies or a lupus anticoagulant). The IgA isotype
has been implicated in smaller studies, but has not yet
been incorporated into the APS criteria. International
consensus guidelines suggest waiting at least 12 weeks
before retesting to confirm antibody persistence.
Reference J Thromb Haemost ___: 4;  295

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___, 

Thank you for allowing us to take part in your care during your 
stay in the hospital. You came into the hospital with chest 
pain.  Your chest pain was treated with nitroglycerin and a 
blood thinner, but your blood tests did not show any damage to 
your heart. You had an exercise stress test to check the 
arteries in your heart which showed no concerning evidence of 
ongoing heart injury. You also had an acute kidney injury that 
arose likely because of starting a medication called lisinopril 
for your blood pressure. Your kidney injury has since improved. 

You should continue the medications as listed in the enclosed 
discharge paperwork. 

Please follow-up with your PCP and your cardiologist. Please 
weight yourself every day and call your MD if your weight goes 
up by 3 lbs. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you, 

- Your ___ Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman with CAD s/p multiple 
stents, HIV (on ART reportedly with undetectable VL), HCV s/p 
Harvoni (reportedly with undetectable VL) , CKD (baseline Cr 
1.9), HTN, and COPD who presented for evaluation of substernal, 
non-radiating, nonpositional, and noninspiratory ___ chest 
pain. 

#CAD: Pt is s/p Promus DES to mid-LAD, D1 branch, and distal-RCA 
on ___, s/p Premier DES to mLCX on ___, and BMS to LAD 
___. He had a Stress MIBI in ___ showing normal 
perfusion and no wall motion abnormalities.  

#Chest pain: Pt presented on ___ with substernal, non-radiating, 
nonpositional, noninspiratory, and nonreproducible ___ chest 
pain at rest. ECG on admission was notable for with <1 mm STE in 
lateral leads, consistent with prior and Troponin x2 were 
negative. His ___ chest pain decreased to ___ with SLN x2 in 
EMS, IV morphine in the ED, and x2 upon arrival to the floor.  
His clinical picture was c/f ACS, perhaps unstable angina given 
his hx, although cardiac enzymes were not elevated and there 
were no ECG findings. He was maintained on telemetry and ECGs 
were trended, w/o evidence of additional ischemic disease 
throughout his hospitalization. A ddx of PNA was also considered 
initially given the patient's admissions x2 (___) for RLL PNA 
and CXR on admission notable for RLL atelectasis, although 
patient had no fever, productive cough, worsening SOB, or 
leukocytosis to suggest this. Also considered that patient's 
chest pain was ___ to GERD/gas pains given his hx of GERD, 
belching and bloating on exam, and partial relief with 
simethicone upon arrival to the floor. PE was considered, but 
deemed unlikely given patient's pain was not pleuritic, he had 
no tachycardia/tachypnea, and he had normal O2sats. 
Musculoskeletal causes of his chest pain were also less likely 
given that his pain was not well localized or positional, and 
and there was no tenderness to palpation on exam. Pericarditis 
was unlikely given that pain did not increased with inspiration 
and did not improve w/sitting forward. On ___ AM, pt denied 
chest pain, said that his SOB and dry cough were at b/l as 
related to his COPD, although he continued to be nauseous and 
complained of abdominal discomfort and bloating as detailed 
below (see #Chronic abdominal pain). On ___, patient had 
pharmacologic nuclear stress test notable for ischemic changes: 
1 mm of downsloping ST segment depression was noted in the 
inferolateral leads and new, partially reversible, perfusion 
defects were noted in the LAD and LCx territory, c/f possible 
restenosis of prior proximal or distal LAD stents per report. 
Based on discussion between the patient's outpatient 
cardiologist (Dr. ___, inpatient consulting cardiology 
team, and primary team, it was considered that the nuclear 
defect noted on the stress test could be an artifact as 
patient's left arm was in the way during the imaging, and it was 
decided not to pursue inpatient catheterization, but to pursue 
an outpatient dobutamine echocardiogram. The decision was made 
at the point to optimize the patient medically from the 
standpoint of his known ischemic disease, and specifically focus 
on managing his hypertension, as discussed below (see 
#Hypertension). On ___, the patient had  additional abdominal 
pain, with repeat ECG unchanged from prior, and with troponin x2 
<0.01. Throughout his hospitalization, patient was maintained on 
his home ASA, carvedilol, diltiazem, and pravastatin as 
described below. His hydralazine regimen and isosorbide 
mononitrate ER regimen were changed as described below (see 
#Hypertension). Of note, the patient was intermittently 
emotional during his hospitalization in the context of 
confronting his multiple medical comorbidities. Social work and 
spiritual care were consulted, and provided resources to the 
patient to help with his coping. 

#HTN: Patient's recent outpatient BPs per OMR have been 
120s-170s/50s-70s. BP 180/71 on arrival to floor on ___, likely 
at least partially due to patient having missed BP doses at home 
iso chest pain. He received home isosorbide, hydralazine, 
carvedilol, amlodipine, and diltiazem at 12AM on night of 
admission, but had BP 210/80 overnight. He was asx w/o HA, CP, 
palpitations, or visual difficulty at that time. He received 
hydrazine 10 mg IV, w/repeat BP 180/70. BP 163/70 on ___. On 
___ AM, patient again had BP 211/73, but hydralazine 10 mg IV 
was deferred, as pt was set to receive his AM BP meds. BP on 
recheck after receiving home BP meds was 155/68 on ___. As 
described above (under #CAD/Chest pain), plan was made to 
optimize patient's BP management iso of his known ischemic 
disease. On ___, patient's home isosorbide dinitrate was 
increased from 30 mg to 40 mg TID and patient was also started 
on lisinopril 5 mg QD on ___ as detailed below (under ___ on 
CKD). After this change, ___ BPs ranged from 124-211/60-101, 
with max SBP still in the 190s, which was a slight improvement. 
On ___, BPs ranged from 125-178/47-80. On ___ AM, administered 
isosorbide dinitrate 40 mg plus isosorbide mononitrate ER 120 mg 
PO (total 160 mg on ___, with resulting BPs on ___ ranging 
from 120-180s/50s-80s. Given continued poor control and 
hesitation about escalating isosorbide total daily dose above 
120 mg, opted to modify regimen to isosorbide mononitrate ER 120 
mg PO QD on ___. Also changed his hydralazine from 75 mg PO q6hr 
to 100 mg PO q8hr, largely for ease of medication administration 
at home. At time of discharge, patient had BPs ranging from 
140-184/64-75. Of note, given patient's refractory hypertension

Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ PMH of CAD s/p Promus DES to mid-LAD, D1 branch, and 
distal-RCA on ___ (also other stents: total 7), HIV on 
HAART, CKD (baseline Cr 2.4-2.5), diastolic CHF, PAD, HCV with 
well compensated cirrhosis s/p harvoni, G6PD deficiency, who 
presented with chest pain worrisome for unstable angina. 

# Unstable Angina: # CAD:
Patient notably has had several repeat presentations with 
similar type of anginal chest pain, when medical workups 
demonstrated some probable new atherosclerotic disease causing 
partially reversible perfusion defects involving the LAD and LCx 
territory. Due to patient's advanced CKD and the risks involved 
with catheterization with angiography, decision had been made in 
the past to treat subsequent events of anginal pain medically 
without surgical or operative intervention if possible.

Patient presented with chest pain that radiated to his left 
shoulder, of approximately 1 day's duration, nonpleuritic or 
positional in nature. Sublingual nitroglycerine provided minimal 
improvement. Patient took 4x81 mg aspirin and presented for 
evaluation in the ED. Laboratory studies were notable for 
troponin of 0.02 in the setting of CKD with a Cr of 2.3 
(baseline), with ongoing stable anemia with Hb of 8.5. Patient 
was admitted for observation regarding his anginal pain. His 
cardiac markers did not elevate further. His isosorbide dosage 
was increased to 120 mg bid. He was discharged with instruction 
to follow-up with his primary care doctor and cardiologist.

# Hypertensive Urgency: 
Patient's observation course was notable for hypertensive 
urgency (first to systolic blood pressures of 210) in the 
setting of his ongoing intermittent anginal pain. His isosorbide 
was increased as above. Resuming his previous discontinued 
torsemide was considered, though he achieved improvement of his 
blood pressures on isosorbide alone. Diltiazem, hydralazine, and 
amlodipine were also continued. At time of discharge his blood 
pressures had improved and he was ambulating well with a walker. 


*Chronic Issues:
# History of Diastolic CHF:  Patient had a history of chronic 
CHF. There was no evidence of exacerbation during this 
admission. Patient had recently stopped his home torsemide in 
outpatient setting in late ___ due to elevated Cr. This was 
not resumed, as above.
# CKD: patient had a baseline of Cr 2.4-2.5 recently.  At 
baseline.  Seemed to improve after stopping Torsemide (was 3.1 
prior). Torsemide not resumed. 
# COPD: continued Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q6H:PRN wheeze  
# HIV:  Continued home Maivudine, Abacavir, Efavirenz
# GERD: continued pantoprazole, discontinued omeprazole given 
redundancy
# Constipation: continued senna/Colace.
# Nutrition: continued vitamin B12

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- patient's isosorbide dosage was increased to 120 mg bid given 
his ongoing hypertensive urgency in the setting of intermittent 
anginal pain. Review of his records had indicated a steady 
pattern of hypertension at outpatient visits, and it appeared 
other elements of his regimen were already at max dosage.
- Patient was not resumed on his prior torsemide (d/c'd in 
___. Should he have refractory hypertension not responsive 
to the above, torsemide may be a good option to resume in the 
setting of his chronic kidney disease (if his Cr can tolerate a 
low dosage).
- Discussion took place with pharmacy regarding his statin 
dosage. Patient may benefit from uptitration of his pravastatin 
dosage to 40 mg daily, which is compatible with his current 
HAART regimen.
- Patient has blood cultures from admission that require 
follow-up

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you had symptoms of 
chest pain that seemed related to your prior history of coronary 
artery disease. You were evaluated in the emergency room with 
blood work, electrocardiography, and imaging, which demonstrated 
minimal evidence of another heart attack. It did seem that your 
pain was related to ongoing symptoms of your coronary artery 
disease, however. Past studies have indicated that you have some 
areas of the heart that do not receive as much blood flow, and 
this may be contributing to some of your occasional symptoms. It 
did not seem that any acute heart attack was happening, so we 
decided not to recommend another attempt at catheterization or 
thinning your blood.

Your blood pressures were markedly elevated on admission to the 
hospital, however, which we think could be related to the pain 
you are experiencing when you have angina. It can be dangerous 
for you to have sustained high blood pressures, especially given 
your heart disease, so we have increased the amount of 
isosorbide you take to 120 mg twice a day. 

Your blood pressures were better controlled at the end of the 
day and you were feeling better, so it was safe for you to leave 
the hospital. Please follow-up with your primary care and 
cardiology doctors and take ___ your medications as prescribed.

It was a pleasure to be involved with your medical care!
Your ___ Cardiology Team

#IBS/abdominal pain: Regarding the patient's abdominal pain 
without n/v, it was acute over the past 4 days, and felt similar 
to past IBS flares per patient but was not relieved after 
linzess and bowel movement as expected. Reassuringly the CT A/P 
was negative for an acute process in the ED. There was mild 
lipase elevation without typical symptoms to suggest 
pancreatitis. It is possible this pain was referred pain from 
cystitis. A cardiac mimic was on the differential, but was less 
likely in the absence of acute ischemic EKG changes, trp

complete resolution of symptoms upon admission to the floor. The 
patient continued linzess from home, received IVF, bowel

Brief Hospital Course:
====================
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
====================
Mr. ___ is a ___ with a history of CAD status post multiple 
stents, HFpEF, HCV cirrhosis, HIV, CKD, COPD, HTN, and anemia of 
chronic disease, who presented with 24 hours of nasal 
congestion, cough and generalized aches; found to have influenza 
A. 

====================
ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES:
====================
# Influenza A
# COPD
Presented with 24 hours of nasal congestion, non-productive 
cough, and generalized aches, subsequently found to have 
positive influenza A PCR. CXR without any evidence of 
superimposed PNA. Admitted given high risk comorbidities 
including COPD and immunosuppression (HIV, HCV). Completed a 5d 
course of Oseltamivir 30mg daily (renally dosed, ___. 
Otherwise continued his home Combivent inhaler q6 hrs PRN and 
started a PRN Albuterol nebulizer. Overall the patient felt 
significantly improved at discharge. He is to follow up with his 
PCP ___ 1 week for follow up.

# Diarrhea
# C. Difficile
Of note, most recent CD4 in the 400s. However, patient noted to 
have several day history of non-bloody diarrhea. Stool studies 
negative for Norovirus, Shigella, Salmonella, Campylobacter, 
Crypto/Giardia, O&P, and CMV. Viral culture NGTD and Cyclospora 
PND, which PCP is to follow up on. Ultimately, C. Diff Ag 
returned positive (however toxin negative) indicating likely 
colonization - however given immunosuppressed state we opted to 
treat with a 14d course of PO Vancomycin 125mg QID (___). 
Of note, had significant associated abdominal distention and 
moderate pain, however KUB was reassuring overall (showed lots 
of gas). As such, was also started on Simethicone which improved 
his symptoms. His diarrhea was improving at discharge. 

# ___ on CKD, resolved: Baseline creatinine 3.5-3.8, with a peak 
Cr of 4.4 during his hospitalization that was most consistent 
with a pre-renal etiology based on FEUrea, urine sediment (not 
muddy brown casts), and history of influenza and diarrhea (as 
per above). His ___ resolved with fluids and 1U pRBC. His home 
Torsemide 60mg daily was reduced to 40mg daily given his 
continued diarrhea at discharge, and PCP should reconsider 
increasing back to home dose of 60mg daily at follow up visit. 
He was otherwise continued on his home Calcitriol and was Sodium 
Bicarbonate 650mg TID. Of note, he missed his Epo injection on 
___ and this was rescheduled to ___ at discharge. His discharge 
Cr was 2.9.

# Hypernatremia
Became mildly hypernatremic to 148 during his hospitalization 
likely in the setting of poor PO intake. Free water deficit of 
1.7 L. S/p 1L D51/2NS and increased H2O intake, with resolution 
of hypernatremia. Discharge Na of 142.

# Acute on chronic anemia
# Coagulopathy
Baseline Hgb ___, which has subsequently downtrended to 7.5. 
Additionally was coagulopathic. However, labs reassuring against 
DIC or hemolysis. Stool guaiac negative. His anemia was overall 
felt to be in part due to missing his Epo injection on ___, 
however this was rescheduled to ___ at discharge. He received 1U 
pRBC with an appropriate increase to Hgb 8.5. At discharge, his 
Hgb was 7.8. His coagulopathy was felt to be due to poor 
nutritional status in the setting of acute illness.

# Vasovagal syncope
Overnight on ___, had witnessed syncope episode while sitting 
up to use the urinal. Overall was most concerning for a 
vasovagal event in the setting of decreased BP and relative 
hypovolemia from influenza infection, particularly given 
positive orthostatics. No h/o seizure or arrhythmia. Remained 
syncope free for the rest of his hospitalization. 

# Hypertension
Patient on aggressive regimen as an outpatient. BP was elevated 
to 180s while in the ED in the setting of missing 
anti-hypertensive medications the day prior to admission. As 
such, continued his home regimen of Hydralazine 50mg BID, 
Carvedilol 25mg BID, Diltiazem 240mg daily, and Doxazosin 2mg 
QHS.

======================
CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES:
======================
# HIV

In our ER he arrived with a BP of 151/88, HR 82, T 97.9, RR 16, 
SaO2100%. Pt had an Iv put in and received labetalol 10mg IV x1. 
He had a CXR that did not show any acute pathology and a CT scan 
negative for hemorrhage, but some non-specific white matter 
lesions. A neurology consult was called. Neurology do not think 
this is a stroke. Patient was admitted to medicine for further 
workup.

In the floor patient's SBP was 150-180, so labetalol 200mg TID 
was started. Patient's BP responded adequatelly to this. Patient 
was put in telemetry, where there were no abnormalities found.

Mr. ___ had an MRI of the brain, which showed hyperintense 
periventricular and subcortical white matter bilaterally, 
suggesting small vessel ischemid disease, which did not look 
like HIV encephalopathy or PML. However, this cannot be ruled 
out.

Patient was without any chest pain during hospitalization and BP 
was 120/80 during remaining of hospitalization. Negative cardiac 
enzymes x2. Patient had a stress test, but did not achieve goal 
HR (Pt on labetalol). Since the BP change was so sudden and 
patient with adequate follow up as outpatient and has not known 
hypertension, secondary causes for hypertension were worked up. 
Patient had 24-hour metanephrins ordered.

Patient was discharged home with follow up with his primary care 
within the next day.

1. Diarrhea
Etiology of his abdominal pain and diarrhea is unclear but is 
certainly concerning for infectious etiology or malignancy. His 
most recent CD4 count is 492, making him at low risk for most 
opportunistic infections. A c-scope was deferred b/c of 
hyperkalemia. His symptoms improved overnight and his abd pain 
resolved, so his procedure was deferred to outpatient.  His 
already scheduled o/p c-scope was arranged to be sooner.  C 
diff, and other routine pathogens (including campylobacter, 
shigella, yersinia, Ecoli O15___ and vibrio were negative, but O 
and P was still pending.  Of note, the patient has already had 
an full o/p w/u for diarrhea in an HIV patient.

The test was repeated and was without hemolysis.  His ecg was 
normal. This suggests that the high K may have been real and 
possibly secondary to his ACEI.  His lisinopril was held. He was 
given lasix and fluid d and his K came down to 4.7.  He was 
discharged off his ACEI to follow up and get a repeat K.  
.
3. HIV: Stable.  Continued home regimen
.

discontinued due to hyperkalemia.  He was started on amlodipine 
5 mg daily after his blood pressure was running in the 150s, 
with good effect.  He had some mild orthostatic hypotension with 
norvasc initiation after his diuresis the day prior.  He felt 
well at discharge with a blood pressure of 122/68.
.

elevation, but he has known hep C. A RUQ u/s was negative. An 
Abd CT was normal. His pain resolved without intervention.

without intervnetion. A head CT done int he ER was normal.

Brief Hospital Course:
1. NSTEMI: Patient presented with chest pain and elevated 
troponin, as well as EKG showing new TWI in leads 2, 3 and AVF. 
He was bolused with Heparin and started on Heparin gtt. Sent to 
cath lab where was found to have complete occlusion of RCA and 
tight lesions in LAD and upper pole of diag. Drug-eluting stents 
were placed in the RCA, LAD and upper pole of diagonal branch. 
After the procedure, patient was chest-pain free. He was started 
on ASA 325, Plavix 75mg daily, and Metoprolol. As the patient 
had elevated Cr 1.3, he was not started on Lisinopril at this 
time. He was also started on a low-dose statin rather than the 
usual high-dose statin for post-MI cardioprotection as he has 
history of Hep C cirrhosis.

Metoprolol during admission as Metoprolol has improved survival 
benefits post-MI.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ is a ___ year old male who came in for lightheadedness 
and hypertension and was found to have hyponatremia. In the 
hospital, his lisinopril was discontinued and his hypertension 
medications were adjusted with the advice of the renal team. He 
had transient diarrhea but felt better. He was discharged home 
with services and will begin cardiac rehab and see his primary 
care doctor.

# Hyponatremia
Presented with a sodium level of 125, a new issue. At discharge, 
Na was 133. Most likely etiology of hyponatremia, given acute 
onset, is drug-induced from lisinopril, which was recently 
started. Hypovolemia likely given his admitted decrease in PO 
intake and decrease in appettite. He appeared euvolemic on exam 
after IV fluids in the ED. He denied other medications as well.

Fluid I/O and electrolytes were monitored and returned to 
normal. An abdominal ultrasound ruled out ascites. Simvastatin 
was replaced by pravastatin 40 mg p.o. QD and metoprolol and 
amlodipine were replaced by carvedilol 6.25 mg p.o. BID. If it 
is well tolerated, to be increased by outpatient providers.

# Lightheadedness
Dizziness unlikely of cardiac origin given the normal recent 
stress test and lack of chest pain. No evidence for stroke - 
moving all extremities, equal strength. No evidence for low 
blood pressure or hypovolemia. Has had dizziness in past. 
Symptoms have resolved at time of discharge. Likely hypovolemia 
in the setting of decreased PO intake and decreased appettite. 

# HTN
Chronic issue for which he recently saw his cardiologist. His 
medications were adjusted as above. Normotensive through 
hospitalization. Will follow up with cardiologist and primary 
care (___) and initiating cardiac rehab ___.

OTHER ISSUES
# CAD
History of NSTEMI ___ with cath; Angina in past. Stable on 
amdission, maintained on Plavix and aspirin and other HTN 
medications as above. Had cardiac rehab scheduled for ___.

# Anemia
Chronic anemia, with Hct at baseline. Possibley due to HIV or 
CKD.

# Chronic Kidney Disease
Current Cr of 1.3 in line with baseline creatinine of 1.0-1.3. 
Thought to be secondary to HIV.

# COPD - chronic issue per OMR with short distance dyspnea on 
exertion. Has cardiac rehab scheduled for ___.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
Patient has decreased appetite and 10 lb weight loss in past 
year or two. Patient says Ensure not covered by Medicare and 
would like help with appetite.

c/b portal hypertension, chronic hyponatremia who presented with

ACTIVE ISSUES:

1.  chest pain: patient presented with atypical chest pain which 
resolved spontaneously prior to presentation to the emergency 
department.  Cause of chest discomfort was unclear, but there 
was low concern for a cardiac etiology with unchanged serial 
EKGs, normal cardiac enzymes x 2 and recent normal persantine 
stress results.  CXR was within normal limits and patient denied 
any symptoms consistent with musculoskeletal or gastointestinal 
causes of pain.  Patient continued on his aspirin, plavix, 
carvedilol and simvastatin for significant history of coronary 
artery disease.

2.  hyponatremia: Patient presented with asymptomatic 
hyponatremia which has been present for the past several months. 
  Evaluation was consistent with inappropriate secretion of ADH 
with euvolemic volume status, urinary Na excretion persistently> 
20 and urine osmolality in 300s.   TSH and am cortisol were 
within normal limits.  Patient was also administered carefully 
monitored IVF challenge x 2 to ensure that hypovolemia was not 
the cause of hyponatremia, especially given the history of poor 
oral intake/ failure to thrive.  Serum sodium did not improve 
with fluid challenges and urine osmolality increased slightly.  
The etiology of SIADH was not apparent with no clear 
precipitant: no evidence of malignancy or culprit drugs.  
Nephrology was consulted and recommended management with free 
water restriction and liberalization of salt intake.  Sodium 
should be periodically monitored as an outpatient, but at this 
time no further evaluation is warranted.

3. failure to thrive: patient complained of progressive appetite 
loss from unclear cause.  Although serum albumin was within 
normal limits, patient had prominent temporal wasting (of note, 
appearance may be partial due to lipodystrophy from long-term 
use of antiretrovirals).  He was started on low dose remeron as 
an appetite stimulant with dietary supplementation with all 
meals.  Nutritional status should be monitored as an outpatient.

CHRONIC MEDICAL PROBLEMS

4. HIV, asymptomatic: per patient well controlled with no 
evidence of opportunistic infections.  During hospitalization, 
he was continued on home antiretrovirals.    

5. HCV cirrhosis: LFTs and liver synthetic function at baseline. 
 Although patient has a history of portal hypertension which can 
be associated with chronic hyponatremia from RAS activation due 
to splanchnic vasodilitation, this did not seem to be the likely 
cause of electrolyte imbalance.  

6. HTN: continued on home dose of carvedilol

7. prostatitis: cont doxycycline

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old single Caucasian man with reported history 
of depression s/p one psychiatric hospitalization in ___ ___ for depression and suicidal ideation, 
history of intermittent cannabis use, who presented to ___ via 
EMS after his roommates were concerned for several hours of 
bizarre behaviors. ED course was notable for agitation with 
patient requiring mechanical and chemical restraints. 
. 
Initial presentation was concerning for severe psychosis with 
apparent acute onset (per collateral was seen by his parents 
about a week prior to presentation and appeared to be at his 
baseline) with ED course notable for grandiosity, irritability,
disorganized and tangential thought process, as well as 
agitation requiring numerous physical and chemical restraints. 
Interview on my examination was significantly more reassuring, 
with patient notably calm, cooperative with thought process that 
is linear, goal and future oriented. Of note, he denies AVH and 
he does not appear to be responding to internal stimuli. 
. 
In terms of etiology, presentation seems most consistent with 
substance induced psychosis, although the patient denies recent 
illicit substance use and his tox screen was negative on 
admission. Differential also includes brief psychotic disorder, 
bipolar disorder (although no clear history of mania in the 
past-- remains on the differential given young age with ?family 
history of bipolar). Has reportedly been depressed in the past, 
but denies depressive symptoms on examination and does not 
appear dysthymic or dysphoric on examination.  
. 
#. Legal/Safety: patient admitted to Deaconess ___ on a ___, upon admission, he declined to sign a CV, stating he wished 
to be discharged home. Patient maintained his safety throughout 
his hospitalization on 15 minute checks and did not require 
physical or chemical restraints. Given his good behavioral 
control with resolution of psychotic symptoms with consistent 
denial of SI/HI, he did not meet 7&8b criteria and was 
discharged upon expiration of his ___. 
.
#. Psychosis: as noted above
- Patient declined initiation of psychotropic medications during 
his hospitalization. He was offered prn Ativan, which he did not 
require. 
- Mr. ___ maintained excellent behavioral control in the 
milieu and was compliant in attending groups, where he 
participated appropriately 
- Of note, during his hospitalization, his psychosis cleared 
rapidly with thought process that became linear, logical, goal 
and future oriented. He was calm, cooperative on examination 
with full range of affect, consistently denying AVH with no 
evidence that he was responding to internal stimuli. 
- Patient was counseled to avoid using illicit drugs, including 
cannabis, as this may increase his risk for a recurrent episode 
of psychosis. The patient understood this risk and stated he 
would abstain. 
- Patient declined referral to a PHP and will follow up with 
outpatient treaters as noted in the discharge worksheet. 
.
#. Medical: no acute issues during this admission

repletion.  CT scan showed colitis as well as incidentally noted 
prostatic enlargement.

reported he felt fine, had no further loose stool x > 24 hours 
and wished to return home.

agreed that 36 hours of IV steroids was likely sufficient for a 
stress dose and that he could be discharged on 1 mg po 
dexamethasone x 1 week and then resume his regular dose of 0.5 
mg po dexamethasone daily.  He should continue his Florinef.
.

encouraged for potassium repletion and he was also prescribed 40 
mEq po potassium for ___.

his mother who reported that she would see to it that the 
medication changes were put into effect, that he would follow up 
with Dr. ___ that he would discuss his maintenance 
dexamethasone dose with Dr. ___ it seems fairly

condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given 
___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The 
patient's home medications were continued throughout this 
hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that 
discharge to home was appropriate.  On postoperative day 1, the 
patient reported a decreased appetite, had soft systolic blood 
pressures and required a 1 L fluid bolus.  Additionally, the 
patient's potassium and magnesium were repleted during his 
admission.  The patient became acutely ill on ___ and was 
taken to the operating room for irrigation and debridement of 
the right knee.  Afterwards, the patient was transferred to the 
surgical ICU, where broad-spectrum antibiotics were continued. 
On ___ the patient was deemed to be stable enough for 
transfer back to the floor.  At the time of discharge, 
infectious disease recommended 4 weeks of IV antibiotics.  Mr. 
___ had a PICC line placed prior to discharge to rehab.

The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weightbearing as tolerated with ___ brace locked in 
extension in the right lower extremity, and will be discharged 
on aspirin 325 mg daily for 4 weeks for DVT prophylaxis. The 
patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A

diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons 
to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions 
were answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.
