Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY
=======
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with chronic respiratory 
failure s/p tracheostomy ___ (nocturnally ventilated), chronic 
aspiration s/p PEG, dementia, advanced ___, HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, recent admission for a right fibula fracture, 
and other issues who presented on ___ with apparent 
lethargy (reported by her son, as the patient is variably 
interactive) in the setting of a reported right lower lobe 
pneumonia apparently noted on outpatient imaging on the day 
prior to presentation. On repeat imaging on presentation to 
___, there were no definite signs of pneumonia and there were 
no clinical indications of acute systemic inflammation or 
infection. She remained on her home ventilator settings at night 
and trach mask during the day. Although very broad spectrum 
antibiotics were provided on presentation in the ED, given the 
absence of infection on chest imaging and the lack of clinical 
symptoms of an acute infection, all antibiotics were stopped 
upon ICU admission, and she was monitored off of antibiotics for 
24 hours without any signs of clinical instability. She was 
subsequently discharged home without antibiotics.

ACUTE ISSUES 
============
# Concern for right upper lobe pneumonia (without radiographic 
or clinical evidence of right upper lobe pneumonia) 
# Chronic respiratory failure 
Ms. ___ has a tracheostomy tube in place in the setting of 
chronic respiratory failure, and requires ventilator support at 
night. During the day, she uses a humidifier with 3L of 
supplemental oxygen. Per history provided by her son (who is her 
primary caregiver at home), Ms. ___ has had increased 
secretions over the last week and an out-patient chest x-ray on 
___ was concerning for potential right upper lobe pneumonia. 
However, on presentation to ___, there was no compelling 
radiographic or clinical evidence of pneumonia. Blood cultures 
and a MRSA screen were negative. She specifically had minimal 
secretions on tracheal suctioning, no leukocytosis on her 
complete blood counts, no fever, no hypotension, no tachycardia, 
and no radiographic evidence of pneumonia (although her lung 
apices were not well visualized on chest x-ray to 
kyphoscoliosis). Ms. ___ was continued on her home 
ipratropium and levalbuterol nebuliizer treatemetns, and 
fomoterol(home med). Her ventilator settings should remain at RR 
___, PEEP 5, TV 300 (reduced from 400cc at home, given her 
height and predicted tidal volume), and FiO2 30%

# History of UTIs
In the ED, the patient did not urinate but on the floor she has 
been incontinent of urine. She has a history of UTIs, and during 
a recent prior hospitalizations, on ___ she grew Klebsiella 
and was appropriately treated. She had another UTI while at home 
prior to this hospitalization which was treated empirically with 
cephalexin and then switched to Bactrim. Urinalysis here ___ 
was without evidence of acute cystitis, and while there was 
initial concern for urinary retention she began to void 
spontaneously prior to discharge, and did not have any more 
issues with retention while inpatient.

# ___ disease 
# Dementia
During her last admission, Ms. ___ had some episodes of 
agitation overnight and her outpatient neurologist Dr. ___ 
___ was consulted. At that time, he recommended an additional 
1.5 tabs of Sinamet as needed at 3AM for agitation. During that 
prior hospitalization, this medication change was noted to 
improve her agitation overnight. Her son says that she 
communicates with him, is normally oriented to person and place, 
and can speak with Passy-Muir valve. We continued Sinamet at her 
home doses this admission.

CHRONIC ISSUES 
==============
#B/l UE catheter associated DVT
She had bilateral upper extremity DVTs diagnosed in ___, 
with repeat US in ___ showing no evidence of DVT. Now that she 
has been treated for more than six months, she remains on 
enoxaparin prophylaxis, which we continued during this 
hospitalization (and on discharge). 

#Hypothyroidism: We continued her home levothyroxine. 

#Esophageal dysmotility: s/p PEG: We continued the Nutrition 
service's final tube feed recommendations from her last 
admission.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for occasional wheezing and cough. There was 
concern for pneumonia but your chest X-ray did not show 
pneumonia and your symptoms quickly improved with nebulizers. 
Antibiotics were stopped and you tolerated this just fine. 
Overall, your presentation is most consistent with a post 
infectious bronchitis or asthma like syndrome.

You were evaluated by speech and language pathology who felt you 
would benefit from a ground diet with thin liquids to minimize 
your risks of accidentally inhaling some of your food when you 
eat (which can predispose to pneumonia and coughing fits).

You were deconditioned and had difficulty moving around and 
physical therapy recommended going to a rehab facility. You did 
not qualify for acute level rehab and so you and your family 
elected to go home with maximal services in order to work on 
getting stronger at home.

found to be sliding out of her chair. She eventually lowered 
onto her right knee, and struck her right forehead on the wood 
floor, son unable to cath her. The patient denies any LOC, 
headache, and per her son the patient was at her baseline mental 
status with normal behavior. She was noted to be ambulatory 
after this fall and headstrike, and used her walker to go to 
EMS. Her son notes that she had an episode of emesis in the 
ambulance.

She was recently admitted from ___ with unresolved cough 
and SOB despite outpatient treatment with doxycycline after 
being diagnosed with pneumonia at an OSH. She was treated for 
bronchitis vs. airway reactivity after infection with atrovent, 
fluticasone and albuterol. There was no evidence of pneumonia on

noted to have difficulty ambulating during the admission, and ___

She was admitted given her frailty, respiratory distress and

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ year old woman with a history of 
___ disease, bilateral blindness, HTN, presenting after 
a fall and head strike without LOC at home, admitted with 
respiratory distress and hypoxia in the ED with rapid 
resolution. 

# Mechanical Fall:
Patient discharged on the same day as re presentation to the ED. 
On previous admission, patient noted by ___ to be at high fall 
risk and recommended acute rehab however son declined as pt not 
accepted to first choice rehab. Patient admitted after fall from 
chair, most likely mechanical in etiology, as he patient was 
startled and slipped to the ground and in the setting of her 
weakness and ___ was unable to stop he fall. There was 
no loss of consciousness to suggest syncope as the etiology.  
Overall picture not consistent with seizure activity, as there 
was no post ictal period, also no elevation in lactate noted on 
labs, and the patient ambulated after the event with the use of 
a walker. Imaging including CT C spine, CT Head, CXR, Pelvis XR, 
bilateral knee XR and L ankle XR without fracture or acute 
pathology. There were no focal neuro signs on exam. ___ was 
consulted who recommended disposition to rehab. She was 
discharged to ___.

# Respiratory distress/Aspiration
While in the ED the patient developed respiratory 
distress/labored respirations requiring NC. The etiology was 
concerning for aspiration as she had been eating her medications 
with applesauce prior to the event. A repeat CXR in the ED was 
negative for aspiration, but may have been premature to 
visualize any changes. The differential also included airway 
reactivity, given the recent admission for reactive airways. She 
was quickly weaned to room air with nebulizer treatments. Given 
the concern for mild respiratory distress a third CXR was done 
on the floor, again without any signs of infiltrate or acute 
pathology. There was evidence of mild volume overload and pt 
received 10mg IV lasix. On the previous admission the patient 
was evaluated by SLP who recommended a diet of ground solids and 
thin liquids. SLP was re consulted this admission, and the 
patient underwent a video swallow due to concerns for bedside 
aspiration, which revealed penetration and trace aspiration, and 
the patient was initiated on a diet of ground solids and nectar 
thickened liquids. She was also seen by nutrition who 
recommended supplementation with ensure plus TID. She was 
continued on atrovent and albuterol nebulizer treatmens, and 
fluticasone inhaler. Of note, albuterol was used cautiously as 
caused pt to become tachycardiac.

# Hyponatremia - RESOLVED
Patient with new mild hyponatremia to 130, with concomitant 
hypochloremia. Likely secondary to hypovolemia given improvement 
with IVF. 
 
# Coagulopathy Elevated PTT - RESOLVED
Patient with newly elevated PTT on admission. On recent 
admission patient appears to have been on heparin 5000 U TID, 
though patient is of normal BMI, likely the etioloy of the 
elevated PTT. No concomitant elevation in INR, no 
thrombocytopenia to suggest DIC. No history of elevated PTT in 
the past to suggest the presence of an acquired or intrinsic 
inhibitor. Resolved with holding subC heparin. The patient was 
restarted on subC heparin for VTE prophylaxis with BID dosing 
without elevation in PTT

Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY:
================
Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed man with history 
notable for apical variant hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, HTN c/b 
CKD, pituitary microadenoma c/b hyperprolactinemia, and 
hypothyroidism presenting with a transient episode of 
right-sided sensory disturbance and lightheadedness.

NCHCT negative for acute stroke. MR with very small punctate 
subacute infarct in the left centrum semiovale. A stroke in this 
area explains his right sided sensory changes. Exam is normal. 
Etiology is likely small vessel disease
vs cardioembolic. 

Before MR imaging was finalized, seizure was on the differential 
for his transient symptoms, thus EEG was performed. Final read 
pending at time of discharge.

Risk factor labs notable for A1c 5.1%, TSH 3.9, LDL 46. Given 
LDL < 70, no indication to increase statin dose at the present 
time.

He was started on Aspirin 81 mg daily.

Given cardiac history and possible cardioembolic etiology, TTE 
was obtained. This showed apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 
without left ventricular or atrial mass (cardiac MRI would be 
more sensitive for focal apical thrombus, TEE for left atrial 
appendage thrombus). Mild mitral regurgitation. 

Ziopatch was placed for extended cardiac monitoring to assess 
for occult atrial fibrillation.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
- Continue aspirin 81mg for stroke prevention

- Ziopatch in place. Follow up read.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr ___,  

 You were hospitalized due to symptoms of right sided sensory 
changes resulting from a TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK, a condition 
where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain 
is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that 
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage 
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result 
in a variety of symptoms.  

 Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:  
 - High blood pressure  
 - High cholesterol

 We are changing your medications as follows:  
 - Please start Aspirin 81mg daily to help prevent future 
strokes 

 Please take your other medications as prescribed.  
 Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.  
 
 If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
 - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
 - Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
 - Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
 - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  
 
Sincerely,  
Your ___ Neurology Team

Impression:
1. Reassuring fetal testing. 

___ LIVER US
1. Normal liver echogenicity. No biliary duct dilatation. 
2. Limited Doppler due to breathing motion; however, normal flow 
is seen in main, left, and right portal vein, and main hepatic 
artery. Wall-to- wall flow in the hepatic veins. 
3. Unremarkable gallbladder with no evidence of cholelithiasis 
or 
cholecystitis. 

___ Liver, needle core biopsy:

1.  Marked portal and moderate periportal and lobular mixed 
inflammation with lobular disarray and numerous apoptotic 
hepatocytes.
2.  Moderate intrahepatic and canalicular cholestasis.
3.  No significant steatosis or ballooning degeneration are 
seen.
4.  Trichrome stain shows minimally increased portal fibrosis.
5.  Iron stain shows no stainable iron.
6.  Reticulin stain does not demonstrate significant hepatic 
parenchymal necrosis or collapse.
7.  Immunohistochemical stains for cytomegalovirus and herpes 
simplex viruses are pending and will be reported in an addendum.

Note: The features are compatible with a moderately active 
hepatitis with mixed inflammation, lobular disarray, feathery 
degeneration of hepatocytes, and moderate cholestasis.  The 
differential diagnosis includes an acute hepatitis of viral or 
drug-induced etiology.  Given the patient's negative autoimmune 
serologies and lack of prominent lobular plasmacytic component, 
an acute presentation of autoimmune hepatitis is less likely. 

ADDENDUM: 
Immunostains for cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex viruses I 
and II are negative with satisfactory controls.

Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital for surgery to remove your 
thymus gland and you've recovered well. You are now ready for 
discharge.

* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour 
while awake.

* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.

* Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours.  If it 
starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change 
it  as needed to keep site clean and dry.

 * You may need pain medication once you are home but you can 
wean it over the next week as the discomfort resolves.  Make 
sure that you have regular bowel movements while on narcotic 
pain medications as they are constipating which can cause more 
problems.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay 
regular.

* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.

* Take Tylenol  ___ mg every 6 hours in between your narcotic.  

* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions

* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
 * No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
 * No lotions or creams to incision site

* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

Call Dr. ___ ___ if you experience:
 -Fevers > 101 or chills
 -Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other 
symptoms that concern you.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with multiple vascular risk factors, including 
prior stroke, atrial fibrillation on River Oxilan and aspirin, 
hypertension, hyperlipidemia, insulin-dependent diabetes 
mellitus, who initially presented with persistent vertigo.  She 
reported a positional vertigo that did not dissipate initially 
on rest.  ED evaluation was notable for hyperglycemia to 430.  
She reported some recent changes with her diabetes medications, 
followed usually by her primary care.  There were no neighboring 
signs or symptoms, or additional review of system features 
suggestive of a peripheral vestibulopathy, such as neuronitis, 
or Ménière's disease,.  Her exam was not suggestive of central 
vertigo, though given her risk factors, she was admitted for 
stroke workup.  Her CTA was unremarkable.  MRI did not reveal 
any stroke, but did show an evolution of white matter disease in 
the periventricular areas.  Therefore, the most likely etiology 
of her symptoms was felt to be hyperglycemia causing 
vertigo-like symptoms, versus benign paroxysmal positional 
vertigo.  Her vertigo-like symptoms dissipated overnight into 
the next morning after admission.  Her blood sugars were better 
controlled while admitted, though her A1c was 12.7 reflecting 
likely poorly controlled diabetes as an outpatient. She 
indicated a desire to follow-up with her primary care provider, 
but as well as the ___ further 
management.  She was advised to stay hydrated to avoid the 
effect of glucose related diuresis.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

Your admitted to the hospital for vertigo, or a room spinning 
sensation.  Sometimes, vertigo is caused by stroke in part of 
the brain, so you are admitted for close monitoring and further 
workup.  Thankfully, your MRI did not show any strokes.  You 
felt better the next day in terms of vertigo, and you were able 
to walk around the hospital without any issues.  The most likely 
explanation for your symptoms therefore is something called 
benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, which can occur when the 
inner ear has problems with debris that builds up over time.  
The other possibility is your elevated blood sugars, which can 
certainly cause dizziness that may mimic vertigo.  In addition, 
the sugar in your blood can act as a diuretic medicine, removing 
more fluid than you are able to make up for by drinking.  This 
may lead to additional lightheadedness and feelings of dizziness 
which may have contributed to her symptoms.  If this happens 
again, you may be referred either to a neurologist or ___ 
rehab to help you with the symptoms, during which they may 
perform certain maneuvers to clear the debris from your year.  
Please contact your primary care provider if the symptoms recur. 
 However, if the symptoms persist, or are accompanied by changes 
in vision, including double vision, or weakness or sensation 
changes, please report to the nearest emergency department as 
they may reflect stroke.  Otherwise, please continue all of your 
medications as directed and do not miss doses.

It was a pleasure taking care of you.

___ neurology

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- You were admitted to the hospital because of shortness of 
breath and an irregular heartbeat.

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?
- In the hospital, we performed some lab tests to determine the 
reason for your shortness of breath. We also performed 
measurements of the electrical activity of your heart, which 
showed that it was beating in an irregular rhythm. We gave you a 
pill that would reduce the amount of water your body held onto 
as well as medications to decrease the resistance against which 
your heart pumped. These medications also decrease your 
heartrate. We also performed some imaging to look at your heart. 
Because your heartbeat was so fast and irregular, it wasn't 
pumping blood efficiently. The medications helped with this, but 
you required an electrical shock to convert your heart back into 
regular rhythm. We are glad you are feeling better after these 
procedures.

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?
- Please take all of your medications exactly as prescribed and 
attend all of your follow-up appointments listed below.
- It is particularly important that you do NOT miss ___ dose of 
your apixaban.

We wish you the best!
Your ___ Care Team

MRI PELVIS W/O & W/CONTRAST

Reason: assess for perirectal abscess. 
Contrast: MAGNEVIST

UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
___ year old man s/p liver transplant, rectal fissure surgery, 
fever. 
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
assess for perirectal abscess. 
CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

EXAMINATION: MR pelvis.

INDICATION: Status post liver transplant. Rectal fissure 
surgery, fever. Evaluate for perirectal abscess.

COMPARISON: Comparison is made with the previous MR from ___.

TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted images were acquired 
on a 1.5 Tesla magnet, including dynamic high-resolution 3D 
imaging, obtained prior to, during and after the uneventful 
intravenous administration of 0.1 mmol/kg of gadolinium-DTPA. 2D 
and 3D reformations and subtraction images were performed on an 
independent workstation.

MR PELVIS FINDINGS: In the ___ o'clock position (when viewed 
lithotomy position, left-to-left/posterior) of the 
intersphincteric space situated approximately 2 cm proximal to 
the anus, an area of crescentic high signal intensity is 
identified on the T2-weighted imaging (series 6, image 26) that 
measures 1.5 cm AP x 7 mm TV x 1.5 cm SI, with a peripherally 
enhancing rim, consistent with a tiny abscess too small to 
drain. This is at approximately the level of the levator ani 
(series 105a, image 14), and might communicate inferiorly with 
the rectal canal at the 6:00 location (series 100, image 68), 
approximately 4.5 cm superior from the anal verge.

A thin slip of high signal on T2W images (series 6, image 29), 
with thin curvilinear enhancement extends from this tiny 
collection inferiorly along the intersphincteric space and along 
the expected location of the internal sphincter from the 
___ location until reaching the anal verge, where there is 
thickening of the external sphincter on the left side (series 
104a, image 27). It is unclear if this represents a tract, or 
may be secondary to previous surgery or granulation tissue. This 
lays along the course of the fistula described in ___. No 
definite fluid is seen along this slip. Susceptibility is seen 
along the inferior aspect, similar to images from ___. The 
internal sphincter is hypoenhancing on post- gadolinium images, 
and indistinct but slightly hyperintense on T2W images, again 
possibly due to prior surgery.

There is nonspecific edema and vascular engorgement within the 
perirectal fat.

There are bilateral hydroceles with an inguinal hernia on the 
left containing some peritoneal fat and fluid. Left ureteral 
catheter is seen with pigtail curling within the bladder. 
Bladder is nondistended.

No evidence of any significant lymphadenopathy. The remainder of 
the bowel where visualized is unremarkable. The osseous 
structures where visualized are normal.

2D and 3D reformations provided multiple perspectives for the 
dynamic series.

IMPRESSION:
1. Small intersphincteric abscess from the 3 to 6 o'clock 
location (from lithotomoy position) on the left at the level of 
the levator ani. This may communicate with rectal lumen 
inferiorly, crossing the internal sphincter at the 6 o'clock 
position as described above, but is too small to drain.
2. No drainable abscess.
3. Mild hyperintensity on T2W images, mild enhancement, and 
thickening of left external sphincter along course of previously 
___ MRI) described intersphincteric tract, which may represent 
residual tract, or postoperative or granulation 
tissue--correlate with surgical history.
4. Bilateral hydroceles with left inguinal hernia containing fat 
and peritoneum.
5. Nonspecific edema and engorgement of vessels in perirectal 
fat. This may be due to hepatic disease and collateral portal 
blood flow.
6. Left ureteral stent with pigtail in the bladder. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
This was a ___ yo M s/p liver transplant in ___, pan-cytopenia, 
splenomegaly who presented with continuous oozing after tooth 
extraction.  Hospital course by problem below:  
Thrombocytopenia - platelet count of 69 on ___.  Platelet count 
on ___ was 14.  Neurontin (started on ___ and 
prophylactic antibiotics ___.  Neurontin was held.  DIC labs 
were negative for chronic DIC.  HIT Ab negative.  Parvovirus B19 
Ab negative. Bone marrow biopsy showed ITP. Prednisone and 
rituxan were not options for therapy given his history of Hep C. 
 The patient underwent two doses of IVIG at 35g, two days apart. 
He experienced only minimal improvement in his platelet counts 
each time, from ___.  He was also transfused platelets on two 
occasions, when his platelets decreased below 10.  he 
experienced only minimal improvement in platelet counts after 
transfusion, from ___.  It was decided that splenectomy would 
be the next best option for him. An abd CT was done on ___ to 
evaluate for splenic vein thrombosis. Findings were significant 
for non-occlusive thrombus adherent to the wall of the main 
portal, splenic, and the tributaries forming the SMV near the 
portosplenic confluence. 

On ___ splenectomy and distal pancreatectomy were performed. 
Surgeon was Dr. ___. Please see operative note for 
further details. A ___ drain was placed. Postop, he was sent 
to the SICU. Pain management was an issue requiring Acute Pain 
service management. He was trasferred out of the SICU to the 
med-surg unit where he continued to have high outputs via the JP 
(~ 3 liters) for which he received IV fluid replacements and 
albumin. Given that he had a distal pancreatectomy, the JP fluid 
was sent for amylase. This was initially 191 on ___, but 
increased to 4170 on ___. A repeat JP amylase on ___ was 2769. 
JP drainage trended down to 40 by ___

Bacteremia: Patient developed fever and leukocytosis on ___.  
He was treated empirically for a neutropenic fever with 
cefepime.  The following day his fever had resolved.  Blood 
cultures grew pan sensitive e.coli. His abx were switched to 
cipro, and his PICC line was removed. A source of his bacteremia 
was thought to be from a perirectal abscess identified on MRI.  
He remained afebrile while on cipro. A general surgery consult 
was obtained with recommendations for an MRI.  A MRI was done 
noting small intersphincteric abscess from the 3 to 6 o'clock 
location (from lithotomoy position) on the left at the level of 
the levator ani. This was non-drainable. Cipro and flagyl were 
recommended for 2 weeks. On ___ CVL was d/c'd for low grade 
temps. 

On ___ he was febrile to 101.2. Blood and urine cultures were 
negative. JP fluid was negative for growth. An abd CT was done 
revealing partially walled-off fluid in the left upper abdomen 
with air locules, interval progression of nonocclusive thrombus 
in the portal system, to a greater degree in the splenic vein 
and left portal vein, moderate left pleural effusion, and left 
nephroureteral stent in stable position, with moderate 
dilatation of the left renal pelvis, which has progressed from 
the prior study. A heparin drip was started. Coumadin was then 
started with goal inr achieved and discontinuation of heparin. 
He was sent home on a coumadin dose of 0.5mg qd with inr to be 
drawn on ___. 

On ___ he spiked a temp to 101.8. Blood and urine cultures were 
again sent with the urine negative and blood cultures negative 
to date. Vanco and Zosyn were started on ___. A CXR 
demonstrated L lung base atelectasis and a small left pleural 
effusion. A CT guided exchange of the drain was done for failure 
of the JP to drain. Upsizing of left abdominal drain as 
described above without immediate complications. Pull back study 
through track failed to demonstrate track communucation with the 
left thorax or left pleural effusion. The drain was upsized. 

Vanco and Zosyn were started on ___. After 3 doses, the zosyn 
was switched to Levaquin. Flagyl was added on ___. He was 
discharged home on Vanco, flagyl and Levaquin with indefinate 
duration pending resolution of fluid collection. He did complain 
of some loose stool which was sent for c.diff x 2. These were 
negative.

Brief Hospital Course:
Temperature was 101 on admission. Urine and blood cultures were 
negative. The LUQ drain continued to have tan, thick drainage. 
On HD 2, he spiked a temperature to 102. WBC increased to 14 
from 11. Drainage was sent for culture. This grew proteus 
resistent to cipro otherwise pan-sensitive.  An abdominal CT was 
done on ___ as followup evaluation of the known portal vein 
thrombus and fever. This showed a large left pleural effusion, 
increased in size with increased lower lobe atelectasis. The LUQ 
pigtail catheter was unchanged in position with continued 
decrease in fluid about the catheter tip, nearly resolved. There 
was unchanged marked dilation of the portal, splenic, and 
superior mesenteric veins with extensive nonocclusive thrombus, 
also unchanged and unchanged left urothelial thickening. There 
was unchanged retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. 

Given these findings, CT guided drainage of the left pleural 
effusion was performed on ___. He received 6 units of  FFP 
prior to the procedure for INR of 4.5
450cc of sero-sanguinous fluid was aspirated with an 8 ___ 
pigtail drain left to external bag drainage. Cultures were sent 
with results noting 2+ pmn and no growth. 

He was initially started on cipro and flagyl, but these were 
switched to unasyn and vanco on ___. Pan-cultures were sent for 
persistent temperatures up to 102. Urine and blood cultures 
remained negative. Lungs remained diminished at the bases. 
Thoracic surgery was consulted for concern for empyema. On ___ 
he underwent VATS with decortication for left empyema.  Surgeon 
was Dr. ___. Please see operative note for complete 
details. FFP was given for reversal of coumadin effect. Postop, 
he did well. Pain was controlled with PCA dilaudid. Two chest 
tubes were to suction. Daily CXR was done. Diet was advanced and 
tolerated. 

Left lung tissue cultures grew staph aureus coag + resistent to 
levo, cipro, oxacillin, clinda and erythromycin. It was 
sensitive to vanco. The BAL culture grew klebsiella pneumoniae 
resistance to cipro, cephalosporins, but sensitive to meropenum, 
zosyn, bactrim and gentamycin. There was sparse yeast. Unasyn 
was switched to meropenum. He continue to have low grade 
temperatures with wbc trending down to 11. Meropenum was given 
from ___ and vanco continued from ___. Both were 
stopped per ID recommendations. A picc line was placed for 
antibiotics. This was removed on the day of discharge ___. He 
remained afebrile (no higher than 100)off antibiotics x 2 days. 

Coumadin was resumed on ___. INR slowly trended up on 3mg qd. 
This was decreased to 2mg qd on ___ for inr of 2.8.

LFTs trended up with alk phos increasing to 711 from baseline of 
mid ___. On ___ a transjugular biopsy was performed given that 
he was on coumadin. Unfortunately, the specimen was an 
insufficient sample. Alk phos started to trend back down 
slightly. Further biopsying was deferred. Immunosuppression 
remained the same with prednisone 3mg qd and prograf 1mg q pm 
and 0.5mg qam for levels that ranged between ___. 

Chest tubes were changed to water seal then the apical chest 
tube was removed leaving the lower lobe tube.  Follow up cxr 
showed a small left apical pneumothorax. The lower lobe chest 
tube was left in and converted to a pneumostat valve (to empty, 
attach ___ lock syringe and aspirate back). Drainage averaged 
___ cc of serosanguinous fluid non-foul smelling. 

On ___, follow up chest CT showed persistent left pleural fluid 
with decrease in the volume of subphrenic fluid in the left 
subphrenic space. Well perfused liver with slight decrease in 
size of thrombus in the aneurysmally dilated left portal vein, 
the extent of thrombus in the extrahepatic portal and splenic 
veins was unchanged. A new fluid collection was noted 
inferomedial to the right kidney. No hydronephrosis was present. 


The plan was to leave the chest tube in place until after the 
LUQ pigtail catheter is removed.The LUQ pigtail drainage 
averaged ~ 20cc of tan thick fluid. 

He was discharged home on ___ ambulatory and tolerating a 
regular diet. 
He will follow up with Drs. ___ in the 
outpatient clinic. ___ services were arranged and follow up labs 
were ordered.

___ Vanco-19.___ y/o male s/p liver transplant ___ years ago now with recurrent 
fever after drain removal 2 weeks ago from known fluid 
collection in the splenectomy bed.
He was started on Vanco and Meropenum and a CT of the abdomen 
obtained on admission showed:
-Reaccumulation of intraabominal abscess within the left upper 
quadrant.
-Left pleural collection small in size with thicked, enhancing 
pleura likely representing empyema, decreased in size compared 
to prior.
-Stable partial chronic thrombus seen within the portal vein and 
splenic veins which are markedly dilated.
After undergoing reversal of his INR with FFP, he underwent 
percutaneous drainage of the known fluid collection in the 
abdomen. Approximately 50 cc of purulent fluid was aspirated, 
with sample sent for culture and gram stain. The catheter was 
attached to a drainage bag and left to open drainage. An attempt 
was made to aspirate any collection in the pleural space, but no 
fluid was available for aspiration.
The fluid culture grew Proteus and this will be continued to be 
treated with IV Meropenum until re-evaluation by the ID team as 
an outpatient. Blood cultures drawn at the beginning of the 
hospitalization have been consistently negative, however there 
are several that remain pending at the time of discharge.

to pursue CBD stone extraction. He was stable post ERCP. IV 
heparin was resumed, and he was restarted on the Coumadin. INR 
therapeutic at discharge.

showed that the left upper quadrant fluid collection since 
___ is stable, there is decreased empyema. Also grossly 
stable liver transplant with chronic thrombus in the portal and 
splenic veins. Pigtail drain was removed.

## Hypotension/Fever/Infectious work up: SBP improved on the 
floor without intervention. Patient appears dry on exam, and may 
have poor po intake in the setting of recent teeth extraction. 
___ also be related to increase in pain medication. Afebrile and 
nontoxic appearing. Denies localizing symptoms for infection. 
Orthosatics were negative on admission. Patient did have one 
temperature in house to 101, but remained afebrile after that 
with antibiotics. Culture data (including blood and urine), UA, 
as well as Chest xrays and RUQ u/s were unrevealing. Patient did 
have recent bottom teeth removed, so he was given Chlorhexadine 
mothwash for sterility as this could potentially be an 
infectious source. Patient's lasix was held for concern of 
worsening blood pressure and for decreasing sodium. Plan to 
restart lasix as outpatient pending repeat labs. 
.
## Change in Mental Status: Patient fully oriented on exam 
throughout hospital stay. Mild asterexis which indicated hepatic 
encephalopathy could be contributing.

Given Fena less than 1 BUN/Cr ratio of 23, very likely pre-renal 
in etiology. Cr improved back to baseline with gentle hydration 
prior to discharge.

signs of dramatic encephalopathy.  RUQ u/s revealed previously

#. Acute on chronic renal failure - Patient with known Stage II 
CKD, currently w/ increase in Cr up to 2.4 x 1 week but his UOP 
continued to be at baseline. His decreased to Cr 1.7 after 1L 
IVF. His ARF was  thought to be due to pre-renal azotemia 
because of dehydration and this was validated by his great 
response to hydration. His FeNa was 2.7% and FeUrea was 57% and 
the discrepancy between these values and pre-renal azotemia was 
thought to be due to the patient being on diuretics at home as 
these could account for the FeNa being high. His Cr was 1.3 on 
discharge which is baseline. 
.
#. Cough - Patient presented with 2 weeks of cough and unchanged 
CXR from basline. This was thought to be due to a viral URI and 
patient's condition improved while in the hospital. 
.
#. ESLD s/p transplant - Pt with elevated INR but no other signs 
of acute liver failure. His tacro level is whithin target range. 
RUQ U/S is unchanged w/ complete obstruction of portal and 
splenic veins. He was continued on his home dose medications.
.
#. SVT - Pt with h/o SVT, rate control with double nodal agents. 
Atenolol was switched to metoprolol initially for ease of dosing 
and ARF since atelolol is renally metabolized. Upon discharge he 
was switched back to his atenolol home dose. He had no issues 
with SVT during his hospitalization.
.
#. ITP - s/p splenectomy PLTs remained stable throughout 
hospitalization.
.
#. Primary hypogonadism - Patient had no issues. Testosterone 
was continued.
.
#. Depression - Patient denied any SI or thought of harming 
others. Rare zoloft s/e could be ARF and considering recent 
increase of dose this could have caused ARF. Zoloft was held 
initially and continued upon discharge.
.
#. DM - Thought to be steroid induced, currently diet 
controlled, no issues w/ hyper or hypoglycemia
.
#. Hyperparathyroidism - Secondary to CKD. Stable. Continued on 
home meds.
.
#. Adiction - Pt with h/o polysubstance abuse. Continued on home 
methadone.
.
#. Splenectomy - Pt s/p splenectomy at risk of infection with 
encapsulated organisms. Afebrile did well throughout admission.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo m with hx of liver transplant with recurrent cirrhosis, 
admitted with AMS, fever, and apnea.  
.
AMS/Encephalopathy: Presentation to ICU with altered mental 
status was initially secondary to hepatic encephalopathy and 
delerium from multiple infections: pneumonia and abdominal 
abcess.  Initial work up involved: a lumbar puncture with normal 
CSF, CT of the head sig for no acute process, and negative blood 
and urine cultures.  An ultrasound of the abdomen showed chronic 
portal vein thrombosis.  Patient was continued on lactulose and 
started on rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy.  Mental status 
decompensated ___ during hospitalization secondary to 
iatrogenic narcotic overdose (see below for full details) in the 
ICU, but improved with narcan x1 and holding of all sedating 
medications (oxycodone, methadone, and trazadone).  Mental 
status improved to baseline with treatment of multiple infection 
and rifaimin and lactulose.
.
Apnea: Patient was found to be apneic and intubated in the ED.  
Respiratory depression was felt to be related to hepatic 
encephalopathy and delirium secondary to PNA and abdominal 
abscess infections.  Patient was extubated on ___ without any 
complications.   On ___ patient was agitated, placed on wrist 
restraints, and given haldol, trazadone and oxycodone in the 
ICU.  Upon transfer to the floor the subsequent day the patient 
was apneic with constricted pupils secondary to iatrogenic 
oversedation.  He was given narcan x1 and respiratory status 
improved.  All sedating medications, oxycodone, methadone, and 
trazadone were held.  Patient remained stable on room air 
without any respiratory problems and was restarted on his home 
dose of trazadone at a later date.  Patient had self tapered 
from methadone (see below) and this was not restarted as he no 
longer complained of pain. 
.  
Pneumonia: On presentation, patient was febrile with 
leukocytosis and was started on broad spectrum antibiotics.  A 
CT ___ showed a RLL pneumonia with parapneumonic effusions.  
Patient completed a course of antibiotic therapy for community 
acquired vs aspiration pneumonia with cefepime (___) and 
leukocytosis improved.  Interval CXR improvement of 
consolidation and repeat CT showed resolution of pneumonia.
.
LUQ abcess: This abcess is a recurrent process after distal 
pancreatectomy and splenectomy and has required multiple courses 
of IV antibiotics and drainage in the past.  Patient initially 
was started on Vanc (___), Flagyl (___), and 
Cipro (___).  CT of abdomen showed abdominal abcess (4 x 10cm) 
and patient went for ___ guided drainage.  Initial set of abcess 
cultures demonstrated proteus resistant to cipro.  He antibiotic 
regimen were changed to Flagyl (day 1: ___ and Cefepime 
(day 1: ___ and restarted ___.  A picc line was 
placed ___.  Patient was put on trial of PO bactrim DS 
monotherapy, which he failed and cefepime iv was reinitiated 
(___).  A second set of abcess cultures were sent which showed 
ESBL organism (pan-resistant klebsiella).  Infectious disease 
was consulted and the patient was maintained on iv cefepime 
throughout the rest of his hospitalization and the JP drain 
continued to drain ___ of serosangounous fluid.  Patient 
underwent ERCP with stent placement in the CBD for prevention of 
future reaccumulation.  A repeat CT of the abdomen ___ showed 
improvement of the fluid collection.  JP drain accidentally fell 
out when patient getting up out of bed ___ and was unable to 
be replaced under ___ because fluid collection not observable on 
CT.  Patient was discharged with iv meropenem ___ to rehab 
with follow up with infectious disease to determine when 
antibiotic would be transitioned to PO prophylactic regimen.  
.
Nutrition: An NGT was placed in the ICU and discontinued upon 
transfer to the floor.  The patient passed speech and swallow, 
but continued to have very poor PO intake while on the floors.  
Nutrition was consulted and calorie counts were done.  Patient 
was encouraged to increase PO intake but reported little 
appetite, and abdominal discomfort with eating.  A decision was 
made to replace feeding tube on ___ and tube feeds were 
started.
.
Hypercalcemia: Patient had hypercalcemia, and was maintained on 
IVFs.  TSH and cortisol were normal, and a PTH was abnormally 
within normal limits.  His endocronologist was contacted, who 
reported secondary hyperparathyroid disease from vitamin D 
deficiency.  His calcitriol was discontinued, with some 
improvement in his calcium levels.  A PTHrP was pending.  
Patient was discharged on his home dose of oral bisphosphonate.
.  
S/p liver transplant with recurrent liver failure: Tacro level 
elevated and on ___ was changed from home dose of 0.5 mg bid 
to 0.5 ever other day.  Elevation in trough thought to be in the 
setting of multiple antibiotics and being off coumadin. Patient 
was continued lamivudine for ppx and home ursodiol.  He was 
treated with lactulose and rifaximin was started.  Bactrim was 
changed to dapsone for PCP prophylaxis as patient was 
persistantly hyperkalemic.
. 
Chronic Pain: Patient has chronic rectal pain s/p fissures and 
multiple complications.  A rectal tube was put in place for skin 
protection given multiple bowel movements while uptitrating 
lactulose.  Rectal tube was d/c'd on ___.  While in the ICU, 
patient receiving home dose of gabapentin.  He was also given 
5mg Methadone tid, as regular dose could not be confirmed, and 
10mg of oxycodone.  On transfer to the floor patient was apneic 
secondary to overdose of sedating medications and narcan was 
given x1 with improvement in respiratory status.  Methadone and 
oxycodone were discontinued.  Pain was not an issue on this 
admission and methadone was not restarted as he was 
self-tapered.
.
PVT: Patient has chronic PVT and was on coumadin as outpatient.  
Coumadin was d/c since last hospitalization in the setting of 
elevated INR.  Decision made to keep patient permanently off 
coumadin.
.
Anemia: Patient has chronic anemia secondary to liver disease.  
Hematocrit remained stable throughout hospitalization.  
.   
Diabetes: BS only mildly elevated patient was initially 
maintained on ISS.  This was discontinued as his fingersticks 
were within normal limits. 
.  
Hypertension: Initially atenolol and Cartia were held given an 
episode of bradycardia in the MICU.  HR improved and patient was 
started on metoprolol while inpatient.  BP remained stable and 
he had no further episode of bradycardia.
.
SVT: Patient has a history of SVT, with a normal ECG in the 
emergency room.  Patient had an episode of bradycardia in the 
MICU (as above) and so diltiazam and atenolol were initially 
held.  Patient was subsequently started on metoprolol while 
inpatient and diltiazam was held.  Heart rate remained in 60-70s 
throughout remainder of hospitalization. 
.  
Coagulopathy: Patient had a recent supratheraputic INR, and 
coumadin was not restarted.  Coags were monitored and INR 
decreased and remained stable at 1.3. 
.
HyperKalemia: Patient had episodes of hyperkalemia, with normal 
ECGs and treated with kayexelate.  A hemolysis work up was done 
and was negative. His bactrim ppx was d/c'd and switched to 
dapsone.  Patient was started on florinef with improvement in K. 
 Florinef was discontinued and K remained within normal limits 
throughout rest of his hospitalization.
.
Depression: Patient was continued on home dose of sertraline.  A 
family meeting was arranged to discuss goals of care.  Patient 
expressed that he wanted to live and have optimal medical 
manegement.

Discharge Instructions:
You were seen in the hospital for altered mental status, lung 
infection and abdominal infection.  You were intubated because 
you were not breathing well.  Your breathing and mental status 
improved as we treated your liver disease with lactulose and 
rifaximin and as we treated your pneumonia and abdominal 
infection with antibiotics.  

We put a drain to help resolve your abdominal infection, when 
the drain was discontinued we were not able to put it back in 
because there was no longer any fluid collection.  You underwent 
an ERCP and had a stent placed to prevent further reaccumulation 
of infection.  You were not eating well and so a feeding tube 
was placed.

The following changes were made to your medications:

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with hepatitis C cirrhosis s/p liver 
transplant with recurrent hepatitis C cirrhosis complicated by 
ascites/encephalopathy who was admitted with GIB/melena.
   
#.  LGIB:  Initial immediate concern was for UGIB, particularly 
variceal bleeding or portal gastropathy in this patient with 
decompensated liver disease.  Differential also included 
gastritis and LGI sources, including hemorrhoids, 
diverticulosis, AVM.  The patient immediately received 2U PRBCs 
post transfusion hct decreased from 25.9 in the ED to 25.8.  
Protonix gtt, octreotide gtt and ceftriaxone daily were started. 
 EGD was performed upon arrival to the ICU which showed 
non-bleeding esphageal and gastric varices as well as an oozing 
gastric polyp which was injected with epinephrine- nothing to 
suggest the cause of patients relatively brisk decrease in 
hematocrit.  Colonoscopy was performed on HD2 which again did 
not show any obvious cause of bleeding.  Dark old blood was 
noted to be transiting through the colon.  Hct trended down 
gently on HD2 and another 1U PRBC transfusion was given.  The 
patient underwent capsule endoscopy on HD2 which showed several 
small ulcers in the small bowel.
  
#. Hepatitis C cirrhosis s/p liver transplant:  Tbili slightly 
elevated from baseline although AST, ALT, alk phos improved from 
baseline.  Patient was not clinically encephalopathic while in 
the ICU.  Transplant surgery was consulted and aware of patient. 
Tacrolimus 0.5mg PO BID, Lamivudine 100mg PO daily (donor was 
HbcAb positive) and Ursodiol 300mg PO BID were continued.
   
#. Duodenal polyp- a non-bleeding duodenal polyp was seen on EGD 
that should be biopsied as an outpatient at a later date.

1. LGIB: Reported to have melena, although at different time 
noted to have brown stool with bloody mucous. Immediate concern 
was for UGIB, particularly variceal bleeding or portal 
gastropathy in this patient with decompensated liver disease. Pt 
with small intestine ulcers on recent capsule study. EGD on ___ 
with non bleeding varices at the lower third of the esophagus 
and gastroesophageal junction, portal hypertensive gastropathy, 
polyp in proximal body of stomach, and 8 mm non bleeding polyp 
adjacent to hepatico-jejunostomy. The patient had an RBC scan, 
which showed no definite bleeding seen on 90 minute dynamic 
imaging, but activity in the rectum on left lateral is 
compatible with rectal bleeding. Pt had a sigmoidoscopy the next 
morning on ___ that noted blood coating the colon, but no e/o 
active bleeding. ___ declined angiography at this time, as it 
would be very low yield as no bleeding was noted on the RBC 
scan. Over the pt's ICU course, he was transfused 5 units pRBCs. 
The patient's HCT remained stable at 34 prior to call out to the 
floor. On the floor the patient remained hemodynamically stable 
however he continued to experience melanotic stools with a 
downward trend in his hematocrit. He became transfusion 
dependent, requiring about 2units/day. He subsequently had a 
CT-A to looked for vascular abnormalities such as scarred 
varices however this was unremarkable. A tagged red blood cell 
study was repeated which showed no source of bleeding.  The 
patient continued to have melena, requiring ___ units of PRBCs 
to maintain adequate hematocrit.  The decision was made between 
the patient and the team to proceed with an exploratory 
laparotomy and a possible endoscopy in the OR. The patient was 
taken to the OR on ___ with Dr ___. At the time of 
surgery a small enterotomy
was made longitudinally and just in the Roux limb just beyond 
the jejunojejunostomy. A colonoscope was advanced in from this 
location distally toward the terminal ileum and then withdrawn. 
No evidence of ulcerations or intramucosal or intraluminal 
pathology was identified. A second enterotomy was made distally 
in the mid to distal ileum, again transversely and then the 
colonoscope  was placed in this location and advance distally 
into the terminal ileum and then eventually into the cecum. This 
was withdrawn and again no identified lesions were noted. A 
bleeding source was not identified during the surgery.    
On POD 2 the patient had HR in the 130's and was found to be in 
Afib, he was given Beta blocker and monitored.
Hematocrit was trended, in the ensuing days he received a total 
of 4 units pRBCs. 
He was also evaluated by nutrition services. After following 
oral intakenit was determined to place a post pyloric feeding 
tube and start tube feeds.
The wound was having ascitic fluid drainage, several clips were 
removed and a VAC was placed. The patient had copius amounts of 
fluid from the VAC, and the output was repleted with 
intermittent albumin and IV fluids.
On POD 19 the patient was transferred to the SICU for increased 
confusion. A head CT was obtained which showed no evidence of 
acute intracranial abnormalities. 
The patient remained in the SICU for 8 days. He was additionally 
followed by neurology who atributed his confusion to 
encephelopathy of metabolic of infectious etiology. An LP was 
performed and infectious etiologies including cryptococcus were 
ruled out. He had been started on acyclovir pending results of 
LP, He received 6 days of this. In addition he received 6 days 
of fluconazole for yeast in the urine. An EEG showed an abnormal 
routine EEG in the waking state due to 
a mildly slow and disorganized background with frequent theta 
rhythms. 
There were no focal, lateralized, or epileptiform abnormalities 
noted. 
He also had an unremarkable BAL. He was covered with Vanco and 
meropenum, but never was febrile and all cultures were returned 
as negative and the antibiotics were discontinued.
The patient eventually cleared and was able to be transferred 
back to ___ 10. He continued to have large volume ascited from 
the wound VAC and continued with albumin and fluid replacements, 
the albumin replacement will continue upon discharge and extra 
fluids are being instilled with tube feeds.
Two days prior to discharge, he spiked a fever and had increased 
abdominal pain. His UA was concerning for a potential UTI, and 
he was covered with ciprofloxacin.  His urine cultures 
eventually returned contaminated, and the ciprofloxacin was 
dicontinued.  Additionally, his PICC line was removed and sent 
for culture, which showed no significant growth.
   
2. Acute on chronic renal failure: Creatinine 1.4 on admission, 
likely due to decreased perfusion in the setting of bleed. 
Improved to 1.0 but then elevated post op as high as 1.7. 
Medications were adjusted accordingly. With adequate hydration 
and use of albumin the patient once again returned to baseline 
creatinine of 1.1 by day of discharge.

# GI bleed: Pt has a h/o GI bleeds of unknown etiology despite 
numerous studies including EGDs, colonoscopies, bleeding 
studies, and an intraoperative endoscopy. He was recently 
admitted from ___, w/o identifying the bleeding source. He 
was discharged with a plan to have twice weekly outpatient CBCs 
with transfusions as needed. However, he continued to have 
numerous large bloody stools and a large drop in Hct, so he was 
again admitted to the hospital. A repeat tagged RBC scan failed 
to show the source of the bleed. He was then challenged with 
heparin, however he did not bleed and so he was reversed with 
protamine. He then had a large melanotic stool, so he was taken 
to angio and challenged with intra-artrial heparin to the SMA 
and ___. Again, no source of bleeding was found. Colonoscopy and 
EGD were performed with no bleeding source identified. He was 
started on Amicar. He remained hemodynamically stable and was 
transferred to the floor. On the floor, patient continued to 
have intermittent episodes of bleeding requiring transfusions. 
He underwent red blood cell scan which showed possible delayed 
bleed around hepatic flexure. He subsequently underwent 
colonoscopy which was essentially negative, showing one non 
bleeding diverticulum. He had a brief trial of octreotide, which 
was d/c-ed after one day secondary to cramping. He was finally 
started on a trial of estrogen therapy. Underwent a capsule 
study which was also negative. As of ___ he had required 17 
units of pRBCs during this hospitalization.  During this time he 
was also treated for a complicated UTI with a course of cipro.

held with patient's three sisters, pain and palliative care,

wanted any blood products.  He also complained of discomfort

and patient was placed on a morphine drip titrated to comfort.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ presented to ___ for admission prior to surgery 
and pre-surgical hydration on ___. Later that day she was 
taken to the OR for Right craniotomy for clipping of PCOMM 
aneurysm. Patient tolerated the procedure well. Please see 
formal op report in OMR for further intra operative details. She 
was successfully extubated and transferred to PACU for post op 
management.

#PCOMM aneurysm
The patient is now s/p right crani PCOMM aneurysm clipping 
performed ___. She was transferred from the PACU to the ___ 
for Q2h neuro checks and ongoing care and surveillance. She 
remained neurologically intact throughout her time in the ___ 
and was made floor status on POD#2. On POD#3, patient received 
IV decadron x1 for right periorbital edema.

#Pain Control
On POD1, the patient continued to have headaches that were 
controlled with PO and IV management. Acute pain management was 
consulted. After evaluating the patient, they recommended 
switching her Oxycodone PO prn to Dilaudid ___ Q4hrs prn 
severe pain. She remained on APAP prn, Fioricet prn, 
Cyclobenzaprine prn, Gabapentin and Tizanadine. Her IV pain 
medications were discontinued on POD#2.

#Asymptomatic hypotension
Overnight on POD#3, patient experienced a brief episode of 
asymptomatic hypotension likely secondary to the combination of 
medications she recieved. Medication management was discussed 
with the patient prior to discharge and she voiced 
understanding. Her lisinopril dose was decreased from 20mg to 
5mg. Patient should follow up with her PCP regarding this 
medication dose change.

Discharge Condition:

Discharge Instructions:
Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
Practitioner if you experience:

- Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or 
movement

- Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision

- Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
lethargy

- Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

- Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications

Activity:
- Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
slowly and increase at your own pace.

- Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days 
after your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more 
detail at the time of your suture removal.  

Incision Care:

- Keep your wound clean and dry.

- Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 

- When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run 
off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel to 
dry.

- Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the 
incision line.

- You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery

Post-Operative Experiences: Physical

- Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away 
after about a month

- You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be 
prevented by:

o Drinking plenty of fluids
oIncreasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, 
fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements
oExercising
oUsing over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as needed, 
stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements or 
diarrhea

- Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time

- Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can 
take weeks or months to fully resolve

- Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area

- Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve 
with increased activity

Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional

- You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
include

o Feeling down or sad
o Irritability, frustration, and confusion
o Distractibility
o Lower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges
o Insomnia
o Loneliness

- If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary 
Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or 
Psychiatrist

- You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in 
your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation

o More information can be found at ___
